PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Diabetics: Insulin
To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent Diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N.H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mrs Child,Mr Cunningham,Mr Duffy,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren,Mr Milton,Dr Theophanous and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Bungey,Mr Campbell,Mr Dawkins and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, and That no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of Nathalia post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of the Skipton post office 3361 places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Canning, Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Berowra respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Werriwa respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of Milpo, Ingleburn, NSW, 2174 post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's sales tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its sales tax legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross and Dr Everingham.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a Sales Tax of 17 1/2% on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully demand:
That the decision to introduce a seventeen and a half percent sales tax on pet food, which will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, should be reversed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its sales tax legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Aid to Polish Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That recent events in Poland are of such seriousness as to justify Australia's direct involvement in attempts to relieve tension there.
Your petitioners note that food shortages are a major cause of civil unrest.
Your petitioners further note that Australia has the capacity to make direct donations of food at short notice.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;
That the Federal Government make the Polish Government an immediate and substantial offer of food aid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Sinai Peacekeeping Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Bipartisan concern exists in the Australian community over involvement of Australian military forces in the Middle East where those forces are not under United Nations auspices;
2. concern is also evident about Australia's military capacity to provide those forces without weakening Australia's defence;
3. Sinai is not an area within Australia's sphere of influence; and
4. Australian agricultural export markets may be adversely affected by Australian military participation in Sinai.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament does not ratify Australian military participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force, unless that force is fully controlled by the United Nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Copyright
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Copyright Act as amended by the Copyright Amendment Act, 1980, places unnecessary restrictions on the education system.
All photocopying and videorecording used exclusively for education purposes should be exempted from the provisions of the Copyright Act.
Any amendments to the copyright law which affect the education system should not be made operative during an academic year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that the Federal Government ensures that:
(a) It honours its 1975 election promise to maintain Medibank-a free, universal health insurance scheme, and institute methods of improving hospital and health services for the Australian people.
(b) The Community Health Program remains a Federal Government responsibility, with increased funding and expansion of services.
(c) It abandons means-testing and the re-introduction of charges at public hospitals which will severely disadvantage low and middle income groups.
(d) Every effort be made by the Federal Government to meet the health care needs and demands of the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give earnest consideration to this most vital matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 take into consideration the protection of the Island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Because of an anomaly in tax rates a single income family pays nearly $10 a week more tax than a dual income family earning the same total amount.
2. Family allowances established in 1976 have not been increased since then, yet over the same period living costs have increased by nearly 60%.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that:
The Parliament should act:-
(1) To restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them for future price rises.
(2) To increase the spouse rebate from $830 to $1,342 per year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths.
That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's Airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m and 6 a.m would-
(a) Substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep.

(b) Contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Honourable Ralph Hunt, in reply to a Question on Notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the pressure of cheap imports, the high cost of new homes and the effects of the credit squeeze are seriously weakening consumer demand for furniture.
That an increase on sales tax for furniture and mattresses would be a complete disaster for the Furniture Industry causing widespread bankruptcy and unemployment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with an increase on sales tax for the furniture and mattresses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Government to abandon the only tangible form of direct assistance to Australia's young unemployed, i.e., the Community Youth Support Scheme, will have a serious effect on the thousands of young Australians presently benefiting from the operation of the scheme through almost 300 decentralised CYSS centres around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse this retrograde decision before the due date of termination on October 31st.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the single parent is part of the most disadvantaged section of the community,
That 73 per cent of single parents will not be assisted by the restricted increase in family allowance,
That neither the guardian's allowance nor the child allowance is indexed,
That sales tax increases on such basic essentials as clothing and shoes will severely disadvantage single parents,

That a single parent with one child receives $66.65 per week plus $6.00 guardian's allowance, plus $10.00 child allowance and $3.80 family allowance (totalling $86.45) compared to a married pensioner couple's combined weekly income of $111.10,
That the means test for a married pensioner couple is $34.50, compared to $26.00 for a single parent with one child,
That a married pensioner couple's income, if shared, will not be taxable, whereas a single parent, even with the lone parent rebate, will pay $386 tax.

And finally that, while agreeing that pensions are inadequate to meet rising prices, comparisons between age and invalid pensions and widows pension indicate even greater disadvantage being suffered by single parents.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will increase the amount of widows pension and supporting parent benefit, index the guardian's allowance, child's allowance and family allowance, raise the tax-free threshold for income tax, and remove the sales tax increase announced in the Budget from essential items.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women and children in the Australian community who use the services of Women's Refuges, Women's Health Centres and Women's Rape Crisis Centres:

(1) Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some States;
(2) Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
(3) Request that the Government ensure one Department to administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
(4) Propose that future funding be on a guaranteed triennial basis taking into account inflation and indexation increases; and
(5) Ask for a positive policy commitment for a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and to develop new initiatives for women and children in the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Women's Refuge Programme. In particular that:
1. Realistic funding levels be introduced to maintain existing services offered by women's refuges.
2. That the needs for child care in women's refuges be acknowledged by a specific and adequate allocation of funds for this purpose.
3. That funding be allocated for the purpose of assisting women and children to establish themselves in the community on leaving refuges.
4. That funding be allocated for refuges to address themselves to areas of special needs of migrant women in refuges.
5. That funding be made available for the establishment of new women's refuges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the burden of interest payments on housing loans is now at such record levels that most citizens paying off their homes are becoming severely financially distressed.
That the burden of additional expense together with increases in health insurance and hospital charges is putting increasing stress on family relationships.
That the policies of favouring overseas private investors to buy up our resources are causing inflationary pressures, declining public services and ever higher interest rates.
That we support all efforts to give relief to people making house repayments, particularly in the first five years of purchase, but also when expenses are higher after the first years of marriage.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will give interest rate relief by way of tax concessions or a subsidy on mortgage repayments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the allowable amount of income to be earned by people receiving social security benefits has not been adjusted since 1972 and in the case of unemployed not since 1969.
That the $20 allowable for beneficiaries in 1972 was at a time when the benefit was $18.25 per week.
That if the same principle applied and if the amount earned had been indexed the amount now allowable would exceed $63.20 per week.
That family allowances have never been indexed.
That heartless, insensitive, frugal and anomalous social security benefits, allowances and rules are causing severe financial distress to many citizens and causing the breakup of families.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will bring all allowances and benefits up to levels which would make them equivalent in real monetary terms to the time when they were set.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers is a tax on knowledge, a tax on information and a tax on culture.
2. That freedom can be protected in a democratic society only if its citizens have access to information and ideas through books, magazines and newspapers.

3. That it is in early life that a taste for books and the habit of reading in the home are most easily acquired. The ability of families to provide the stimulus which books offer will be limited by the higher cost imposed by the tax.
4. That the development of the Australian publishing industry is based on a vigorous consumer demand. Such a tax can inhibit the industry and create unemployment among its workers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will reconsider the proposed tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medibank
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce Medibank.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling for such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich.

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(2) The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
(3) The Government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

1. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''non-institutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from, or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a ''disability'' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Housing and Construction
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia and building, construction and maintenance artisans employed by the Department of Housing and Construction respectfully showeth:

That the dramatic decisions, to dismantle efficient and viable depots and to replace loyal long serving workers with workers employed by private enterprise, be reversed. In the interests of our national security, government employees, who have been security checked should be the people to work on and within Defence and other government establishments. The trust and reliance placed on us, should not be cheaply disregarded.
Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that the harsh decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions Committee, be reversed and that common sense will prevail.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of parents and citizens associations respectfully showeth:

That retention of the schools commission and the curriculum development centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community:

That serious concern has been generated by the decision within the schools commission guidelines, to cut funds to the general recurrent and capital programs by reallocation to transition, the decision not to implement the school improvement program; and the divisiveness created between government and non-government schools due to the increase of $43.25 million to non-government schools while government school funds have not increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the government will reverse these decisions-will retain the schools commission and curriculum development centre in their original forms; retain the schools commission proposals including recurrent and capital funding proposals; basket of services and the schools improvement program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron and Mr Cross.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Henty P.B.R. Division of Repco respectfully showeth that:
1. The automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. If imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Burke respectfully showeth that:
1. the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners resident in the Tasmanian North-West Coast and West Coast municipalities of Circular Head, Wynyard, Burnie, Penguin, Waratah, Zeehan, Strahan, Queenstown and Gormanston are desirous of retaining first class air service through the major airport serving the area, namely the Wynyard airport.

Since the Government has agreed to provide $5.5 million for Devonport which serves a smaller population and area, we ask the Government as a matter of urgency to also provide sufficient funds to upgrade Wynyard airport to the standard required for it to accommodate medium size jet aircraft.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give urgent consideration to this request.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ingle Farm Community Kindergarten
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Parents of children attending the Ingle Farm Community Kindergarten Inc. showeth that:
(a) the recent allocation of funds for operating costs in kindergartens is grossly inadequate
(b) resulting higher kindergarten fees add to the already heavy financial burden on young South Australian families
(c) these higher fees will make attendance at a kindergarten less accessible to the general community
(d) standards of care and facilities previously enjoyed in South Australian kindergartens will inevitably fall as a result of the above.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will immediately move to rectify this matter and restore funds as they were previously committed, for operating costs of this Kindergarten, including the provision of extra funds to counter the effects of annual inflation upon the funding allocation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ballarat respectfully showeth:
1. That the proposed imposition of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax to building materials will have a disastrous effect on the already seriously depressed industry.

2. That the latest interest rate rise of 1 per cent to home mortgages will now end the hopes of many intending first home buyers. We believe the Federal Government must initiate a scheme of assistance to first home buyers, as proposed by building industry representatives.
In conclusion we reject the Federal Government's lack of genuine interest in the home industry. We also clearly state that the effects of points 1 and 2 above are not acceptable to us.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government give immediate attention to an already seriously depressed industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. PROCTEXT.PARA: Mrs Darling proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Primary Industry--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I rule that the question must be put on notice.

—I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industry. Can the Minister advise whether steps will be taken to overcome this shortage?

—I can understand the honourable member's concern over a shortage of meat inspectors at a time when the lamb season is about to open in Western Australia. The fact is that the lamb season has been caught up in a number of events which have caused a shortage of inspectors at several spots around Australia at the moment. With the close-down of a number of abattoirs because of a shortage of cattle, the Bureau of Animal Health did not continue its recruiting campaign and allowed the numbers to run down following retirements and resignations. In addition, the meat substitution problem in Melbourne caused the need for a number of inspectors to be transferred there to carry out the new procedures. The Katanning problem, I am pleased to be able to inform the honourable member, has been overcome by the availability all of a sudden of a number of inspectors from Wagga Wagga, which is closing down its works in a few days' time. Those inspectors will be transferred to Katanning and, therefore, I hope that the problem of Katanning will be resolved. I wish the Katanning operators all the best for a good lamb season.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, is prefaced by my indicating that I have exchanged correspondence with the Minister on uranium enrichment. I quote an extract from the correspondence:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government regards the possible establishment of an enrichment industry in Australia as a commercial matter, to be determined by the companies concerned. Similarly, the negotiation of contracts for the supply of enriched uranium or enrichment services would be a commercial matter.

Does the Minister acknowledge that the decisions on whether uranium enrichment is to be conducted in Australia, what technology is to be used and the terms on which such technology is to be transferred to Australia involve fundamental questions of nuclear proliferation? Why then has the Government handed over these decisions to the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia, which is a consortium of private companies, which means that such decisions to set up this important industry are therefore to be based entirely on commercial criteria? Why has the Government abdicated its responsibilities for policies in this highly sensitive area to commercial interests and to the exclusion of the States? Why has it sold out any public interest in this potentially valuable industry? Will this Government take immediate steps to reassess this scandalous policy initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —A commercial group, the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia-this is a number of leading Australian companies-is doing an evaluation of the possibility of setting up an enrichment plant in Australia. It is the Government's aim that, if there is to be an enrichment plant in Australia, it be privately funded and operated so that it will be based on a sound commercial proposition. However, I want to clarify the situation. The type of technology that the group selects will have to be approved by the Government. Also, any sales that it makes of enriched uranium will have to be approved by the Government to ensure that they meet our international safeguard requirements. There will be no neglect as far as our international responsibilities are concerned and there will be no weakening of our position, in order to ensure that the proliferation rules laid down by international organisations are fully upheld.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Has the Minister seen reports that the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport may soon be lifted for the new wide-bodied aircraft? Did the Minister say on 5 June that he was conscious of the noise sensitivity of the communities around Australian airports and that he would take the views of those communities into account? Has the Minister taken the views of the communities around Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport into account and is a decision on the curfew imminent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I must say that the headlines that appeared in the Sydney Sun yesterday were misleading and sensational and were clearly designed to sell the edition. The Government has not made any decision to vary the curfew in any shape or form. I have issued statements about the matter and I adhere to them. The Government's position is thus: There will not be any easing of the curfew applying to airports until there has been a proper evaluation of the noise levels of the Airbus 300 and until adequate discussions have been held with local community groups and the aircraft noise abatement committees at those airports. I have made that point very clear.

ANSWER.PARA: The report may have arisen from the results of tests that have been taken and which indicate that the Airbus 300 is far and away the least noisy jet aircraft being operated by airlines in Australia at present. In fact, it is only a fraction noisier than the propeller driven F27. Undoubtedly, it is a less noisy neighbour than any other jet aircraft flying in the sky today. The Government has not moved from its position. It intends to continue to monitor the situation and to assist local communities to monitor the noise level around airports to ascertain whether it would be increased by allowing the Airbus 300 to operate in curfew hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to published remarks by President Reagan of the United States that he envisages the possibility of limited nuclear war in Europe without involving the super-powers? Does the Government support this view? If so, will the Prime Minister explain how his Government justifies such an attitude? If not, will the Government make its views known to Washington?

—I am sure the honourable gentleman has some understanding of the concepts on which the defence of Western Europe is based. Quite plainly, the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers need to be able to match the Warsaw Pact states in terms of overall armaments. It is a sad fact of life that, in terms of the numbers of divisions, numbers of tanks, numbers of guns, numbers of aircraft, numbers of armoured personnel carriers of a very sophisticated kind that have been designed so that soldiers can fight from within the carrier and have a good deal of protection from different kinds of warfare, the Warsaw Pact countries are basically and substantially ahead of the NATO powers. For a long while that has meant that the basic defence of Western Europe rests either upon the nuclear deterrent or upon the willingness of Western European parties within NATO to use tactical nuclear weapons. If it rested on conventional weapons alone, it is probable that Western Europe could not be defended for more than a few days.
—So you can see a limited nuclear exchange?
—I do not see war in Europe.
—But can you see a limited nuclear exchange?

—The honourable gentleman asked a question. I think it is fair enough for this House to have the realities of the European position very much in mind in understanding the circumstances of Western European defence, circumstances which I am sure the governments of Western Europe have known and understood for very many years. If Western European nations wished to rely for their defence on conventional weapons alone they would have to expand enormously the number of divisions, tanks, aircraft and guns. Quite plainly--
—But could there be a limited nuclear exchange?
—Answer the question.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question. I ask him to remain silent while the right honourable gentleman answers. I indicate to the House that which I have indicated many times. Under the Standing Orders an honourable member is entitled to ask a question, but the same honourable member is not entitled to demand an answer in a specific way. Therefore, I ask all honourable members to remain silent while the answer is given.

—If the honourable gentleman is interested in the terms and nature of European defence and the broad philosophy on which it is based, he will find my answer relevant. I might also add that I believe that leaders of all countries readily understand the horror of nuclear war and would not want nuclear war visited on their own people. It is for those reasons that I basically believe that nuclear war will not occur. What has happened over the years--
—Can there be a limited exchange? Answer the damn question.
—The Leader of the Opposition should remain silent.
—Mr Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition persists in wanting to interject, not even with any degree of common courtesy. I have no particular wish to add to the answer I have already given.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR SERVICES TO AND FROM CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware of the problems and inconvenience caused by the cancellation, often at short notice, of scheduled air services to and from Canberra? What action can he take to ensure that when an air service is advertised it is in fact available to the travelling public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the cancellations of services from the published timetables of both Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia over the Canberra-Sydney and Canberra-Melbourne routes and other routes throughout Australia. I have had numerous representations and complaints from travellers and from honourable members on both sides of this House about the way in which the two major domestic airlines are treating the travelling public at this time. As a consequence, earlier this week I sent to the principals of both TAA and Ansett the following message:

ANSWER.PARA: I have received an increasing number of representations objecting to cancellations of scheduled services between Melbourne and Canberra and Sydney and Canberra.

The most frequent complaint is that actual services flown do not correspond with published timetables and that cancellations are being made at short notice. Often with both airlines cancelling flights at the same time slots.

I understand that your proposed timetables for operation commencing 25 October provide for reduced services. I would expect that the services envisaged and the new timetable will be operated and not subjected to substantial cancellation, particularly at short notice, thus creating considerable public inconvenience.
I believe it is essential that the airlines have regard for the convenience of the travelling public.
Unexpected cancellations of scheduled flights are playing havoc with planned travel arrangements.
This practice is quite unacceptable to travellers and the Government.
I might say, as one who has been a victim of the circumstance, that I object to it along with the rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Defence. It follows hot on the heels of the question which I asked the Prime Minister as to whether he supported or disagreed with the view of President Reagan that it was possible for a limited nuclear war to occur in Europe without involving the super-powers. The Minister will recall that the Prime Minister equivocated in his answer. Therefore, I ask the Minister--
—The honourable gentleman is not entitled to make a statement of that kind in asking his question. I ask the honourable gentleman to go on with the question.

—I ask the Minister for Defence: Does he recall his remarks in this House on 5 May this year in which he said that he doubted very much if there could be such a thing as a limited nuclear war? Does the Minister still hold that view? Is it a personal view or, at the time when he made the remark, was it the considered view of the Government and its senior military advisers? If so, has there been any change in the Government's view since May? If there has been a change in the Government's attitude, on what grounds or because of what advice did the change take place?

—I am flattered no end that the honourable gentleman recalls the speech that I made. I wish to remind him of the circumstances under which I made those observations. He will recall that I drew the attention of the House to a very considered speech given by the former United States Secretary for Defense, Mr Brown, in which he discussed precisely this position. Mr Brown asserted that he took the view, as a philosophic attitude, that the prospects of a limited nuclear war were very remote but, very properly, he did not cancel out the probability that one could occur. As a consequence of that Mr Brown stated that it was incumbent upon civilised mankind to consider both positions. For my part-I have never disguised this either in the House or in the country-I regard this as plainly the most outstanding consideration that faces the world and that every effort must be directed towards ensuring that mankind is spared the horror of a war.
—So you don't support limited war?

—No, I have not changed my position one iota. I understand it was in this context that President Reagan made his remarks. I only hope that the honourable gentleman will acknowledge that this is a desperately serious consideration.
—I have it here. You are trying to cover up for your Prime Minister. He cannot make up his mind. You know that you have some moral concern but he does not.

—I only hope that the honourable gentleman will be persuaded to accept the view that we will never find anybody stupid enough to find out whether the proposition that we can have a limited nuclear war is true by trying it out.
—Will the Minister for Trade and Resources advise the House of the prospects for Australian trade with the Middle East following the election of the new Egyptian leader Mr Mubarak?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Egypt is the largest single trading partner that Australia has in the Middle East. Last year we exported over $400m worth of products to that country. This growing trade has been due largely to the policies of the late President Sadat after he managed to bring about peace with Israel in 1973. The opening of the Suez Canal has brought Egypt in considerable revenue. There has been exploration for oil and oil is now being exported from Egypt. Manufacturing industry has increased considerably and Egypt is exporting many products. Indeed, two million to three million Egyptians working around the Middle East are now repatriating funds to Egypt. So its external financial position is strong and it is expanding its trade.

ANSWER.PARA: It is terribly important to recognise that the key to the stability of Egypt is a continuation of those policies laid down by President Sadat. Indeed, I believe a stable Egypt is very important to the whole of our trade with the Middle East region. Should there be a threat to the political or economic stability of Egypt, then I believe the whole area could be jeopardised. It is important for a person like the new President, President Mubarak, to continue, and be able to demonstrate his ability to do so, to follow through with the policies that were laid down by President Sadat-not only his economic policies but also his peace accord with Israel. Should there be any uncertainty in Egypt not only would trade be jeopardised but there would be a real possibility of a threat to the whole peace of the region. It is in the interests of Australia and the whole world that Egypt's stability be maintained. We wish President Mubarak all the best in the enormous job that he has of progressing his people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry, follows a question asked by the member for O'Connor. Is it a fact that the Metro Meat Company Ltd has been forced to close its abattoirs at Geraldton in order to transfer meat inspectors to Katanning? Is it a fact that this has cost the loss of over 100 jobs in Geraldton, which is already a depressed area? Will the Minister move to obtain the services of State meat inspectors to fill any shortfall in the availability of inspectors for abattoirs? Will he give an undertaking that the transfer of meat inspectors from the abattoirs now closing in the north-west of Western Australia will be sufficient to meet the requirements of Katanning, therefore making it possible to keep the abattoir at Geraldton open?
—I have a sneaking suspicion that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie did not listen to the answer I gave to the question asked earlier.
—I did. I listened very carefully.

—Had the honourable member listened carefully he would have heard me say that meat inspectors are to be transferred from Wagga Wagga to take up the positions at Katanning so that the Katanning lamb chain can operate. Therefore, there is not a requirement to transfer meat inspectors from Geraldton to Katanning, as was suggested in the honourable member's question. If the proprietors of the Geraldton meatworks close down their meatworks it is not because of any requirement for meat inspectors at Katanning. I heard on the grapevine yesterday that there was some suggestion of that. The fact is that if the proprietors of Geraldton close their works they close it for their own commercial reasons.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. It concerns reports of a slowdown in the growth of employment in Australia. According to the information available to the Minister's Department, has the growth in employment in Australia slowed down in recent months? What has caused this slowdown if there is one? Are there any grounds for confidence that we may see a renewal of growth in the near future?

—The Government has always maintained that Australia can hope to see substantial and steady increases in employment only by the adoption of economic policies which encourage industry and commerce to invest in those areas which generate large numbers of job opportunities. Indeed, there is a great deal of evidence to suggest that those policies are working. Just how successful those policies have been can be seen from the current employment figures. The Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force statistics, released today, show that employment has grown in Australia by some 140,800, or 2.2 per cent, over the 12 months to September 1981. That is a very good performance indeed. It is so good that in the month of September alone, total employment grew by 109,800. That increase occurred in one month. It is a very good increase indeed. I suppose that I can best illustrate on that evidence just what a successful performance it is by saying to the House that during the 12 months from August 1980 to August 1981 the net increase in total employment was 109,600, whereas in the month of September alone we saw a growth of 109,800 jobs. Of those 109,800 jobs, 100,000 are full time jobs and some 9,000 are part time jobs. So the year on year growth in employment has increased since August from 109,600 to 140,800. It is a creditable performance indeed.
—Still lower than the 1978 figures.

—The honourable member, who has a record of trying to pick the box, on this occasion seems to have gone a little wrong. If we look at the figures we find there was an increase of 15,000 in September 1978, an increase of 76,000 in September 1979, an increase of 78,000-odd in September 1980, and an increase of 109,800 in September 1981-last month. We have always maintained that one month's figures must be treated with caution, but the evidence shows-it is indeed very good evidence-that the economy has the strength to continue to generate large numbers of job opportunities within Australia.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I require the Minister, under Standing Order 321, to table the documents which he has used in answer to the question he just wrote.
—Was the Minister reading from a document?
—I was referring to notes but I am quite happy for the honourable member to have them. I will table them.

—Mr Speaker, I submit that the Standing Order refers to documents. I requested under Standing Order 321 that the documents-that is more than one piece of paper-to which he was referring and from which he was quoting in the course of answering his own question be tabled. I am referring to all of the documents, not the notepaper on top.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document?
—In the first place I was not quoting from a document. Secondly, I was referring to some handwritten notes of my own, but I will table them.

—If the honourable gentleman was not quoting from a document there is no requirement under Standing Orders that he table a document. However, the Minister can at any time table a document if he wishes to do so.
—I table the document.

—Has the Treasurer seen a report on semi-government authorities' loan raising and pricing policies by the Sydney stockbroking firm Dominguez and Barry reported in the Australian on 14 October? Are the report's conclusions that State authorities, especially electricity authorities, will be forced to find half their funds for expansion programs from internal sources a direct result of Federal Government restrictions on raising loan funds? Will adoption of these user pays principles lead to a further 50 per cent increase in electricity prices this year for consumers in eastern States, as the report suggests? Are these Federal Government fiscal policies threatening the viability of new power station projects to service new resource projects effectively ending, as the report suggests, the era of cheap electricity for domestic consumers of power?

—I have not seen the particular report from Dominguez and Barry to which the honourable member referred, but I do not mind making a response to the general point raised by the honourable member. It is true that the extent that public sector utilities are prevented from replacing internally generated revenue from increased charges by larger borrowings has an impact on their charging policies. The point that has to be made is that the approach the Federal Government took at successive Loan Council meetings this year was designed to reduce the overall demand for funds in Australia from all forms of public authorities. We make no apology for having done that. It was done because we believed there was an overall requirement to ease pressure on interest rates and, to the extent that it was necessary for State utilities and semi-government utilities to carry their share of the burden of reduced loan raisings, that was only fair and proper. I remind the honourable gentleman that the Commonwealth Government made a massive contribution to that particular exercise by the reduction in its own Budget deficit and the restraint that it imposed on its own semi-government borrowing authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the honourable gentleman's question very much indeed. The House would be aware that the company's decision to defer the Point Wilson project was based, of course, on a number of factors, including increasing costs in the construction stage of the project as well as the operational stage. As the honourable gentleman has made clear, the company has--

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. This matter is listed today for discussion as a matter of public importance. If the Minister wants to expatiate on the topic he could respond to the matter of public importance.

—A similar situation arises in relation to the point of order as arose in relation to an earlier point of order taken by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. It is not anticipating a debate because until the letter is reported to the House it is not before the House. The 'blue' is for the information of members. The right honourable gentleman is entitled to continue his answer.
—As I was indicating--
—Mr Speaker, I just make the point that there is no chance of getting the same sort of decency from this Minister as we had from the Treasurer.
—I call the Minister for Industry and Commerce.
—As I was indicating to the House--
—Have a look at today's Australian Financial Review.

—And as the honourable gentleman who is waving a piece of paper ought to well understand, the company has indicated that it costs 20 per cent more to build a plant in this country than it does in the United States or Europe. Therein, of course, lies the tragedy of the manufacturing sector at present, because at a point where manufacturing certainly is entering a new growth phase the pressures for hours reduction and wages increase and a continuing high level of industrial unrest are very markedly souring the present picture.

ANSWER.PARA: What is at stake with this project and many others like it throughout Australia is the capacity of this country to maintain its competitive edge. That is why this Government has brought down successively responsible Budgets. That is why we have sought to contain the excessive increase in wage costs. That is why we have opposed the union campaign for a marked reduction in working hours. The environment for industry growth is being restored at present. The figures certainly bear that out. I am indebted to the honourable gentleman for making clear in this House the very significant burdens Australian manufacturing industry is carrying at present because of high wage costs, those costs associated with a reduction in working hours, and the very high level of industrial unrest.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate presses its requests for amendments to the Bills.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to the constitutional question this Message involves. The Message purports to repeat the requests for amendments contained in Message No. 160, which the House rejected on 14 October. The right of the Senate to repeat and thereby press or insist on a request for an amendment has never been accepted by the House of Representatives.

INTERJECT.PARA: On several previous occasions when a request was pressed on the House by repetition the House had regard to the claim that the public welfare required passage of the legislation which was the subject of the pressed request and gave the pressed request the House's consideration notwithstanding that the House resolved to refrain from determining its constitutional rights. The House so informed the Senate of the terms of its resolution in its Message to the Senate in reply. It is not certain whether the Senate's right to press a request by repetition is justiciable in the courts. However, it is a matter of constitutional propriety as between the Houses based on the provisions of sections 53 to 57 of the Constitution. Strong arguments that the Constitution does not give the Senate the right to press a request were advanced by Quick and Garran, who were intimately involved in the development of the Constitution. Their views may be found on pages 671-2 of their classic analysis of the Constitution.

In 1943, some 40 years later, the question was examined by four eminent constitutional lawyers, Garran, Knowles, Bailey and Castieau, who, after considering other learned opinion, summed up the question in the following words:

In our opinion, the Constitution in denying the right of amendment and conferring the right of request intended a substantial difference. In this we respectfully agree with the views expressed by Sir Harrison Moore, Sir Isaac Isaacs, and Sir John Latham. We think it clear that the Constitution did not intend to stultify itself by giving back in one clause what it had taken away in another. The essence of the difference between request and amendment is that in the case of a request the right of decision as to the form of the Bill rests solely with the House of Representatives. To press a request is to insist upon it-which is a contradiction in terms, and also in our opinion unconstitutional.

Other more recent legal opinion has been of a similar view, including that of Professor J. E. Richardson, Professor Geoffrey Sawer and Professor Dennis Pearce. I respectfully agree with these opinions. It rests with the House whether it will consider Message No. 185 insofar as it purports to press the requests that were contained in Message No. 160.

(1) That this House endorses the statement of Mr Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by Message No. 185 transmitted from the Senate in relation to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981;
(2) That this House declines to consider Message No. 185 insofar as it purports to press the requests that were contained in Message No. 160 from the Senate; and
(3) That the consideration of further action in relation to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981 be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
Mr Holding-Mr Speaker, will you be so kind as to furnish honourable members with a copy of the legal opinions which formed the basis of your opinion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have referred to opinions of Professor Richardson, Professor Sawer and Professor Dennis Pearce. I have seen the relevant parts. They are not opinions in the strict sense of a commissioned opinion; they are public statements made by those gentlemen dealing with the issue. I will give the honourable gentleman references to where they may be found.

That means that in three or four years time, if the same thing happens, people will look back and say: 'The House of Representatives in October 1981 merely endorsed what the Speaker had to say'.

This measure has never been tested in relation to the rights of the Senate. It has been a view of the House of Representatives, and a view of many of the constitutional lawyers of this country, that the Senate does not have that right. But it was the view of many constitutional lawyers and of most people who have served in the House of Representatives since Federation that what took place in 1975 could not take place. Previously the House of Representatives, according to your statement, has considered the public welfare message of the Senate.

What is the public welfare message? It has been outlined by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). The Treasurer (Mr Howard) presents a view that we are misrep- resenting what he is trying to do. How on earth could we misrepresent what the Government is trying to do? It is raising another $330m in a full year from increasing sales tax. It is as simple as that. It is as plain as black and white. The Australian taxpayers will have to pay $330m in a full year as from January next year that they did not have to pay before the Budget was introduced in August this year. No one can misrepresent that. That is what the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the Independent senator, Senator Harradine, are being asked to vote on.

Of course, I agree with the Leader of the Opposition entirely-the Senate could throw the whole legislation out and this Government would not go to an election. It would not dare go to an election on this issue. The Senate ought to throw it out. In consideration of what the Senate has asked us to do there ought now to be a full scale debate in this House again on the ramifications of the sales tax. Many more people in Australia now understand the burden that will be carried by the people of Australia once these sales taxes start applying. It might be all right for the Democrats to pick out three or four things that they think might be popular but once these taxes start being applied on a multiplicity of goods the living standards of Australian people will be affected. It will not be just the sales tax; it will be the sales tax on top of a 22 per cent increase in pay-as-you-earn taxes that will be paid by wage and salary earners in this country.

We ought to do what the House of Representatives has done in the past-there ought to be a discussion on this matter. It is not a question of recognising the number of times on which the message may come back. I do not believe it is in the best interests of the Parliament or of the Constitution and specifically the best interests of the House of Representatives merely and glibly to fall into line especially when there is a bloke like the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) in the Government. TALK.START.PARA: —They have been good enough to toss you out on a couple of occasions.

—The Minister had better start wearing gloves. He will be caught with his fingerprints one of these days. This is all that the Senate is asking us to do. Labor Party representatives in the Parliament are always expected to say: 'We will abide by what is right, by what the Constitution appears to say'. We on this side of the House are justifiably entitled to have some very deep suspicions about the way in which this Government is trying to manipulate and interpret for its own benefits what the Constitution has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: We all knew what happened in 1975-it should never have been allowed to happen-would be repeated, that once again the Australian people would be looking in the near future at the sort of political turmoil that they lived through in 1975. This will happen because the Government has demonstrated the way in which the Senate may be used. There were many constitutional views and opinions that the Senate could never do what it did in 1975. But we did not hear the conservatives in the House of Representatives in 1975 saying to the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the then Leader of the Opposition: 'Let us not proceed. How would it be if every government in the House of Representatives for the next 100 years were to face a hostile Senate on the constitutional interpretation given to it by the conservatives of 1975? There is a precedent for this case. The precedent is outlined in the second paragraph of the explanation given by the Speaker. We should discuss the ramifications for public welfare contained in the message. What are the ramifications contained specifically in the message? All the Australian families who have children going to school will have to pay more to clothe them in 1982 not just as a result of the increased costs of clothing and labour but as a result of the increase in sales tax which has been imposed by this Government right across the board-on books, building materials, school clothing and shoes. The Government has not missed anything that affects the average wage and salary earner in this country. That is why the House of Representatives ought to put aside time to discuss these matters. That is why the Democrats should understand more clearly the debate on the sales tax. That is why, instead of playing around with it and sending messages to the House of Representatives, they ought to do what they originally intended to do and that is to vote with the Labor Party and with Senator Harradine to throw the whole thing out.
