INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's inept policies which have resulted, inter alia, in ICI shelving its $500m Geelong petrochemical complex investment.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement by ICI Australia Ltd yesterday that it is not going ahead with its $500m Geelong investment is a tragedy not only for that region and for Victoria but also for the whole of this country. But from a reading of this morning's newspapers it is not the only bad news that we have to withstand. All who are dedicated to creating new jobs, as we in the Australian Labor Party are, will feel the tragic and disastrous effects of the announcements in today's newspapers. They are almost as bad, if not as bad, as the announcement by ICI. In these newspapers today we read that plans for a $100m titanium processing plant appear certain to be shelved. Further, there are likely to be revisions of the Altona petrochemical company's expansion plans. Hundreds of millions of dollars of investment will be lost because the ICI plant at Point Wilson was going to be a potential customer of Altona. It is well known that the Alcoa Portland investment is under grave threat. The list of closures of enterprises and failures of possibilities to materialise is a tragically long one. I do not have the time to give more detail on this today because my task must be to highlight the root causes of these grave disappointments and to seek by persuasion to bring about changes which will prevent recurrences of these losses of investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minster for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) in Question Time today may have said that I am not one of his main advisors. Of course, I am ever hopeful that he will come to his senses and accept the sort of advice that we on this side of the House are putting to him. While he and the Government pursue the present economic policies we will have more closures, further lack of investment and more announcements such as that made by ICI yesterday. I need go, as I said, no further than the list that I have given to show that this is so.

I want now to move on to the root causes of these problems. Firstly, inflation is raging in Australia right now due to the inept policies of the Fraser Government. We are becoming less competitive at a time when, to create the 2 1/2 million new jobs we need in this decade, in the 1980s, we have to become more competitive. I will return to that point a little later. Secondly, there has been the appreciation-the upvaluation-of the Australian dollar. It has risen by 12 per cent since 1979 and 8 per cent in the last 12 months. This is making worse our lack of competitiveness. This would not be happening if our national Government were properly controlling capital inflows into this country at the present time. These root causes of the problems, incidentally, have been given by ICI in its statement. The third root cause is that there are grave uncertainties emanating from this Government right now which are, indeed, leading to the killing off of manufacturing industry today and eliminating all those service industries and service jobs in the tertiary sector which are tied to manufacturing.

Let me deal with these points in a little more detail. The first point I want to deal with is the disastrous return to double digit inflation. According to the Budget Papers, our inflation rate is likely to be 10.75 per cent this financial year compared with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 9.5 per cent. I am glad to see that the Minister for Industry and Commerce is going to take part in this debate today after all. I welcome him to this chamber and to this debate. It is the first time that we have managed to entice him in here for, I think, years. It is no good his seeking, as he did in Question Time today, to lay the blame for these problems on the workers of this country. Total economic mismanagement of this country by him and his partners in this venture called the national Government has caused the increase in inflation. If he wants more co-operation from workers in relation to the 35-hour week or, indeed, in relation to wage restraint he ought to give to the workers of this country a total economic package which is acceptable to them. This prospect of increasing inflation destroys any remaining vestige of credibility that the 'fight inflation first' strategy that he has been pursuing ever had.

Yet it seems the Government wants merely to repeat a dose of this philosophy in its sixth year of office. That is what it is doing in this Budget that we are still debating in this Parliament. To fight inflation first, under this Government, means to fight inflation forever, using the same tactics of keeping a lid on the economy, which tactics, of course, are leading to such announcements as we heard yesterday from ICI. ICI, Geelong and the rest of us are the sufferers from the renewed lid on the economy, the stringent monetary and budgetary policies which are being pursued. The tragedy of this approach is that it has effectiveness only when there is no significant growth in the economy. Indeed it essentially controls inflation by putting a halt to growth. The Government has no anti-inflation policy for a growth economy and so, having reached only 2.9 per cent real growth as it did in the last financial year, it has had to slam on the brakes with razor gang cuts, reduced Loan Council programs, higher sales and income taxes-in the previous debate we were discussing the sales tax aspects-and the Government's very tight monetary policies. Is there any denying that these are some of the root causes of the high costs, incompetent management and the uncompetitiveness which ICI referred to in its statement when it announced tragically that it will not go ahead with that investment at least for some time. It is against this background that necessary developments and industry policies must be assessed. My Labor colleagues and I believe that we should be moving in the opposite policy direction to that now being taken by this Fraser Government. Instead of yet another bout of restrictive macro-economic policy we must have a renewed emphasis on longer term industry policies, fight inflation directly by reducing taxes and charges, strike a bargain with the trade union movement and promote a broad base of growth in our economy.

What are the major elements of this alternative strategy? I will go though them quickly. Firstly, we must have some means for containing inflationary pressures under conditions of economic growth. This means that we must have a policy for prices and incomes which should be mutually agreed to by the major sectors of the community. It is this policy which the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Labor Party have been jointly pursuing in recent months. It aims to find social consensus where there is now only contest and to limit claims on the economic system to a non-inflationary level.

This is a positive approach to these problems of increasing costs in our community instead of the rhetoric of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, as displayed in Question Time today. This approach to industrial relations, to prices and to general economic policy must be underpinned by a further policy change towards the introduction of a degree of indicative economic planning. I am sorry that I do not have time in this debate to go into that matter in more detail. But if we had this approach, this closer partnership between government and a company such as ICI, if we had this prices and incomes policy, if we had the indicative planning approach, we would not have had the announcement such as we had yesterday from ICI.

I refer now to our currency upvaluing. The Government has reduced the competitiveness of Australian manufacturing industry by allowing the vast capital inflow of the past 12 months to cause an appreciation of the exchange value of the Australian dollar. This, of course, has made imports cheaper and our exports less competitive. That is another reason why ICI has not been able to go along with this investment. Indeed the upvaluation of the dollar has been equivalent in price effect terms to a fall of about 40 per cent in effective levels of tariff assistance for most of our import competing industries. By allowing the capital inflow of over $6,000m to have this effect the Government has effectively caused the manufacturing sector to contract in response to the expansion of the resources sector. The ICI announcement is just another example of this contraction in the manufacturing sector.

Capital inflow is, of course, related to the investment phase of the minerals and energy development. But that investment phase is not the only cause of it. There is far too much speculative capital coming into this country, far too much for portfolio investment which does not create jobs in the community. The so-called Gregory thesis which implied that new export industries could displace established industries is proving correct, even at this early stage of the resource-based expansion. We have not had to wait for the increase in exports, which will not be significant until 1983. We are getting this effect because this Government is allowing this capital to flow into Australia unabated. The Labor Party believes that the appreciation of the dollar in these circumstances represents a gross mismanagement of the economy. This mismanagement is damaging our longer term growth prospects and ironically will ultimately mean that Australia will import less from the rest of the world than would otherwise be possible.

We need to cut tariffs in order to bring imports into this country for the export stage of our resource-based industry expansion, if only we had an expanding economy right now. That greater volume of imports would automatically be coming into this country without any cuts in tariffs, with all the dangers there are in those for manufacturing industry. Not only are ICI and Geelong suffering from this policy but also so is our reputation as a trading nation. The same criticisms could be validly applied to any attempts to effect an across the board reduction in levels of tariff or quota protection. That uncertainty is the third reason given by ICI for its decision. Such a decision is very clearly threatened by the Fraser Government following its reference to the Industries Assistance Commission on ways of reducing general levels of protection for Australian industry.

It is all very well for the Minister to talk glibly as he did yesterday to the National Farmers' Federation about offsetting some of these future tariff cuts with accelerated depreciation. We want the accelerated depreciation to help industry now. Manufacturing industry is suffering right now. New investment is not taking place right now because of the lack of adequate industry policies on the part of this Government. As the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment recommended, such general measures as reducing tariffs are not desirable in circumstances of high unemployment. Our unemployment rate is presently 5.8 per cent and rising. Tariff reductions can only increase this level as alternative job opportunities do not exist.

This particularly applies to the regions and skilled categories in which our manufacturing sector is presently concentrated. I refer, of course, to Geelong among such regions. I could refer to Adelaide, Albury-Wodonga, Melbourne or many other regions which are heavily dependent on our manufacturing industries. There is little point in restructuring the work force out of some of these industries because they are said to be inefficient when that restructuring would merely mean that people will be restructured into unemployment. Such change rightly creates a strong reaction which will result ultimately in reduced import levels. Thus a decision which superficially may appear to benefit an expansion of trade could in fact lead to a contraction of trade in the longer term.

The free trade theorists in Treasury and in the Liberal Party ranks who seem to be having such an influence at present do not appreciate the point I have just made. They seem unable to raise their analysis above the level of simple economic theory to take into account the social and political factors, particularly those relating to the longer term. What is the point of deterring investment in the new jobs in Geelong, other parts of Victoria and everywhere else investment may be contemplated when there is such high unemployment at present? A far more productive approach, indeed the one advocated by the Labor Party, would be to establish mechanisms in Australia to enable a higher overall growth rate to be pursued without an increase in the level of inflation. I have given an indication of how this can be done. The present Government has no such mechanisms. It is presently retreating as fast as it can from even the miserable 2.9 per cent growth rate that we had in the last financial year because even this modest growth is accommodating a renewal of inflationary pressures under the sort of policies it has. Restriction and recession are the Government's only weapons against inflation and the only weapons it is using at the moment against this industry generally. It is no wonder that I repeat that I believe the Government's policies are totally inept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that the Australian Labor Party has raised this matter today. It is the party that brought resource exploration and investment to a halt through takeovers and threats of expropriation. It is the party that destroyed domestic and overseas confidence in the resource industry. It is the party that allowed industrial strife to reach new heights, with over six million working days lost in 1974 alone. In office, the Australian Labor Party abolished the investment allowance, drastically curtailed the export incentive scheme, saw the near cessation of mining and oil ventures in Australia, slashed tariffs by 25 per cent overnight and in one year alone caused the loss of some 123,800 jobs in manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The litany of Labor's demonstrated inability to manage the Australian economy goes on and on. Its current industry platform demonstrates that it has learnt nothing since 1975. Under a Labor government, Australian industry could expect the termination of the investment allowance, an expansion of the functions of the Foreign Investment Review Board to monitor transnational corporations in Australia, a restriction of overseas investment, the introduction of a resource rent tax and an excess profits tax, the monitoring of technological change, the exemption of unions from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act, support in principle for the introduction of the 35-hour week, the supervision and monitoring of international resource negotiations between mining companies in Australia and overseas buyers and, of course, a commitment to a much larger public sector.

In complete contrast to this, and as a result of the very policies which this matter of public importance proposed by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) seeks to attack, $35 billion worth of major manufacturing and mining projects are either committed or at the final feasibility stage. The revival of business confidence has been brought about by our policies designed to assist and encourage industry growth. In 1981-82 $524m will be outlaid in direct industry assistance and development. This compares with $181m in the 1975 Hayden Budget. Manufacturing industry has now recovered from its setbacks of the mid-1970s and has embarked on a new growth phase. Factory output, having fallen after 1974, has now improved and surpassed its previous peak. In real terms, manufacturers' sales were up 3.4 per cent in the year. Over the past year manufacturing industry has demonstrated its confidence in Australia and in the policies of this Government by increasing by 44 per cent the value of its investment. Yet the honourable member for Adelaide in this House today had the hide to claim that no more investment is taking place.

The ICI Australia Ltd Point Wilson project was only one of some 366 projects that are now in the offing, yet the Opposition has worked itself into a frenzy over the shelving of that project. It has taken the suspension of that project out of perspective. As with any such project, the viability of Point Wilson turned on its competitive prospects. I have been assured by the Chairman of ICI that government policy for the manufacturing sector was the least of that company's considerations in postponing the project. The reasons for the postponement are far more fundamental than those offered by the Opposition. They concern the capacity of Australian industry to maintain its competitive edge. That is no more quickly destroyed than by unreasonable wage demands, the implementation of a 35-hour week and industrial unrest. On these fundamental issues the Opposition has remained silent or become the spokesman for some sections of the union movement, at the same time jettisoning any sense of responsibility to the Australian people or those employed in the work force. It has jettisoned any responsibility for creating an environment that seeks to sustain the competitive edge of industry in this country. The Opposition demonstrates a total lack of understanding of the Australian industrial scene, blinkered as it is by narrow sectional interests.

This Government is firmly committed to the development of a stronger, more viable and internationally competitive manufacturing sector in the interests of the nation as a whole. We are convinced that the best service government can provide to industry is to set the precondition for sustained economic growth and to minimise its demands on and intrusions into the private sector. The re-establishment of a sensible economic framework has therefore been a prime objective of this Government since our return to office in December 1975. Over this period we have ensured that policies for the manufacturing sector have been developed within the broader framework of policies aimed at restoring growth and stability in the economy as a whole. But we are not in the business of directing the activities of industry or underwriting the success of individual commercial ventures. These are matter for judgment and decision by those who stand to gain or lose in the market-place.

The Government has been very conscious of the need for a predictable policy framework against which industry can make its investment decisions. This has been a key feature of our approach and the record speaks for itself. As well as inheriting an economic shambles when we re- turned to office in 1975, we found an unco-ordinated and ad hoc attitude to industry development. It was this Government that formulated a comprehensive and soundly based approach to industry policy in the White Paper on manufacturing industry in May 1977 and this was reconfirmed in August 1979 in our response to the report of the study group on structural adjustment. Within this framework we have developed specific measures designed to encourage positively industry activities that are efficient, innovative, internationally competitive and more oriented to export markets.

I instance just a few of those measures. We have taken decisions to introduce improved depreciation rates for plant and equipment, to extend the application of the investment allowance, to increase government support for industry development and industrial research and development, and to increase support for Australia's small business community. We have acknowledged the role that reductions in protection can play in bringing about improvements in Australia's industry structure. Significant progress has been made in reducing the Australian tariff, at the same time having very careful regard to the capacity of this country to absorb social and economic change. Let there be no mistake: Sudden sharp cuts in assistance, ill-conceived and ill-considered, are not a feature of this Government's approach and we will not repeat the overnight across the board 25 per cent tariff cut of July 1973. That action contributed to a significant loss of business confidence and caused disruption and hardship for many firms and individuals as well as for particular regions. Gradualism and predictability are cornerstones of this Government's approach. There is no doubt that there is certainty about this Government's policy towards industry, certainty about our determination to bring inflation under control, certainty about our capacity to rein back the size of the public sector and certainty about our ability to eliminate Budget deficits.

Recent references to the Industries Assistance Commission on protection, export incentives and budgetary assistance for industry are no basis for uncertainty about the Government's industry policy. In fact, these references are designed to do the opposite. For example, the outstanding issue of protection will be settled sooner than would otherwise have been the case by the IAC's report being brought forward by 18 months. The reference on budgetary assistance to industry is designed to ensure that the forms of Government assistance are the most cost effective which can be provided. Existing levels of assistance-I emphasise that-will be maintained. They will be provided in what the IAC report and our consequent consideration of it show to be the most cost effective manner. I repeat that ICI's decision to defer the Point Wilson project should be kept in perspective, reflecting as it does conditions in the international chemical industry. The chairman of ICI, Mr Milton Bridgland, said yesterday that there was very little the Government could do to improve the economic attractiveness of the project in the short term. The fact is that the project was subject to a feasibility study which would necessarily examine the prospects of selling the corporation's output a number of years ahead. That study would be bound to be influenced by conditions in the world market and, in particular, by the major structural redevelopments taking place in the world petrochemical industry. This restructuring was sparked off by the oil price increases. It has been accelerated by the present depressed state of the world petrochemical market and the desire by some oil-producing countries to broaden their industrial base through the development of export-oriented petrochemical industries.

The highly regarded international publication on the chemical industry-I refer to Chemical Insight-recently reported that Saudi Arabia was about to commence the construction of major chemical plants which could produce, as well as other chemicals, about 1.6 million tonnes of ethylene, 335,000 tonnes of caustic soda, and some 810,000 tonnes of polyethylene. Saudi Arabia is not, of course, the only country planning extensive new petrochemical capacities based on cheap gas. It will not even be the largest producer because, by the end of 1980s, Canada and Mexico each may be producing up to 1.9 million tonnes of the ethylene compared to the 1.6 million tonnes produced by Saudi Arabia. ICI's decision reflects the specific circumstances of the chemicals industry. As I have said on a number of occasions, and I repeat it here, resource development projects are neither pre-ordained nor are they guaranteed. They will always be subject to ongoing assessment of market conditions, costs and other factors. ICI's announcement demonstrates the crucial importance of keeping wages and other costs under control so as to maintain the competitive edge of Australian industries.

If I could reflect on Question Time today, I think it is a matter of concern to all honourable members of this House to read the statement by ICI that the construction of its plant here would entail a 20 per cent cost disability over the construction of a plant in the United States or Europe. Surely that is the problem of the competitive edge we are fending off at present in Australia. Although individual projects may be deferred from time to time, there can be no doubt as to the overall strength of investment in industrial development.

I am confident that, in the final analysis, Australia will secure supplies of raw materials, and will offer opportunities for major developments in the chemical industry, such as the production of caustic soda for our large and expanding alumina industry. Australian manufacturing industry has now recovered from the setbacks it experienced in the mid-1970s and has embarked on a new growth phase. The environment for industry development is being restored, and this Government will not hesitate to take the necessary steps to reinforce that environment of a growing and competitive Australian manufacturing industry. The Government rejects the motion before the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) cannot so easily dismiss the arguments put by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). The shelving of the $500m chemical and petrochemical plant at Point Wilson by ICI Australia Ltd is certainly a matter of importance and worthy of discussion in this place. But the charge that it is as a result of this Government's policies is quite false. As the Minister said, it is ironic and, as I said the other day, it is rather hollow coming from that side of the House which, when last in government, presided over such a massive boost to inflation and costs. Under the Labor Government we saw the cutting of tariffs. In particular, I refer to the across the board tariff cut of July 1973. We saw a halving of the then prevailing export incentives, we saw the removal of the investment allowance; and, over most of the period, we saw a significant upvaluation in the Australian dollar. All of this led to a disastrous fall in the Australian manufacturing industry and the emergence of very high levels of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: In point of fact, the ICI project to which we are now referring has been shelved for some very important, powerful and fundamental reasons. As Ian Perkins, the Financial Editor of the Australian newspaper wrote today, it was always a razor's edge proposition. Its competitive prospect was marginal. As the Minister said, it was not included by the Department last June in the list of development projects in the committed or final feasibility stage. Such projects in Victoria totalled some $3.5 billion. In fact, as I said, the ICI project has been shelved for some very powerful reasons. The first reason, and the first mentioned by Mr Bridgland, the Managing Director of ICI, is the high and mounting cost structure in Australia. There is an alarming prospect for accelerating costs, associated with claims now being made for large wage increases in the wake of the abandonment of wage indexation, associated with the push to the 35-hour week and associated with the prospect of a national wage decision next February. I say in passing that if at the next wage hearing a significant general increase is proposed there must be a way of offsetting against it these increases now being won. If not, there will be the prospect of the abandonment of not only this rather marginal project, but other development projects in Australia which would have created widespread employment opportunities. It was envisaged that this project in its construction phase would provide in the order of 1,000 jobs and, thereafter, 200 jobs for management and production employees. In general it needs to be appreciated that it is such projects, albeit not of this marginal character but more soundly based projects, which provide the continuing thrust to economic growth and more jobs in the economy over the coming years. It is critical that the basic condition, the containment of increasing costs, be achieved. In that context I can only urge that those unionists in employment should have regard to the effect of excessive demands on the prospects for the employment of others.

There is the first cause of the shelving of this project. The second cause was the appreciation, the upvaluation, of the Australian dollar up to a month or so ago, a matter which I will come back to. Thirdly, there were undoubtedly increased financing costs because of the current higher interest rates as compared with those prevailing when the project was first mooted.

Finally, and doubtless most importantly, are the conditions of demand and capacity in the chemical industry not only in Australia but also world wide, in the international chemical industry. There is on the one hand the circumstance that capacity is being greatly expanded overseas, as the Minister set out, and creating circumstances in which there can be quite fierce import competition in other markets. At the same time the demand growth for polyvinyl chloride in particular-a principal output of the proposed plant-has significantly declined in this country. In the early 1970s demand growth was of the order of 18 per cent per annum. By 1975, following the increase in oil prices, it had fallen to the order of 12 per cent per annum. Following the further increase in oil prices in 1979 it has fallen to the order of 5 per cent per annum. In all these circumstances, as the Minister put it, the competitive prospects for the proposed plant were marginal indeed.

I return to the question of the exchange rate. There is no doubt that the order of appreciation of just short of 10 per cent over the past 12 months until a month or so ago is of great significance to an industry such as the chemical industry which is subject to significant import competition. It would be correct to say, as the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) said, that this could amount to an erosion of the order of 40 per cent of the nominal protection afforded the industry. The point I make in that connection is that the impact of this factor on export and import competing Australian industries has not escaped the Government's attention. The upvaluation of the Australian dollar was stopped and in the last month or so to some extent it has been reversed. Although it is not proper to speculate about the course of the exchange rate, perhaps one can say that it has now been stabilised.

I repeat that the Government has not been unmindful of the impact of this factor on the export and import competing goods sector but it was judged necessary to respond to the then favourable overall balance of payments situation and the requirements of anti-inflation policy with the upvaluation of the Australian dollar that has taken place until recently. The role of that upvaluation as a restraint on inflation is itself important for industry. As I said, the rate presently has stabilised. It is undoubtedly a factor which the Government will take into account in its response to the Industries Assistance Commission's report on the references that have been sent to it on possible approaches to lower protection and on budgetary assistance to industry.

I can only assert that this Government's policy for industry-a wide ranging one covering the general economic environment and hence the Government's overall economic policy, its specific measures of industry policy and its tariffs, subsidy and assistance structure-is one which, contrary to the charge levelled by the Opposition, has been supportive of industry and which has led to a significant expansion in output and production.

The Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill which I will introduce to the House shortly propose to amend the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act and the Television Licence Fees Act 1964 to vary the basis on which commercial broadcasting and television stations are charged for their use of a limited public resource. Honourable members will be aware that those Acts impose fees in the nature of a royalty charge, thus following the practice common to all governments of ensuring that the public gains some benefit from the commercial utilisation of public resources. The present Acts provide for a lump sum payment on the original grant of a licence and for a lump sum and a percentage of the gross earnings of the station in respect of each year after the grant. The Bills propose an increased fee of $500 on the grant of a licence and tying the annual fee simply to a revised percentage of gross earnings. That percentage varies in relation to increases in gross earnings, subject to specified upper limits.

Honourable members will be aware that Bills to give effect to those measures, which were announced in the Budget, have previously been considered by the House. The present Bills differ from the earlier ones only in imposing an upper limit on the proposed percentage of a station's gross earnings. The reason for their introduction is that while there will be no reduction in the amount of money received as a result of the Bills, there will be a variation in that henceforth the rate of escalation of contribution is to be limited. That limitation is to be applied because each of the stations enjoying a licence will contribute significantly more each year, according to their gross earnings which, of course, are predicted on the extent of the market on which they operate, up to a point where the acceleration in the amount paid rises to a very considerable percentage, and it is not felt justifiable that the fees should forever increase at that percentage rate. The proposed limits are: Five per cent of gross earnings in the case of broadcasting stations and 7.5 per cent of gross earnings in the case of television stations.

The Government has examined these measures in the light of representations from the broadcasting and television industry on the effect of the measures, not in the short term but in the long term. It is the long term effect of the measures and the fact that there would continue to be a very marked increase in the amount of fees required to be paid that the Government believes it appropriate that a maximum level be set which will not lead to any reduction in the amount budgeted for in this financial year but will lead to a continued ceiling which will ensure that, while the principles of the measure continue, the percentage required to be paid is not excessive.

Licence fees are calculated on the basis of gross earnings of stations. Of course, the gross earnings of stations relate very much to the area that the station serves and the area of the licence is a product of the licensing procedures. The area of the licence determines the size of the market and, to a large degree, the gross earnings. It was felt, therefore, that that criterion has a very real relevance to the extent to which an individual station can be called on to pay a higher fee. We are talking about the air waves which are a restricted or limited public resource and, being a restricted or limited public resource, require licensing. The availability of that licensing, of course, should in return both pay for the amount of use and also have some relationship to the extent to which there is a wider or smaller market. Honourable members will be aware that the effects of inflation will inevitably lead to an increase in gross earnings of stations without necessarily a corresponding increase in disposable income. To impose an open ended obligation would steadily increase stations' real expenses. Those expenses will have to be recovered from advertising revenues which will increase the costs to advertisers using medium and larger sized stations.

The Government feels that it is equitable to fix upper limits on the percentages applicable. This allows stations to budget with reasonable assurance and requires that the Government take a positive decision to increase the rate of this taxation, thereby giving the Parliament the opportunity to debate the matter on its merits. The overall level of licence fees and their impact on stations will, however, be kept under review. The Government has decided to re-examine the whole question by 1984 to ensure that the levels of licence fees remain appropriate. The variations will not substantially alter the position of stations in the short term. Stations with gross earnings of less than $2 1/2m will still pay lower fees than under the current provisions and estimated revenue from this source in 1981-82 remains at $31.5m.

Of course, it is true that over the period to 1984 those stations which are not at the ceiling will be called on to pay an increased amount according to the schedule of fees up to the ceiling now to be imposed. The estimated revenue, the licence fees and the changed scale provide a modification to the present system and this modification now being introduced will benefit approximately 120 of the 130 commercial broadcasting stations and 20 of the 50 commercial television stations. The Government hopes that this will enable stations benefiting by these changes to improve programming and services to the public. It does not believe that these aspects will suffer in the bigger stations. Advertising revenue is the life-blood of commercial broadcasting and television. It is directly related to the audience share of a particular station and obviously this relates to the programming appeal of the station to the general public. No station can, therefore, afford to lower its programming standards. The details of the proposed rates are clearly shown in the Bills. The changes will take effect, as they are in fact a repeat of the earlier legislation, on 1 September 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the sorry record of what I would say is the Government's crass stupidity in this matter. We must bear in mind that the charges related basically to whether the people concerned were entitled to pensions. It was a question of medical assessment. It would have been far wiser and more beneficial, particularly from the taxpayers' point of view, perhaps to have refused the pension to those concerned on the basis that medical evidence did not support their present entitlement, rather than charge a large number of people with offences and not be able to prove them. But in November 1980, which I think is very significant bearing in mind that there was an election in October 1980, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) advised the Parliament, through the Senate and after consulting with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), that these charges would be dropped and new charges laid. I think that was a little out of order because the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible, is surely entitled to make up his own mind. Honourable members will recall that a former Attorney-General resigned on the basis that he was not going to be told what to do by the Prime Minister. I make the point that it is significant to consider the gentlemen who are undertaking that case for the Commonwealth. Prior to the last election I announced that the Opposition would have a good look at the issue on the basis of whether the case should be terminated, because it seemed that it was becoming a playground for enrichment-not on any unjustifiable basis except that of the Government's ineptitude. Having said that, I think one of the counsel took umbrage and thought I was suggesting that he was getting money that he was not entitled to. I withdrew any suggestion of that; I never even made the suggestion. But it was significant that the solicitor who wrote to me on his behalf was the same solicitor who prosecuted Mr Whitlam and others. I make the point that there seems to be some interweaving of the whole problem if one looks at the point I have just made. The sum of $2m was spent on counsel for the Commonwealth and another $1m by way of legal aid was spent on counsel for the unfortunates who were trying to defend themselves. It can all be seen in the estimates.

What about the estimates supplied to us? At page 481 of Hansard it is stated that costs of $7,000 have been awarded against the Crown in respect of unsuccessful prosecutions. Yet it is on record on 14 November last year that Mr Brown, S.M. awarded costs of $22,000 against the Crown when no evidence was offered against 38 defendants. As the magistrate pointed out at the time, it is a fundamental principle of the British system of justice that such people are presumed innocent. In fact, 110 persons arrested in March and April of 1978 must be presumed innocent. This case is going on, and it is going to cost more. A prosecution witness who was granted both a pardon and an immunity was offered sums of up to $200,000 for evidence which he might give in court. That is unprecedented anywhere. In my view, there has been an infringement of civil liberties and harassment of innocent people. The Opposition has said that the charges are ludicrous. We have seen consistent evasion and ministerial incompetence in an attempt to cover up the real fraud and conspiracy, that is, the maligning of the Greek people in Australia.

There is also the separate question of a prosecution in Greece under Greek law on charges of fraud against the Australian Government. The Greek Government has been encouraged to lay charges because a fraud has been perpetrated against the Australian Government. It is incredible to think that this could happen and that the charges rely on the same evidence of the police officer concerned. We were told consistently that this action was taken wholly on the initiative of the Greek authorities, yet the evidence against these nine people is the sworn evidence of the same detective involved in the Australian prosecution. The behaviour is inexcusable. I doubt that a worthwhile assessment has been made of whether any of the remaining 73 charges still before the courts have any chance of success.

I wish to deal with another matter. We are well aware that the Sankey v. Whitlam case had no chance of success. It failed but it cost the taxpayers an enormous amount of money. They had to supply legal aid for the defendants. Costs of $75,000 were awarded against Mr Sankey. When they were paid they were to be reimbursed to the taxpayers of Australia. Of course, the costs of the whole case were much more than that. Mr Sankey, understandably, said that he did not have any money-that is another matter for comment-that he could not pay the $75,000, and that he would go to gaol. I raised this matter in the Estimates committee. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) said that if I could produce some evidence something would be done about investigating the matter I had raised. As Mr Sankey was not able to pay the $75,000 and as it looked as though he would go to gaol, how remarkable it was that a dear old lady-that was the expression used in the Press-walked into the Queanbeyan Court and paid the $75,000 for him with a bank cheque. It was a remarkable act of charity that saved Mr Sankey from going to gaol.

The issue underlying this is where the $75,000 came from. I said in the committee that if I could produce evidence the Australian Federal Police should pursue the matter further. The evidence is that the $75,000 came from the ANZ Bank at Burwood by way of a bank cheque. There is the chance for the government to get the Federal Police to go to the ANZ Bank and find out from whose account the $75,000 was withdrawn. As honourable members know, if a person gives funds to somebody else to lay a prosecution, two issues arise on the question of maintenance of an action. One is civil maintenance and the other is criminal maintenance. There are all the elements of criminal maintenance in this matter. In other words, a criminal offence could be established. If it is shown that this money came from somebody else's account, particularly that of a member of parliament, it is a matter with which we can deal in this place. It is certainly a matter on which we need a report. I am not satisfied that the matter can be ignored. CANADA WANTS TO SPEND $500M ON BIOTECHNOLOGY

Canada should spend $483m on biotechnology in the next decade said John Roberts, Canadian Minister of State for Science and Technology, last week after receiving a hard-hitting report from a ministerial task force.

The report says Canada has 'a practically non-existent biotechnological industrial base, a rapidly shrinking federal government research capability and a highly fragmented and unfocused university effort'. It calls for a 10-year national plan to develop biotechnology. This would require $33m in its first year and $50m a year for the remaining nine years.

The task force's report selects key areas of biotechnology particularly suited to Canada. It calls for Canada to make better use of its forestry resources, which already bring in $12 billion a year. It says: 'the forestry industry in particular is in danger of losing its world competitive position because of its slow pace of innovation stemming from a comparatively low investment in research'. Much of the money in the 10-year plan will probably finance research on ways of turning wood cellulose into sugars and starches-the new feedstocks for biological processes. Canada should also concentrate on discovering how to make the best use of hundreds of thousands of tonnes of cellulose wastes from its pulp and paper mills.

The strength of Canada's agriculture prompted two other recommendations that the task force made-for more research on nitrogen fixation and plant breeding. Canada alone in the Western world has no antibiotics industry, so it is no surprise that the task force wants more money on this kind of research. Rather more puzzling, however, is its suggestion for research into microbes for mining awkward seams of mineral such as copper. This is surprising because most of the processes of this kind tried in Canada have proved unprofitable.

The Ministry of State for Science and Technology took about a month to approve the task force's report. By contrast, the British government took over a year to respond-negatively-to the Spinks report on biotechnology. But then John Roberts is personally very keen on the subject.

On the other hand, the science ministry has no money of its own to spend and must go cap in hand to other departments, such as the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Resources. Eminent biotechnologists, such as Murray Moo-Young, professor of chemical engineering at the University of Waterloo, are sceptical that the government will ever stump up more than the initial $33m for the proposed program.

Meanwhile the provincial government in Ontario has set up a biotechnology company with the help of Canada's biggest brewer, Labatt's. The firm has $105m to spend over the next 10 years. It will, however, face a keen shortage of qualified manpower. Last week, for example, the company issued a press release recruiting staff at the European Congress on Biotechnology in Eastbourne.

In Australia we have come to accept the fallacy that education reached its peak in the early 1970s and is now in decline. As a result, many misinformed people in the community have come to accept the propaganda line that we have too many teachers, too many university students and too many graduates and to accept that numbers in secondary schools and tertiary institutions can and should fall in the 1980s. This involves making the assumption, which many administrators, politicians and policy-makers are all too ready to do, that the working classes are largely ineducable, that migrants should be left to do the dirty jobs, that too many women are pursuing higher education and that education is essentially a cost to the community-an economic liability, in fact-rather than the most important single element in creating a better society.

In Japan, the most productive society per capita, and Sweden, which boasts the highest per capita income, education is recognised as still being the most important single factor in growth. In Japan more than half the process workers in the Honda plant have university degrees, mostly-but not necessarily-in engineering. The Honda workers have discovered that having a degree is no hardship personally-quite the reverse. It adds to their potential for mobility and promotion and adds incentives to product improvement. In Australia, Great Britain and New Zealand the cultural context of industrial employment is entirely different from that of Japan. The idea of process workers in factories having degrees would be rejected out of hand as an absurdity.

I conclude with one observation. I refer to an article in the New Scientist of 6 November 1980 called 'Japan stakes its future on research'. Japan is a nation with no raw materials whatever and Sweden-a country to compare it with-has very limited raw materials. We find from the article that Japan in 1980 spent 1.7 per cent of its gross national product on research and development. This amount will be three per cent by 1990. President Mitterrand, starting from a base of 1.8 per cent in France expects to triple this by the end of his seven-year term. I point out to the Minister for Science and Technology and particularly to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) a comment by MITI-the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry-which reads:
We reject the view that we can buy--
That is, technology but specifically-
chips from abroad. We must create the technology from the beginning to reap the benefits of using it.

The Minister in an uncharacteristic slip in a speech last week commented that if other people invent the wheel we in Australia do not need to invent the wheel all over again. With respect, I think that is profoundly wrong. I think that in many ways we have to think through the whole idea of product innovation, right from the start; that we virtually have to re-invent the wheel in many cases.

Second, this support over the past few years has been unpredictable and deficient. Third, our industry-and our community as a whole-is receiving too little of the benefit of modern technology, and paying too much of its costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Ron Johnston of Wollongong University described our dilemma bluntly and succinctly last year in these terms:
Manufacturing industry is running down its innovative capability to such an extent that it is unlikely to be able to respond to or take advantage of new technological developments.
As a consequence, technological innovation in manufacturing industry is not a competitive proposition.

This is the problem staring us in the face. In the view of the Opposition, the problem is actually aggravated by the 1981-82 Budget as it concerns support for science and technology. That objective is 'to promote and improve the efficiency of Australian industry.' The reasons are that funding is being swamped by the effects of other government attitudes and actions which restrict the access of Australian firms to modern technology, which discourage international competitiveness in Australian industry and which encourage foreign control of Australian industry. For example, the Government's open door policy on foreign investment, especially in the minerals area, places no obligation on foreign investors to transfer technology and skills to Australians. The most debilitated of post-colonial regimes insist on such obligations: This Government is too craven.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) and honourable members opposite examine carefully the operation of the patents system as a case study of how foreign-owned corporations are handed on a plate dominance in the capital-intensive sectors of Australian-based industry. Most payments for technical know-how-85 per cent, in fact-go to related enterprises overseas; that is, to the parent transnationals of firms operating in Australia. Payments by Australian companies to foreign enterprises for technical know-how, including patent licence fees and royalties, totalled $130m in 1978-79. In return, the same payments to Australian firms totalled only $14m. All this occurred at exactly the time when the net deficit in our technological balance of payments was getting steadily worse.

Between 1976-77 and 1978-79, in fact, the deficit had doubled, from $56m to $116m. This is the cumulative effect of the long period of foreign domination of Australian based industry. Among comparable industrialised nations, only Canada is as badly off. Canada introduced laws and restrictions to screen technology transfer agreements back in 1976. By contrast, what we have is a system that actually subverts the development of an independent, competitive, Australian manufacturing industry. The reality is that industry is hesitant to invest in our future through research and development. Judging by its record, the Government will not, or cannot, or does not, know how to encourage and support this absolutely vital investment.

First, a national research, development and innovation corporation will: Administer grants for industrial research and development; co-ordinate government supported research and development programs for manufacturing industry; advise the Government on ways to improve Australian industry through technological innovation; and direct the Government's support to programs which increase the ability of Australian owned firms to capitalise on new industrial technologies, which increase employment in new fields and which improve indigenous capacity in selected industries, especially those based on natural resources and those with a high skill content.

Secondly, the incoming Labor Government will ensure that the development of our mineral and energy resources will bring lasting benefits to Australia's economy. To this end, we will take effective steps to ensure that foreign resource investors will maximise local downstream processing and manufacturing, transfer their technologies to local control and establish local research and development capability. Thirdly, a Labor government will not allow this administration's open door policy on foreign ownership and control of Australian industry to continue. We believe that Australia's place in the coming technological age depends on our traditional capacity for innovation and initiative. We believe that this capacity should be nurtured, not neglected as it has been for the past six years and as it is in this Budget. We believe that it needs, not the reluctant and erratic way of this Government, but encouragement through a responsible and systematic policy of the kind that will be set in train by a Labor government in two years' time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the operations of the Department of Communications. One referred to the provision of television services to the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia which has been a perennial for quite a number of years. In the reply the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The estimated cost of Stage 2 of the project to provide television services for the Eyre Peninsula is $0.7m in Year 1 and $1.1m in Year 2. Further field studies are required before this project can proceed and the proposed appropriation of $150,000 this financial year is for such studies on this and several other major projects. The timing for commencement of the necessary capital works will be the subject of separate consideration in the normal budget context.

Since then I have received a letter from the Minister in which he says that the program will be completed in 1983-84 which is about six or seven years after this project was actually promised. Just prior to the elections in 1977 I made Press statements attacking the Government for its lack of action in the provision of these television services. A Liberal senator who claims responsibility for that area in South Australia queried what I said, accused me of being mischievous and a few other things. I will read that Press statement that was released at that time. It reads:

Senator Don Jessop (Liberal, South Australia) said today that he had just received a definite undertaking from the Minister for Post and Telecommunications, Mr Eric Robinson, that a satisfactory television service would be operating on Eyre Peninsula and the West Coast within the next twelve months.
Senator Jessop said it was not possible to give a firm date when the service would commence, but it would be within the new year.
Specific details are in the final stages of preparation which includes the location of the installations.

This is a definite public undertaking and providing the present Government is returned, the people of Eyre Peninsula will be able to enjoy a decent television service at long last, Senator Jessop said.

That Press statement is dated 2 December 1977. Since then I have continually pressed the Government to try to get something definite on what it intended to do. One could never get anything positive. The replies from the various Ministers as to what was going to happen were always airy-fairy. In May 1978 I asked the Minister a question on this matter. He said:

Broadly speaking, however, it is envisaged that the project will include a high-power national station on Mount Cooper to provide a wide coverage service to the rural population in the western section of the Peninsula, subsidiary low-power national translators to serve Streaky Bay, Smoky Bay-Haslam, Wudinna and Kimba, a medium-power translator to serve the farming area in the central Eyre Peninsula, including the towns of Cleve and Lock, a translator at Port Augusta and an additional translator at Port Lincoln. In addition, upgrading of the existing national translators at Mount Olinthus and Brothwicks Hill is envisaged to provide improved coverage along the west coast of Spencer Gulf.

We have kept asking the various Ministers these questions to try to get something definite from them. Over the years we have never been able to get anything quite definite. On 9 November 1979 the Minister for Post and Telecommunications, who was then Mr Staley, in answer to a question I asked, said:

While the plan has not as yet been finalised nor submitted to me in final form for approval, officers of my Department have advised me that they expect to commence acquisition of sites on the Eyre Peninsula by the middle of next year. This would allow the necessary facilities to be progressively constructed and completed by the end of 1982.

The present Minister for Communications, in his latest letter, refers to 1983-84. I give the previous Minister, Mr Staley, credit in that he did endeavour to speed up the matter. He realised that the Government's record in the provision of these services was pretty abysmal which was how I described it in a question I asked the Minister last March. He wrote to the Acting General Manager of Telecom in these terms:

I write to seek your personal consideration of a difficult problem of project scheduling in the capital works program to extend the national broadcasting system. This is, as you know, administered by my Department with Telecom Australia acting as construction agent.

The particular project is to extend and upgrade national television services in the Eyre Peninsula region of South Australia. This has had a most unfortunate history of unmet commitments, and I am determined to commence actual installation of these facilities as a matter of urgency.
He went on further to say:

I have given a personal commitment to the residents of these areas to complete this part of the overall project as quickly as possible. My specific undertaking was to commence installation of these sites before the end of this year so that actual transmission could begin early next year.

That is, early this year 1981. We now find in the latest information from the Minister that it is now to be in 1983-84. The good senator who claims that he represents my electorate came out with another statement at the same time. It is in these terms:
Senator Don Jessop announced today that he had received further information on progress to extend national television services to the west coast of Eyre Peninsula.

Senator Jessop had previously announced that facilities to bring ABC television to this area would be commenced at Wirrula, Streaky Bay and Kongwirra before the end of this year so that actual transmission could commence early next year.

The Minister had today approved technical operating conditions for these three projects. As it is intended that they all be installed on sites owned by the Commonwealth there will be no difficulties in site acquisition. Therefore the Minister expects that installation will commence immediately.

In any case the Minister had advised me Senator Jessop said, that he would be personally taking the matter up with the Acting Chairman of Telecom Australia, who act as the construction agents, to ensure that Telecom understands the Minister's desire to move immediately.

That statement was made in August 1980, just over 12 months ago. Honourable members will note that it states that television services to the west coast of Eyre Peninsula would open earlier that year. Since that time one small station, with limited range and using the Intelsat satellite, has been opened. It was only by sheer luck that it could be installed. Apparently the dish that was to receive the signal from the satellite was to go to a place in Western Australia. People sent petitions which stated that they did not want this because of possible interference with commercial television. It saved the Government a bit of embarrassment. It took the dish that was to go to Western Australia and placed it at Streaky Bay. Of all those projects about which there have been promises concerning when they would come on air, only Streaky Bay has a small station.

It is quite obvious from what the Minister has said in his latest letter to me that it will be 1983-84 before this project is completed. So much for the earlier statements that were made that Eyre Peninsula would have television within 12 months; that is, in 1978. There has been a list of broken promises and broken commitments. Even the previous Minister responsible described the situation as such. I mentioned when speaking on this matter that I expected that the previous Minister, Mr Staley, would not be the Minister for Post and Telecommunications by the time television reached Eyre Peninsula. I hazard a guess that the present Minister will not be Minister for Communications when those installations finally arrive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I relate my remarks about the report of Estimates Committee C to the Department of Administrative Services, particularly the property section of that Department. If honourable members examine the important role of this Department they can see that if they use their influence in a planned way they could have an enormous influence over the pattern and development of the major cities in our country. At present there seems to be a free market forces approach to the role of the Department of Administrative Services. There also seems to be very little planning regarding the location of Commonwealth employees. In a study the Whitlam Government carried out in 1974-75 we found that each year half a million square feet of floor space was rented by the Department of Administrative Services and another half a million square feet was needed to upgrade the conditions under which the people accommodated worked. But it goes far beyond that because apart from accommodating Commonwealth departments the Department also accommodates statutory authorities such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Trans Australia Airlines, Australia Post, Telecom Australia and the Commonwealth Bank, just to name a few. Those organisations, as well as Commonwealth public servants, should be located in areas which are in the best interests of planned development of the metropolis as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly refer to two cities which had programs set out by the then Australian Labor Government in 1972-75. Sydney and Melbourne worked in co-operation with both a conservative government in New South Wales and a conservative government in Victoria on planning and development. Under the McMahon Government, which had been the government of the day, the property section of the Department of Administrative Services-or whatever its name was at that time; it has varied from time to time-was in favour of developing a Commonwealth Offices site at Woolloomooloo in Sydney. That site could have housed 15,000 Commonwealth public servants. The Labor Party was supported with information which convinced even a conservative member of the Joint Committee on Public Works that we should not then proceed with the Woolloomooloo site. The project was deferred.

When the Labor Government came to government it made it clear that we would not proceed with the Woolloomooloo development. The 15,000 Commonwealth public servants would be located at sub-metropolitan centres throughout metropolitan Sydney. On gaining office we immediately acquired the first site at Meggitt's in Parramatta. We decided that we would develop that site to house between 4,500 and 5,000 Commonwealth public servants. We decided that in developing Meggitt's site and similar areas no longer would we build just office blocks for public servants; other human environment would be there as well. At Meggitt's two theatres, art galleries and child minding centres would be built. We would have social, recreation and retail facilities for people living in that building. Also we would be able to create cultural and artistic facilities for the communities of the western suburbs which had been so badly treated for so long.

Not only would Commonwealth public servants have been located at Parramatta but also we would have located them at places such as Blacktown, Penrith, Liverpool, Campbelltown and probably Hurstville or Sutherland on the southern end of Sydney. The reason for that was two-fold. It is necessary that jobs are located where people live. Also, if a Commonwealth government supports its State counterparts in upgrading urban public transport we should not encourage transport systems being geared to a peak load-in other words all the jobs being created in the central business district of, for example, Sydney or Melbourne. We want to see jobs and social amenities created out in the fringes of the cities.

If the property section of the Department of Administrative Services had people with foresight to plan we could create a much more balanced metropolis. When we were in government we carried out a study with the Victorian Liberal Government of the day. It was found that 18,000 too many Commonwealth public servants were located in the central business district of Melbourne. It was agreed, again by jointly planning with the Victorian Government, that we should develop sub-metropolitan centres in places such as Sunshine in the west, Broadmeadows in the north, Dandenong in the south-east and Epping-Watsonia in the north-east. Those places would have been built up in a similar pattern to what I have talked about in relation to Sydney. It distresses me that again the market forces are allowed to take over. Most of the space rented by the property section of the Department of Administrative Services is in the central business districts of Melbourne and Sydney. This is not in the best interests of employees. For example, Sydney stretches 50 kilometres west, 50 kilometres south-west, about 35 kilometres north and 35 kilometres south. Most people who live in the area are forced to travel to their employment in or near the central business district of Sydney. What we need to do when developing and planning a metropolis is to make sure that the Commonwealth gives the lead, in co-operation with the States and local government, in developing the sub-metropolitan centres as I have mentioned.

I have given examples only of Sydney and Melbourne but examples can be given of other places as well. It is important at all times that the Commonwealth does not withdraw from its responsibilities or allow market forces to determine these issues; it should start to locate its huge work force in a proper way. I believe that, if the Government works in co-operation with the State governments and local government on the location of both Commonwealth and State public servants and people employed in statutory authorities, it will have an enormous influence on the future pattern of development in our cities. At a time when there is an energy crisis, people should not be forced to travel 100 kilometres a day to go to and from work. They should be given jobs and opportunities where they live. During our period in government we created a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office at Macarthur House in Parramatta. Volunteers were sought to fill the 1,000 positions created there. In fact 1,500 Commonwealth public servants from within the Taxation Office volunteered to work at the Taxation Office in Parramatta. I am quite sure that if a centre were built at Penrith, in the area represented by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free), public servants living in areas of the lower Blue Mountains, in the St Mary's, Mount Druitt and Seven Hills areas, would move, both from west to east and from east to west, to a place such as Penrith for their employment. If we are to upgrade a transport system, we need to ensure that people move in both directions in the mornings, instead of having the present peak load situation. I give notice that, when we are in government in 1983, we will implement this policy in co-operation with the State and local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, under this Government the environment portfolio has received a very low priority indeed. In the six years of the Fraser Government it has been shuffled through at least four multiple departments. Equally unfortunately, in this year's Budget expenditure on very important environmental programs has been severely cut. A mere $16m in total has been made available. That is a reduction of 17.2 per cent in real terms over the last year. What is more there is an indication that it is the Government's intention to cut staff levels by 6 per cent over the next financial year. I will give some of the worst examples of the cuts. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has had its funds cut by 16.2 per cent. That is not surprising because in the razor gang proposals it was made very clear that Federal interest in national parks in the Northern Territory was to be scaled down. I forewarn the House that the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, which I think will be released in the next week may have something very interesting to say about that proposal. Similarly, grants to voluntary conservation organisations have been severely cut. They have been cut by almost 50 per cent since 1976-by almost 10 per cent in the last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of this is that these groups do an excellent job. The Government refuses to order environmental impact statements on major projects. Since 1976 only 18 have been ordered to cover projects under the auspices of the Department of Trade and Resources or the Department of National Development and Energy. Similarly, the Government has refused to order public inquiries under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. Because of these two facts the role of voluntary conservation groups is most crucial indeed. The Government must reconsider its miserly attitude to the voluntary environmental groups throughout Australia. When the Government is very tardy about ordering public inquiries and environmental impact statements, in effect these groups are doing the Government's work and clearly they ought to be funded. Funding that has been cut over the last five or six years should be reinstated in real terms.

I turn now to an area in which funding was increased in this Budget. I refer to the 21 per cent increase, in real terms, in funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. However, strangely, its staff has been cut by five positions. The implication of this is that that reduction in staff will be made in the section responsible for preparing zoning plans for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. There is little wonder at that because over the last seven years only 2.4 per cent of the park has been declared, including only 0.008 per cent of the Cairns section. This Government has been guilty of both cowardice and capitulation to the Queensland Premier and of lying to the environmental and reef protection groups in Queensland about this matter. I will explain that. In 1975, when we introduced the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority Act, we thought that over the subsequent eight or 10 years the whole of the Barrier Reef would be declared as park, that is, the whole area from the low water mark on the west to Torres Strait in the north and to south of Gladstone. However, as I have said, after six years, only 2.5 per cent of the park has been declared. This has been the fault of the Government in not standing up to the Government of Queensland.

The ministerial council responsible, which comprises two Federal Ministers and two State Ministers, is a body which is supposed to consider the recommendations of the Authority, yet it did not meet for 13 months, until 28 September 1981. We were told that the Cairns section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park would be declared by Christmas last year. What have we seen? Since the previous ministerial council meeting less than 0.01 per cent has been declared. Why is this so? It is so because the Queensland Government and the Queensland Premier wish to allow oil drilling in or near the Barrier Reef, and so does this Government. Why else does this Government not use its power under the Act to declare the park? Why did it amend the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to allow oil drilling within 30 miles of the reef on the eastern side?

The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) must accept one simple and fundamental fact: He is being heavied and bullied and stood over by Bjelke-Petersen, the Queensland Government and the Queensland bureaucrats on this very important matter. The Minister submitted eight proposals to the recent ministerial council meeting and the Queensland Government submitted none. All the Federal proposals were knocked over, yet the Queensland Government submitted none. Why does the Minister accept this humiliation? It is humiliation not only of himself but also of the Government. I will tell the House what is going on. I will quote from an article in the Canberra Times of 15 October 1981 which states:
Publicly, federal officials are loath to criticise the Queensland Government because that could upset the delicate relationship between the governments and the snail's-pace negotiations.

However, one Federal official said the position was similar to the Yom Kippur war and (mixing his metaphors) that some of the Queensland techniques of propaganda were 'straight out of Hitler's Germany-very frightening and hard to overcome'.
In turn, Queensland officials responded by called the Marine Park Authority 'a mob of egg-heads' and Federal Ministers 'weak to ridiculous'.
State officials also leaked out stories that declaration of a total marine park 'could cause the resources boom to come to a grinding bloody halt'.
The officials told deliberate lies that the marine park would mean ships might not be able to move through reef waters . . .

So the sorry story goes on. Why is the Minister allowing bureaucrats to mislead him and to obstruct the stated intention of the Federal Government to declare by Christmas last year the Cairns section of the Barrier Reef below the high water mark? We have seen no action except that at the last meeting only 0.008 per cent of the Cairns section was declared, making a total of 2.5 per cent declared over the last seven years. What a sorry record that is. The World Heritage Committee will meet in Sydney next week. This Government has nominated the Great Barrier Reef for inclusion on the World Heritage list, yet it has declared only 2.5 per cent of it as a marine park. Australia, as well as the Minister, will be seen by an international environmental organisation to be, as those Queensland officials described the two Federal Ministers, weak and ridiculous.

In the closing minutes of the time available to me, I wish to deplore the fact that no funds were allocated this financial year to conduct public inquiries under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The Minister has supplied information to me which purports to say that as it cannot be anticipated at the time of preparation of the estimates whether there will be an inquiry no money is allocated, but if there is any inquiry money will be allocated during the financial year. Over the last seven years there have been only two public inquiries, one into Ranger and one into Fraser Island, both of which were instigated by the previous Whitlam Labor Government, and on which this Government to some degree has acted, particularly in the case of Fraser Island. That is two inquiries in seven years, both instigated by the Federal Labor Government of the time. When will this Government accept its responsibilities and start to order some public inquiries into great environmental issues, into areas of national significance that are included in the National Estate, issues such as sand mining on Moreton Island? In regard to South West Tasmania, we have moved in this Parliament to challenge the Federal Government to set up an inquiry, and that is what should be done with regard to hydro-electric developments. It should also be noted that all the people of Brisbane, Queensland, including the City Council, the Opposition shadow Minister, and the State Opposition are in favour of a public inquiry and are not in favour of sand mining on Moreton Island.
