TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the report of Estimates Committee C relating to the Department of Communications. The two matters with which I would like to deal are the Government's attack on the role of Telecom Australia as the common carrier, and the campaign that is being waged to hand over the more lucrative elements of Telecom's activities. In the first instance, it is a fundamental right of every Australian to participate in the common carrier philosophy, and the right to proper communications is fundamental to that philosophy. Everything this Government has done over the last few years has led to the basis being laid for an attack on that principle. Unfortunately, we as a party declined to oppose what might be the modus operandi for giving effect to that attack when we did not oppose the Overseas Telecommunications Amendment Act in 1981. That Act breaks down the monopoly of Telecom and lays the basis for an attack on that principle. The real issue here is not whether we want to maintain a monopoly on employees in a department or in a particular industry, it is a fundamental principle that applies to every Australian. It is not a question of whether we can afford communications. We have a fundamental right to communications. The obvious manoeuvre of the Government is in that direction and believe me, it will move in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Referring to the handing over of the more lucrative areas of Telecom's activities, the basis for that was laid when the late Mr Eric Robinson and the then Minister, Mr Staley, came to grips on the issue. An argument ensued and the matter was taken to Cabinet by Mr Robinson. A decision was made that private enterprise would not only participate but also would participate to a large extent. When the communications satellite was mooted, Mr Robinson indicated that, as far as he was concerned, there would be participation by private enterprise in the consortium that would run it. In 1980 it was said that there should be private participation in that satellite, otherwise there would be a great drain on the funds of Telecom, which should be used for the extension of the system. That is a complete hoax, because it did not extend the system. The fact is that deferred applications during 1980-81 are higher now than they ever have been.

By draining the funds of Telecom the Government is in fact limiting the capacity of Telecom to provide a service to everybody in Australia. The Government gave to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) the job of telling Telecom how to run its affairs. He could not organise the running of a penny-in-the-slot lavatory; he is in no position to be able to advise Telecom on how it should run its business. Telecom is a very efficient organisation. It developed its workshops and entered into research, leading up to the time when the satellite communications system was handed over to the consortium. It has carried out research related to the viewdata and other processes, which will be lucrative areas of operation in the future. It has carried out all those investigations and is in a position economically to put them into effect.

Let us look at the great carve-up. The Government is helping big business at the expense of every communications consumer in this country. It is selectively applying favours to private companies such as the Myer Emporium Ltd and others. The Myer Emporium enters into nothing which will not be lucrative. I worked with that company for a number of years, and the number of people it squeezes to death is nobody's business. It is in the market to skim the cream off the top. It will not participate in communications in the country areas, where losses will be incurred; it will be scooping off the cream. One of the areas where the cream will be is the viewdata processing area. In all the add-on connections that will be made in the communications areas, Myer will be right in on the ground floor. It was to be part of the consortium set up to run the satellite system. Peter Holmes a'Court indicated on its behalf, and on behalf of others, that they were not interested in the non-profit areas that would be provided by the satellite; they were interested only in the fact that when it did get under way it would be subsidised by every consumer of communications in this country. The installation and maintenance of PABXs-private automatic branch exchanges-is a lucrative area based on business usage. The Government has given exclusive rights for supply to private industry. Most of those machines are now imported. The Government has cut Telecom right out of the research and design and the provision of that equipment. Telecom would insist on local content if it were able to proceed with the program that it had laid out in the first instance. It developed its workshops for the purpose of research and design in many areas. But what did this Government do? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a matter which I raised in the Estimates Committee concerning the negative role of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) and his lack of support for measures ensuring that the Australian environment and human health are protected from the danger of hazardous chemicals. Specifically, the Minister has failed to support recent international efforts by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to develop principles and standardised guidelines for the testing of chemicals, backed away from any commitment to making such procedures compulsory for companies introducing new chemicals, and opted for the introduction of a voluntary interim notification scheme from 1 October this year, but provided no staff resources to the hazardous chemicals sections of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment to administer the scheme. I understand that that section of the Department employs five or six people. Clearly, that is quite inadequate to manage any kind of internal section in a department dealing with hazardous chemicals. Clearly, it is quite inadequate to deal with a major new scheme for which the Government is making some claims.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 50,000 chemicals are in commercial use in Western industrial economies but very few have been tested for their long term effects on the environment and human health. The public has increasingly become aware of public health disasters associated with chemical spills, explosions and accidents such as the notorious incident at Love Canal in Upper Niagara in the United States of America, where the dumping of toxic wastes led to birth defects and spontaneous abortion among residents for 20 to 30 years later. Australia has not been entirely free of such accidents. I mention the collision on the Pacific Highway near Port Macquarie involving a truck carrying chemicals. This case was recently highlighted on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's Nationwide program. The whole question of agent orange also has been a matter of considerable concern to some honourable members in this House. I do not intend to canvass the matter, although it represents an example of the hazards associated with chemicals in common use within this country.

Hazardous chemicals also provide a major threat to the health of workers exposed to them in key industries. Workers' health is being endangered not by high dosages but by long term exposure to low levels of chemicals. Chemicals used in the work place can cause cancer, birth defects and diseases of the kidney, heart and liver. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has recently said that such incidents have constituted industrial tragedies. Examples of such tragedies include bladder cancer among workers handling dyestuffs in rubber industries and cancer and lung disease. The latter have taken a heavy toll among workers in the asbestos industries, for example, the workers at Wittenoom Gorge in Western Australia. Two out of three workers with exposure of more than five years have contracted asbestosis. Acro osteolysis, or clubbing of the fingers, occurs from exposure to vinyl chloride monamer in the PVC plastics industries located in various cities around Australia.

While these are the most well-known examples, my concern is that grossly inadequate regulatory mechanisms have allowed many more potentially hazardous chemicals to be introduced without adequate safeguards. This was of relevance to this Committee. As a result of questioning the Committee heard of the initiatives being taken, within the OECD. Mr Crawford, a former member of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has been very closely associated with these initiatives. These moves have been towards developing standardised agreements so that chemical companies are requested to pre-test chemicals before they are released. The OECD's chemical program has been working towards international collaboration on the management of hazardous chemicals. The program aims to harmonise national systems to test chemicals, foster information exchanges, and develop common approaches to the assessment.

In May 1980 the OECD convened a high level meeting to consider principles of international harmonisation on the testing of chemicals. At that meeting four draft resolutions were framed for formal adoption by the OECD Council. The four resolutions referred to standardised guidelines for the testing of chemicals, principles of laboratory practice for chemicals testing, acceptance of test data on chemicals between OECD countries, and the use of a minimum pre-marketing set of data for initial assessment of new chemicals.

In May 1981, the OECD Council adopted three resolutions on the mutual acceptance of data. The resolutions mean an agreed set of guidelines for testing and standard practices for running laboratories. Australia asbstained from voting on the three resolutions adopted by the OECD Council. The fourth resolution called for the compulsory compliance of companies that wished to introduce new chemicals. The OECD Council is planning to adopt a formal position on this question this year.

The Commonwealth Government claims, as it did before the Committee, that it has no official position on this question. But of course, it is hiding behind constitutional difficulties with the States. Indeed it may be that the Committee was misled when it was told that the Commonwealth had no official position. I believe the Commonwealth's position is negative rather than neutral. In fact the Commonwealth has very clear-cut powers in this area. Nearly all the new chemicals introduced in Australia came from overseas. The Commonwealth Government has clear powers to control the import of new materials. In the related areas of new drugs, pesticides and food additives, the Commonwealth Government exercises firm control and uses clearance schemes of the kind needed for general chemicals. Instead, the Commonwealth has opted to introduce a voluntary notification scheme through the Australian Environment Council. Through this scheme, manufacturers and importers will be asked to notify government authorities voluntarily of the identity of new chemicals. This voluntary notification scheme cannot possibly work in the long run. It places too much onus on private interests to provide information which could be prejudicial to them. Worse, the Federal Government is not really serious in ensuring that even this half-baked scheme will work.

The hazardous chemicals section of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has no resources to support the Australian Environment Council's interim notification scheme. For this job to be performed the section would require a staff of some 13 people. In fact, as I have pointed out, and as was confirmed at the Committee meeting, no additional staff has been provided. The Minister is so serious about this new voluntary notification scheme that he has made no attempt to secure the necessary staff!

The technical requirements of these positions require a majority of them to be filled by people with scientific backgrounds-for example, chemists and biochemists. Such staff cannot be found from other sections of the Department. We have to compare this parlous situation with the assessment and notification procedures for industrial chemicals used in other countries. For example, the United States Toxic Substances Control Act is administered by some 1,000 people in the United States Environment Protection Authority. In Australia the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has no staff to administer its recently introduced prenotification scheme. This scheme was commenced on only 1 October this year and already it appears to be doomed to failure. I wanted to raise these matters which I raised within the Committee to confirm that Australia is well behind other countries within the OECD.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my remarks to the appropriations for the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Trade and Resources. I took part in the deliberations of Estimates Committee F on those two departments and also, due to the temporary absence of the shadow Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who has just spoken, for a short time in its deliberations on the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. I know that he will deliver some remarks and thoughts in relation to that Department in a moment. The two departments on which I am focusing together employ about 2,660 people and spend over $500m per year in providing advice to the Government on trade and industry issues and on operational activities in each of these areas, including the promotion of exports. Clearly, there is a very major commitment of resources and personnel to these very important purposes. Accordingly, I believe we should expect a clear indication that appropriate benefits are accruing from this commitment. Unfortunately, there is little evidence that adequate benefits are being enjoyed by the Australian community. As I was able to indicate in a debate today on a matter of public importance relating to the very sad and tragic decision of ICI (Australia) Ltd, due to inadequate Government policies, not to go ahead with its investment at Point Wilson, I do not believe that adequate benefits are being enjoyed by the Australian community from the efforts of these two departments.
—They referred to wage costs also.

—I do not criticise the departments directly for this. Rather, I believe the current mismanagement of trade and industry and the general economic policy by the Fraser Government is to blame. In the past 12 months there has been a marked shift in Government thinking back to the ideological roots of its long-standing rhetoric. Whilst some of the better elements of the Jackson and Crawford inquiries filtered through to form part of the Government's approach in the period from 1976 to 1980, we have now witnessed their eclipse by the hard line monetarism which is favoured by the most ideologically motivated of the Government's ranks. As such, the future of Australian industry and trade now rests more in the hands of the Treasury and the Prime Minister's Department than with the two departments on which I am focusing, which are formally charged with responsibility in these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: This return to fundamentalism and the consequent rejection of a creative government role in industry and trade development arises for a variety of reasons. All these reasons are political and ideological. They are just as ideological as stupid remarks that are occasionally made about the reason for the ICI closure being related to wages only. That is extraordinarily narrow thinking. It is just ideological thinking when one takes into account all the other factors which are responsible for increases in costs and prices in this community. The Government's arguments are not economic. They do not reflect a reasonable assessment of the needs of industry in this country at this stage of our history. The reasons include the need of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to maintain his support with the dries of the Liberal Party back bench and the encouragement he has taken from his mentors in the Reagan and Thatcher camps. They also arise from the Government's blind acceptance of market forces, even when they result in such disruptive experiences as the recent up-valuation of the Australian dollar. As the annoucement of the deferral of the $500m ICI petrochemical plant shows, such blind faith will lead us to lose many developmental opportunities.

The list of failures of this Government in relation to trade and industry policy grows longer every day. In the brief time available I will list just a few of them. Firstly, there has been a sharp increase in the degree of uncertainty in the manufacturing sector as a result of the Government's vacillating tariff policies for Australian industry. Business has become completely disillusioned with this Government because of its failure to provide a stable environment for manufacturing investment decisions. Secondly, industry consultation has been dramatically downgraded. In 1978 there were 37 meetings of the industry advisory councils. Last year there were only 24 meetings. This year has been even worse. There have been only nine meetings in the first nine months of the year of the dozen or so industry advisory councils. The Government is no longer listening to industry, and industry is wondering whether there is any future for it under the Fraser Government.

Thirdly, programs of assistance to industry and for export promotion have been cut. The Regional Economic Development Scheme has been scrapped. Fourteen companies on the verge of having their projects approved were left with nothing. Other incentives have been reduced, but there is no clear statement of Government policy on any of them. The same applies to the virtually unexplained decision to abolish government procurement preferences for locally produced goods. Fourthly, the financial environment for business has sharply deteriorated. Interest rates are at a record level. A virtual credit squeeze has been applied in recent months. The small business sector has suffered from a lack of finance of various kinds. This has been confirmed again this week by the Bureau of Industry Economics. We in the Australian Labor Party, together with small business organisations, have been pointing out these factors for several years. The response of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) has been perpetual procrastination.

The four weaknesses I have outlined are just some of the weaknesses of the present Government's trade and industry policies. Under these policies Australia now faces a massive trade deficit. Our exports of manufactured goods are stagnant. During 1981 there has been a decline in our exports of the higher technology goods, the so-called elaborately transformed manufactures. The bankruptcy level is at an all time high. Our economic growth has averaged only 2 1/2 per cent over the past six years and unemployment has increased by over 150,000 people since the Fraser Government took office. Quite clearly, the trade and industry policies of this Government are an abysmal failure. Six years after the Government took office virtually every economic indicator shows that there is no recovery. Unemployment is rising again. Under the current trend of the return to monetarist fundamentalism the sad truth is that the indicators are likely to get even worse.

What is needed in Australia today is an entirely different approach to trade and industry policies. The departments of Industry and Commerce and Trade and Resources should be directed to develop a policy package based on an expansionary macro-economic strategy instead of a contractionary one. This requires the preparation, in consultation with industry and trade unions-that consultation is reducing at this time-of an economic plan on a national scale comprising a series of objectives and targets within which business can confidently invest. Such planning in the current context would include at least a medium term commitment to a stable exchange rate and a stable level of tariff protection for industry. At the same time, a more creative program of positive industry assistance is needed. Key elements which are needed in this area and which have not been developed adequately by the current Government include expanded industrial research and development programs; the creation or adaption of financial institutions for the provision of venture capital; the development of a program of equalisation of regional economic development opportunities to provide security in the employment prospects of our provincial and regional cities; the creation of trading companies and other institutions for the direct promotion of Australian exports, particularly manufactured goods; and, the last in my list, which is by no means comprehensive, the overhaul of depreciation schedules in the manufacturing sector.

I willingly acknowledge that a package of this type involves greater government intervention and initiative but it is directed at creating greater entrepreneurial effort in Australia. The vast resources of the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Trade and Resources, which I have been focusing on, are available to make this effort. They should be directed to do so. Business in Australia has become disillusioned with monetarism. Investment projects are being deferred. Internationally we can expect the next few years to witness the demise of the fundamentalist policies of people such as Thatcher, Reagan and Fraser. That process has already begun in Europe. Similarly in Australia real hope for sustainable economic recovery lies in planned and co-operatively determined growth strategies rather than the confrontation and restriction practised by the current Administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject some of the tired old cliches that we have just heard from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford). Without putting too fine a point on it, what we are seeing now in 1981 is a far cry from what we saw a few brief years ago when businesses in droves were planning to leave this country if the Australian Labor Party were returned to office. We cannot say that business confidence in this country, whilst it can be better, is not at a much higher level than it was when this Government took over in 1975, and is increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I speak briefly on an aspect of business which I believe needs attention and where some improvements can be made. I speak about the compulsory distribution of the profits of private companies. In this country at the moment the best figures that are available to me show that some 66,000 private companies paid tax in the last financial year. Something like 130,000 private companies did not pay tax but, presumably, they are hoping in due course to move into the tax bracket as their businesses become more successful. The state of affairs at present is that under division 7 of the tax Act some 30 per cent of the profit of private companies must be distributed back to the shareholders. If they are not, then that 30 per cent of profit attracts an undistributed profits tax of some 50 per cent.

There may be some historical reasons for this penalty on undistributed profits. There was a time when there was a differential tax on private and public companies. It can be argued that it is better now to have a tax on 30 per cent of the undistributed profits than the situation a couple of years ago when it was 50 per cent. But that is a fairly weak argument in my view. We should be moving to providing no penalty at all on the undistributed profits of private companies. I acknowledge that this tax provides a certain amount of revenue to the Government. Of course, this is not to be lightly dismissed at a time when the Government is trying to restrain its spending. This does not, in my view, outweigh the factors in support of abolishing the requirement of taxing undistributed profits.

In the main, there are two arguments that I put forward in support of the abolition of the tax on undistributed profits. The first is that this tax discriminates against private companies compared with public companies. Public companies are not required to distribute their profits. If they do not they are not subjected to a tax. They are in the hands of the shareholders. So, we have discrimination against private companies. A second main reason for the abolition of this tax is that it is preventing the development and expansion of the very people whom we should be encouraging-the small companies and the family companies which are establishing themselves and trying desperately to forge a business, to expand and to get on with the business of making Australia strong. Private companies find it very difficult to expand under the present climate, particularly at a time of high interest rates. The 30 per cent that goes to the shareholders under a forced distribution is further taxed. This taxing may be at whatever level the recipient pays tax-at 60 per cent, 46 per cent or 32 per cent. Once those people get the money in their hands they are taxed on it. Even if they wish to return the money to the company to which they belong there is very little left. It would seem to me that it is much better-if it is the shareholders' wish-for the money to be left in a company which is trying to expand.

This tax is a discriminatory provision. I have failed to find anyone in government or out, in the Public Service or in the private sector who believes that it is in any way justified and should be retained. I ask the Government to take note of this inconsistency. I believe that what I have suggested is very much in the interests of encouraging a stronger free enterprise economy. I ask the Government to move in the next Budget so that this provision is totally removed. The latest release of the Bureau of Industry Economics Research Report No. 10 entitled 'Finance for Small Business Growth and Development' states:
The investigation, based on data obtained from more than 4,000 firms, was the most extensive and detailed yet conducted on the availability of capital for small firms in Australia . . .

'While many small firms are successful in obtaining the funds needed to finance growth, the report reveals a number of apparent weaknesses in existing arrangements for financing small manufacturing and service enterprises' . . .
Most of these enterprises are private companies. The statement continues:
'These include a shortage of equity capital, inadequate sources of venture capital, particularly for product-innovative firms, and possibly a scarcity of start-up capital for new enterprises.
'The report also explains why small firms may not benefit from the interest rate ceiling on bank loans of less than $100,000'.
I make the plea that as soon as possible this discriminatory provision be removed. It is one option that I am putting forward in a constructive way to help small business in this country.

Sound micro-economic policy and the degree of planning and Government involvement which of necessity go with it, have been left wanting because this administration is incapable of providing the sort of macro-economic environment in which all sectors of the business community can grow and prosper. If businesses are to succeed we must have a more adventurous policy on the part of government. No amount of special assistance to small businesses will curb the present bankruptcy rate of well in excess of 5,000 per annum-that is 100 bankruptcies a week throughout Australia; a figure which represents a 250 per cent leap on the prevailing rate in the mid-1970s-if enterprises are compelled to conduct their trade in conditions of economic recession, an avoidable economic recession which is being promoted by high interest rates and contractionary fiscal policies of a government afraid of growth and economic recovery because it knows it cannot put together a sensible pricing and incomes policy.

In 1981 we have seen the final abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal after a long process of dismemberment and disembowelment. It may be argued that what was left of the PJT at the time that the Lynch razor gang finally wielded the knife probably was not worth saving. In terms of promoting this sensible prices and incomes policy that this country needs so badly, the PJT, as it stood after continued hatchet jobs by the Fraser Government on its powers and staffing, left it with little or no industrial relations role to play. Between 1975-76 when this Government came to power and the beginning of 1981 staff numbers of the PJT were reduced by about 50 per cent and its powers cut back to where it was commonly seen in industry and in the trade union movement as being a mere supervisor of inevitable price flow-ons to consumers. The facts are that this Government never gave the PJT a chance. It never provided it with adequate staff, resources, legislative power, or moral backing. It certainly never provided it with the sort of general economic backdrop of growth with stability that would have enabled the PJT to fulfil even a limited role in selectively bearing down on unjustified and unfair pricing practices.

Now we have the Petroleum Pricing Authority in its place. The fate of the PJT will no doubt serve as a warning to the PPA to ensure that it keeps not only to the letter of its legislative powers but also well within the unwritten ideological confines set by this Government. That is a pretty straight and narrow area. The PPA will have a staff of approximately 14-one for every million persons in Australia. This represents yet another drastic reduction of government commitment to this area on top of the reductions that I have noted earlier. Yet we will be told all this is presumably in the name of efficiency. Let me ask the Minister: How efficient is it to conduct substantial work on pricing in the aluminium industry because the Government suspects there is a massive rip-off going on and then refuse to make use of the results? Despite recent claims about lack of profitability in the industry it must be noted, as my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide has done on a number of occasions, that the price for Australian aluminium-a commodity in which everybody would agree we have a comparative advantage-has, despite the recent price cuts, remained relatively stable whilst the price of aluminium on the London Metals Exchange and the free market prices has plunged by at least 40 per cent since January 1980.

The Government is a substantial user of aluminium and aluminium products, yet it is even unwilling to provide the information which it has gleaned at great expense to satisfy the Australian taxpayer that he or she is getting value for money in government purchasing. Yet it would be wrong to suggest that the PJT has been the only area to suffer in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. Both the Trade Practices Commission and the Industries Assistance Commission have suffered greater staff cuts than the overall 3 per cent lowering of staff ceiling to be implemented in the Public Service by 1982. The TPC does not even have a final staff figure set for June 1982. According to the Public Service Board annual report it is the only department or departmental authority not to have at least the dubious benefit of such a target to set its priorities over the next 12 months. Questioning by Opposition members at the Estimates Committee hearing produced responses from the Minister which served to emphasise the comments made in both the Trade Practices Commission and the Industries Assistance Commission annual reports that both those bodies were unable to fulfil the full scope of their charters because of government interference in their staffing arrangements.

I am not overburdened with time so I will pass to another matter about which I questioned the Minister. It is related to another area of the Department of Industry and Commerce. I noted in the estimates that an amount of $750,000 was set down over a two-year period to alert the Australian public to the heinous results or the disastrous effects on the Australian economy of a move to a shorter working week in the metal trade industry. It appeared that this huge advertising campaign set out, with this large amount of money, to convince the Australian people what a disastrous situation it would be if working hours were reduced from 40 hours. Upon questioning the Minister he told me that the staff who have the job of implementing this advertising campaign and spending this $750,000 work 36 1/4 hours a week with flexitime. What a ridiculous situation it is that people working 36 1/4 hours have $750,000 to spend to tell the Australian people what a disastrous effect it would have on our economy if the metal workers got their week reduced from 40 hours. I think that fully sums up the attitude of this Government to most things, particularly in the business area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer very briefly to the estimates for the Department of National Development and Energy, that part of the estimates that allocates some $35m to water resource programs throughout Australia. I refer in particular to the salinity problems of the River Murray. Over the past few weeks and as a result of the tabling in this House yesterday of the new River Murray Waters Agreement we realise that constitutional difficulties have hampered and caused major indecision in the development of our national incentives affecting the long term well-being of Australia's greatest national resource, the Murray-Darling Basin. This is because, under the Constitution, States have a pre-eminent role in all aspects of water resources. The Commonwealth has become involved in these problems only at the request of the States or in response to Commonwealth initiatives but always-I emphasise 'always'-in co-operation with the States. I, and others in this House, have, to the point of frustration, put forward suggestions that national authorities be created to manage and monitor Australia's inland waters. A recent Senate select committee proposed the setting up of a national water commission, but all State governments have opposed this. A national authority for the Murray-Darling system, if it were to work effectively, would require the surrender by at least three States of practically all matters in the Murray-Darling catchment which affect water quantity and quality; that is, not only water regulation and allocation but also policy on irrigation development, land use for agriculture, forestry and industrial development.

SPEECH.PARA: To date no State has agreed to cede or even to share these responsibilities with a national authority. At the outset I referred to the recent River Murray Waters Agreement. It has taken five years of negotiation for a new agreement which only gives the River Murray Commission responsibility to manage river quality. This new arrangement, which does place new responsibilities on the River Murray Commission, particularly formulates water quality objectives and standards for any part of the River Murray. It will also allow assessments of the implications of new developments which could have significant impact on water quality in the river and representations on any proposals which might adversely affect water quality. The new agreement will also allow further development of strategies to reduce salinity and other water quality problems in the river to manageable proportions.

There has already been too much parochialism, selfishness and political unawareness that has stopped effective and prompt action on Australian water research and control. I do not wish to add to that. We all know of the reasons why various States held off signing this agreement over the years and everyone must make his own political judgment on this. This case simply emphasises the difficulties. This new agreement only gives the River Murray Commission an advisory role in matters affecting water quality. It does not give it a managerial or enforcement role which would be necessary for a national water authority to be effective. While this parochialism is perhaps understandable, I believe that long term national development and research must be carried out by professionals without any restrictions, be they either financial or political. We should be able to develop a program of hydrological research and management over all these waters.

Of course, there are many options that can be put forward for an expanded Commonwealth water research presence. They could, of course, include some of the arrangements laid out in the Bill which has been presented in this Parliament. More appropriately perhaps, we could expand existing organisations such as an institute within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or a division of water research within CSIRO. We could develop a bureau of water research within a Commonwealth department or have the option of having an expanded water research focus in the Department of National Development and Energy. I am personally fed up with the continuing waste of political and community energy and expertise on point scoring and squabbling. Courageous decisions have to be taken following credible unrestrictive research of programs of national importance. Obviously the Commonwealth has an important role to play in this area.

Currently some 30 projects are either in progress or completed to mitigate salinity along the Murray River. But the question I pose is whether any will be adequate to stop further deterioration of our river system. For example, some $35m was provided by the Commonwealth for the construction of Dartmouth Dam and over $26m in loan funds has been provided to the three States to help them meet their respective shares of the cost of this project. Also some $36m has already been spent on major new salinity control projects in the Murray Valley since July 1978. The Commonwealth has provided $18m of this as it matches contributions by the States. I think some heart can be taken about the problems that exist in the Murray-Darling basin from River Murray Commission figures that show that while last year had the second lowest river flow in 15 years, salinity levels were better than those in the 1967-68 drought, indicating that existing works have had some impact.

I am extremely concerned about a project that is presently under way and which the Commonwealth has shared in the funding. That is a project in my electorate called the mineral reserves scheme. I make it quite clear that the responsibility for the decision to establish this scheme was the State Government's. Whilst the State Rivers and Water Supply Commission and back bench public works committee in Victoria recommended the scheme, the final decision must lie with the Victorian Government. There are a number of questions that I would like to have answered about this scheme before it proceeds. Why has there not been full consideration or a research program to develop a major pipeline to the sea? Why was this not considered? How long are we to tolerate the disposal of one region's problems to another area? How long can we continue to create unsightly expanses of saline wasteland or brine lakes, sometimes flooding natural flood plains, wildlife habitats or productive farming lands? How long can we guarantee that new projects will not expand the enormous problem of dry land salinity that is developing in the Mallee region? As desalination technology improves, are we fully capable of monitoring these techniques and considering them as feasible alternatives?

I will give some examples of my reason for questioning the effectiveness of this scheme. It has been estimated by the Victorian State Rivers and Water Supply Commission that the benefits of the mineral reserves basin schemes are a reduction of only 11EC units at Mildura and 7EC units at Morgan, South Australia, at a cost of some $5,500,000. The benefits of the Mildura-Merbein-Buronga interception scheme that is presently operating is a reduction of 9EC units in river saline quality. I also note that the estimated reduction in EC units of the Lake Tyrell proposal that is anticipated to follow the mineral reserves scheme is some 35EC units. I ask the House to relate these figures to the 1.3 million tonnes of salt that enters the River Murray annually over its full length. Thirty six per cent of this salt intake occurs along the South Australian section of the river. To emphasise further the immensity of this salt load, it is the equivalent of some 350 ten-tonne trucks each tipping a full load of salt into the river every day. I believe that no issue is of more importance to this House or to the Australian community than the future viability of the River Murray. I urge all States to give up their parochial interests and urge the Commonwealth to indicate its total and unrestricted support to ensuring the preservation of our nation's most valuable resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address my remarks on the report of Estimates Commitee F to the appropriation for the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. I am sorry that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) is not in the House tonight when his Department's appropriation is being debated. I remind the Minister of two speeches I made in this House concerning the tariff on imported wheel-chairs. On 29 April I explained how the House put some imported wheel-chairs beyond the range of the average disabled person who is struggling to buy one. Again, on 2 June I joined my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) in calling for the tariff arrangements to be replaced with a bounty scheme to local producers. In this International Year of Disabled Persons I again urge the Government to introduce a bounty and to get rid of the tariff. If a bounty is good enough to help farmers buy tractors and superphosphates, it is good enough to help disabled people buy wheel-chairs. It is interesting to read the debate in Hansard of 2 June, page 2966 and to find that after the debate concluded the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs gave notice that he would introduce a Bill for an Act to provide for the payment of a bounty on the production of certain printed fabrics. Also he was to present a Bill for an Act to provide for the payment of a bounty on the production of certain textile yarns. While not opposing the introduction of either bounty, which cost the taxpayer approximately $75m, I ask the Minister: What do he and his Government have against the disabled? Why superphosphate, tractors, textile yarns and printed fabrics? Why not wheel-chairs for the disabled?

SPEECH.PARA: Disabled people are currently paying a tariff of 34 per cent on imported electric wheel-chairs. That is equivalent to approximately $1,000 on a chair. This is an enormous burden to place on people who are already disadvantaged by the necessity to have a wheel-chair. On top of the cost of $3,000 for an electric wheel-chair, it costs a disabled person $20 to $30 a week to maintain it. A wheel-chair in constant use lasts only a few years. The Government has indicated that the tariff will reduce to 20 per cent over two years, but I point out to the Minister that this is still 5 per cent higher than the tariff which existed prior to 1 January 1980. The decision on the tariff ignores the fact that there was a thriving wheel-chair industry in Australia when the tariff was only 15 per cent. It is obvious that the Government does not understand the problems faced by disabled people in obtaining aids for daily living. The Executive Director of the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled said that the Government had ignored the views of disabled people. ACROD, in its submission to the Industries Assistance Commission in 1980, indicated the massive cost of being disabled and recommended a bounty of 20 per cent on wheel-chairs.

Australia does manufacture a great variety of wheel-chairs, but mostly they are manufactured on a one-off basis. The Australian wheel-chairs are powered by two ordinary wet cell batteries. They are very heavy and many of them are not capable of being transported in the boot of a car. In contrast, the Omega chair, which looks more like a golf buggy than a conventional wheel-chair, is highly mobile, can be turned in limited areas such as in a lift, and its seat resembles that of a normal office chair. It can be rotated through 360 degrees so that it can be backed up to a table. The user can turn the seat through 180 degrees to sit at a table in a chair which looks very little different from a dining or conference chair. Furthermore, it is powered by a battery called a gel cell, which requires no maintenance, contains no acids and is the only battery which under international aircraft regulations can be carried aboard passenger aircraft.

The Omega wheel-chair is designed for use inside buildings. It is designed for persons who have some limited mobility. It is useful for travelling in hospitals, libraries, factories, large offices or outdoors in the garden. The heavier Australian wheel-chair is designed largely for outdoor use. It is heavier, sturdier and far less easy to transport. No similar or equivalent wheel-chair to the Omega is manufactured in Australia. Therefore, if the tariff were removed and a bounty substituted, we would not be creating unfair competition for Australian manufacturers.

In this International Year of Disabled Persons, about which Government members have spoken so much and done so very little, the removal of the tariff from these wheel-chairs would be a gesture appreciated by all Australians, not just by the disabled. The cost to the Government would be negligible. The wheel-chair industry would not suffer from the introduction of a bounty. I urge the Minister, even at this late date, to introduce a bounty for the wheel-chair industry. I point out to the Minister and Government members that disability is defined as the loss of bodily function. Handicap is man-made through our legislative, environmental and social barriers. Why does the Government not back up those disabled people who are wanting to import a wheel-chair? Why does it not support those people, introduce a bounty, remove the tariff and let disabled people choose whether they want an Australian manufactured wheel-chair or an imported wheel-chair, with no loss to either the disabled person or to the industry?

The two basic convictions on which the Government should have approached this matter are: Firstly, the needs of the wheel-chair user are of primary importance as a wheel-chair is a necessity, not a luxury; and, secondly, the existence of a viable Australian wheel-chair manufacturing industry is necessary to supply both standard and non-standard units to cater for specific disabilities. We also need an efficient, viable Australian wheel-chair manufacturing industry to provide an efficient maintenance and parts supply service. A bounty would attend to this and would also give some relief to disabled people. I think the Minister is unaware that the majority of disabled people, particularly young paraplegics, live on invalid pensions. One cannot buy very many imported wheel-chairs on an invalid pension.

I do not believe it is appropriate for disabled people to have to bear the cost of protecting the local industry. I believe it is a community and therefore a Government responsibility. The Government responsible for this is the Government that is introducing taxes on newspapers, books and pet food. It is the Government that is introducing taxes on clothing, building requirements and the screenings, bitumen, tar and other necessities of road construction. I suggest that it is about to go down in history as the Government that taxes wheel-chairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words relating to a matter which concerns the Department of National Development and Energy. I follow more or less what was said tonight by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher), who dealt with the Murray River area. My main concern is water resources throughout Australia. I do not think that the need for a water resources program can be overemphasised or that any resource is in greater need of development than are water resources within Australia. The honourable member for Mallee pointed out tonight, and it certainly has been pointed out in the House previously in recent days and weeks, that there is a very great problem with the Murray River. We can learn a lot from what has occurred over a century with the Murray. We have to appreciate that it takes in about one-seventh of Australia, draining not only areas of Victoria and New South Wales but also a part of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The area through which the river flows was settled in 1824 and ever since the river has been used for the purposes of irrigation, pleasure, generation of power and supplying water for domestic use. It has reached the stage at which it is basically worn out. We should learn a lesson from that. The Commonwealth and the States have a great responsibility to research and over the years to adopt a suitable program for water resources development in Australia. Possibly, there is no drier continent on earth. The rainfall around the continent is very varied indeed. Much of Australia is desert land, much is semi-arid land and, of course, we have agricultural land around the seaboard. We often hear people say that they are fed up with seeing so many millions of tonnes of water flowing daily into the sea. Most of the water resources development in Australia is basically a State responsibility. However I do not want to pin that responsibility entirely upon the States because I believe that the Commonwealth has a responsibility to co-ordinate the States so that over the years sufficient money will be set aside to look after the natural water resources throughout Australia. I am concerned that most of the States have in the works being undertaken by them no great regard for the consequences of those works in a national context. In my electorate of Lyne, on the New South Wales coastline and in the Hunter Valley area, often the need is emphasised for water for industry, water for domestic purposes and water for irrigation. Over many years many thousands of acres within the Hunter Valley have been irrigated by water from the Hunter River. Those farmers today are running short of water simply because of the demand by industry. How do we develop a general program covering all the river valleys within Australia which have a high concentration of agriculture, a growing concentration of industry and an increasing population? I advocate that we should accept our national responsibility for water resources and, with the States, try over the years to adopt a program that will meet the environmental demands of the people and the countryside, that will meet the demand for water for domestic, industrial and farming purposes.

In this country we are very dependent on the export of our primary industry products and the sale of our natural resources, such as coal and other minerals, is growing in importance. These industries require a great amount of water. I hope that, as we approach Australia's bicentenary, we will all place particular emphasis on improving Australia by protecting our important natural resources of water, soil and trees by undertaking a program of water management, soil conservation and tree planting throughout the continent. It is appropriate to look at this matter in the bicentenary year and accept some definite responsibilities for it. Water resource programs do return money to the people of Australia. In other words, they are a sound investment of public funds. This has been proved over the years in the returns so far as labour on the farms and in the industry are concerned, in the general profits that bring about the development of our countryside, and certainly in improving the standard of living of the Australian people. I often wonder whether we ought to take a page out of the book of America, or the other countries of the world who over the years have encouraged private enterprise to develop the water resources.

From the public point of view, in California and other American States one finds that over the years governments have encouraged private people and private companies to put many millions of dollars into water resource development around the countryside. One has only to go to the Westlands water district of California to see what can be done with the harnessing of snow waters, to see the tremendous production that has taken place in desert lands along the coast and inland over the years. If we are to meet our responsibilities in the years to come to feed not only our own people but also the people of the world, and particularly the Third World, we have to measure up now and do something about our water resources generally within Australia.

The 1980s is the appropriate time-due to the growth of the population, the growth in demand for goods produced in Australia, and the need to keep our standards of living high-to look upon water as gold. We cannot continue to let water flow into the sea. We cannot continue to allow our agricultural lands in dry farming areas to be affected by drought, in many instances not only without water for irrigation but also without water for stock and domestic purposes. I strongly urge the Government to join with the States to encourage, financially and in every way possible, the proper planning of water resources, to recognise the importance of water generally to Australia, to recognise that development is essential, to recognise that there is a very good return for the investment made, and at the same time to ensure the water supplies that are necessary today for all forms of industry.

In conclusion, it worries me that not only in the Budgets of the Commonwealth but also in the Budgets of all the States of Australia the emphasis on the productivity side of our industries is diminishing. We should encourage, financially and otherwise, development on the farms and in the mineral industries of Australia. We should encourage private enterprise to expand. There is a responsibility, I believe, for governments to look at the direction of the general funding in the Budgets and to see that a greater percentage of the taxpayers' money is spent on the sorts of development I have spoken about tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Estimates Committee F, which covered the Department of National Development and Energy, I raised the matter of the National Energy Office, and quoted from the Department's annual report, which described the role of the National Energy Office in relation to Loan Council approvals and the approval of infrastructure grants to the States for electricity authorities. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Energy Office is involved in the review of State proposals submitted for Loan Council approval and the provision of advice on future capital requirements and financing of electricity systems within Australia.

I suggest tonight that the Government, particularly through the Department of National Development and Energy, has now placed the country in a very serious situation with respect to electricity supply and particularly with respect to the pricing of electricity in this country, which in turn reflects the difficulties in terms of the cost structure of the electricity industry. I believe that this situation has arisen very much as a product of the enthusiasm-I think one would say the over-zealous enthusiasm-of the Government to get into the business of resource-based development and resource-based recovery.

What resource-based means, in effect, is that Australia's energy resources are to be exploited in various ways to enable exports of energy to take place and, it is hoped, through that process to improve the national income. In that enthusiasm the Government has been rather insensitive to some of the difficulties that might be involved. When one is talking about energy policy, or indeed any other aspect of policy, one has to recognise relationships. One of the industries that has been quite central to the Government's thinking and the Government's enthusiasm is the aluminium industry. As we all know, that industry has been taken on in this country as a major area of investment because the international companies believe that Australia will be able to supply cheap energy.

So we have had two parallel developments, one in the private sector and the other in the public sector, and they are both very closely related. In the private sector, a number of commitments have been made to establish aluminium smelters in particular in various sites around the country. Indeed, at the beginning of this year it was estimated that aluminium production would move from its current level of capacity of something like 369,000 tonnes per annum to a capacity by 1984 of 1,398,000 tonnes, or nearly 1.4 million tonnes. There was going to be a dramatic increase in aluminium production. Because aluminium is an energy-intensive industry which makes use of electricity power, there would also need to be a massive expansion of electricity generation across the country.

Over the last few years the Government has been encouraging the States to get into a dramatic increase in capital works in the electricity area and to build power stations around the country. Simultaneously, we had an increase in private investment in the aluminium industry, and we had the Commonwealth Government encouraging the States to move into the very rapid expansion of capital facilities for electricity generation right down the eastern coast of Australia and even extending to Western Australia, where smelters are also proposed. Clearly the Commonwealth Government has had a central role in this whole area. The Commonwealth Government is the Government that said recovery would be based on resources and on energy. It was the Commonwealth Government that went to the Loan Council in 1978 and encouraged the States to take out increased loans. We have had a dramatic increase over that period in infrastructure loans from the Commonwealth over and above the normal loan capacity.

Let me give some figures. From 1978 until this year we have moved from $150m to a figure very much higher than that-something like $800m. There has been a dramatic increase in the infrastructure loans that the States have been encouraged to get into over and above the considerable loan capacity that they have in general terms. I was surprised to find out in the Committee hearing that this has all taken place without any effective assessment by the Federal Government. I had the opportunity to question the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) about the basis on which the National Energy Office assessed the viability of the various projects to which loans were being directed. I was told both by an officer of the Department and by the Minister that our assessments, to quote Mr Ives, 'are related to the nature of the particular project that is proposed'. He said:
The question of its ultimate financial viability is a matter for the State Government which has put the proposal forward.
The Minister for Trade and Resources said:
We just accept a total figure-not a feasibility operation, but just a total capital figure for the program; that is what is presented to the Commonwealth.

So the Commonwealth in its enthusiasm for aluminium and electricity generation is encouraging the States to get into billions of dollars of investment for electricity generation. It has not done any assessment of the financial viability of the various projects. It has not, for example, even sought or tried to compel the States to reveal basic data such as the prices to be charged to the various companies which are seeking to secure access to Australian power. I think that has produced what is now a very critical situation. Since the beginning of this year we have seen a dramatic decline in the expected expansion of the aluminium industry. Whereas at the beginning of this year it was estimated that it would expand to 1.4 million tonnes by 1984, the revised forecast, if we remove Alcan at Bundaberg, take out Lochinvar, which was Alumax and now BHP, and take out Alcan expansion at Kurri Kurri, the figure comes down to 817,000 tonnes in 1984. The Portland smelter proposed by Alcoa has to be seen now as being in very considerable doubt. On the other hand, the electricity authorities have been grinding away getting into the most massive capital works projects in this country's history on the assumption that there will be a dramatic increase in aluminium production up to the kinds of figures that were being spoken about only 12 months ago.

This year the Commonwealth has got cold feet. It has said to the States: 'We really think that you are rushing into this electricity generation which a little while ago we were encouraging you to rush into. You will have to cut back on your loan programs. Indeed you will have to finance these capital works from your own revenues rather than through a loan'. What does that mean? According to a consultant report to which I referred earlier today, it means that if 50 per cent of the funds which it is necessary for these authorities to raise each year are raised internally then we can expect to see on top of the 40 per cent increase power prices in Victoria and New South Wales over the last 18 months another 50 per cent increase in electricity tariffs. That is all a result of the failure of the Federal Government, in my view, to plan effectively in an area of energy in which clearly it has a direct interest and in which, through the Loan Council, it has considerable powers. We are moving very dramatically into a situation where not only the motorist will be paying record high prices for petrol but also ordinary domestic consumers will be paying very high prices for electricity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confine my remarks this evening to the Department of Industry and Commerce. In particular, I would like to speak on behalf of several thousand constituents in my electorate of Isaacs who will be affected by decisions that will be taken by this Government in the near future in regard to the motor vehicle industry. I have received several thousand open letters from workers in my electorate, mainly in the automotive component parts side of the motor vehicle industry. The overall number of people affected in the bayside region of Melbourne could be around 7,000, that is, taking families into account. All of those people are concerned about their future and the future of their families. They have requested my assistance to urge the Government to keep the Australian motor vehicle industry strong and viable, to safeguard job opportunities for Australians and to encourage new investment in the industry. These letters have come from people who work for companies in my electorate and from others who reside in the electorate. Companies such as Yazaki, Lucas Industries, Nylex, Kaufmann, Dorman, Repco, Patons Brake Replacements and Bosch have also been in touch with me in regard to this vital question of tariff protection for the industry. Of course, all of these companies are component parts manufacturers in the bayside region of Melbourne. I sincerely hope that the Government will take heed of these petitions.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of all of my constituents, I now put forward a few points for consideration. Australia needs to continue with the existing 80-20 quota system or replace it only with a system that ensures 80 per cent of the market for Australian production. Australia's local content plan must also continue. At present this represents 85 per cent of the market. Australia's automotive component parts industry employs many tens of thousands of people. They cannot be pushed aside by the thrust of an increasing amount of imports into the country. However, we on this side of the House believe that a rationalisation of the industry over a number of years must take place. It must take place in consultation with the industry because we must strive to become more competitive. This can occur through research, technology, better planning, better management and greater productivity. Standardisation of parts is another likely step that would help the industry and make it more economic and competitive.

However, one thing which troubles me is the number of vehicle manufacturers. Five vehicle manufacturers are too many. I believe a country the size of Australia in population and economy can find room for only three at the most. However, above all else, the changes that I have mentioned must be part of a co-ordinated, managed change to benefit the Australian motor vehicle industry and the tens of thousands of people who work in that industry. The human and social elements of any decision that the Government may make must be very carefully considered. When one stands in front of hundreds of people to tell them that their jobs and their futures are at stake one suddenly realises the real human tragedy that could occur if the Government was to pander to one section of the industry or to foreign corporations at the expense of thousands whose whole futures may be put at risk by such a decision. The motor vehicle industry is the base of our manufacturing industry. We need to strengthen it, not dismantle it. Our manufacturing industry needs to be strengthened in order to assist with the massive task of supplying jobs for Australians in the future.

During a debate on a matter of public importance on 15 September this year the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) estimated that Australia would require two and a half million jobs in the 1980s to keep pace with the expanding work force and ease the unemployment situation in the country. However, although our manufacturing industry will not be able to supply all of those jobs, a strong and viable industry is needed to create its share of employment for the future. I wish to quote from that debate on 15 September. In proposing the matter of public importance regarding the motor vehicle industry the honourable member for Adelaide said:

Any reasonable Australian can see that the motor vehicle industry and the component parts manufacturers in that industry are very important to this country. I strongly urge the Government to take up and consider very carefully the points that I have raised tonight. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take up the matters raised by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe) concerning the restrictions and constraints on State infrastructure as a result of the so-called acceleration in the resource development program or resource development boom. Very great constraints are being made on public infrastructure. I am of the opinion that some State governments and even sections of the Labor movement do not seem to realise that economic benefits and disadvantages are involved in all of this. For instance, it is well known that the present Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) decided at the last Loan Council meeting in June to restrain the infrastructure borrowing program for this financial year. However, power developments alone in three States already have a committed borrowing capacity over the next five to six years of some $9,000m, not taking into account projects that have been rejected at this stage, such as the Bunbury coal-fired power station in Western Australia at a cost of $700m or projects that might yet be submitted, such as the hydro-electric schemes in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned that as the infrastructure borrowing program blows out to service this so-called resource development boom the disadvantage will be seen as follows: The borrowing programs and the State semi-government authorities and larger authorities have increased over the last three years by some 15 per cent, yet the general purpose capital borrowing programs have declined by some 30 per cent over the same period and the local government borrowing programs have declined by at least 10 per cent. So there is the disadvantage there.

I am very concerned also with two other aspects. The first relates to employment. We on the Opposition benches are not at all convinced that the employment prospects in this area about which the Government talks are anywhere near as rosy as they are purported to be. For instance, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs says that to 1986 only 60,000 permanent jobs will be available in this mining and minerals processing area. The Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research of the University of Melbourne gives an even lower figure of 40,000. Even if we are very generous, applying a multiplier factor of some three to one, we can see that no more than 180,000 permanent jobs will be provided in this area up to 1986. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs estimates that we would need to create up to 130,000 jobs a year until 1986 just to keep unemployment at its present level. That is 650,000 new jobs. The Government is to provide 180,000 jobs from resource development. I invite the House to draw its own conclusions as to the contribution towards total employment that we can expect from resource development. This is not to put an argument against per se; we need rationalised development not only to cater for minerals processing and mining but also to preserve, expand and service the manufacturing sector and to preserve jobs in the export rural competing sector.

I wish now to turn to a question directed by me to the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) at the Estimates Committee hearing. It related to the Imhausen study into coal to oil technology. It is self-explanatory. I said to the Minister:

These projects will require large water resources, electricity resources, and coal resources. Given the present state of competition between the States in their attempts to attract such projects with the connotations for capital requirements and possible damage to the environment and so on, if we get too far down this track by allowing this State competition situation to continue, will the Federal Government be concerned to determine an order for the development of the projects, particularly in environmentally sensitive areas, such as the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, or will it simply take a sort of free market approach and let State governments and the companies and consortiums concerned run the state of play, at least up to the assessment stage?
The Minister replied:
We will be leaving it entirely to the States to determine the priorities.
I asked why that was so in light of the resources that are going to be used, financial and material. He said:
You tell me what authority the Commonwealth has to do otherwise.
I said:
You have other instruments.
He replied:
You tell me.

He did not know. I ask the House: What sort of reaction is that from a Federal Minister and a Federal Government? A coal to oil plant producing 50,000 barrels of oil a day, using 10 million tonnes of coal at a cost of $1 billion would consume a very large quantity of electricity. If we were to produce from coal as much oil as we now get from Bass Strait we would need to double Australian black coal production-that is if we used black coal for feedstock. What I am getting at is that, despite the vast demands on financial and material resources that these projects and other resource development projects will make, the Minister is really saying that the Commonwealth will leave it up to the companies, both national and transnational, and to State governments to make the decisions and then we will have to live with the economic consequences. That is what it is saying. That is the sort of irrational economic behaviour that is leading us into the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you trust the States?

—I think there has to be some sort of overall rationalisation. The Government is looking at a situation, both economic and environmental, in which the States will be coming to the Commonwealth and asking it, through the Loan Council, for money to provide the infrastructure. There will be both economic benefits and disadvantages.
—Don't you trust Wran?

—Honourable members opposite were talking about a blow-out of the Loan Council borrowing program. I remind them that their own Prime Minister rejected the application by the Court Government in Western Australia for borrowing approval to obtain funds to build a $600m coal-fired station at Bunbury in Western Australia to service the Reynolds aluminium smelter that now does not look like going ahead. I am simply putting to this Parliament an argument for rationalisation and sanity in these matters. There is only so much money in the economic washbasin, so to speak, to go around and if we put it all into this area it will be the social areas that will be disadvantaged. I turn now to a situation that I think is scandalous. Despite the fact that this financial year we are getting $3.3 billion in oil revenue, only $15m has been allocated for research into alternative liquid fuels. Over the last three years the Government, despite vast sums from oil revenue, has invested only $4.2 billion in ethanol research and $536,000 in research into obtaining methanol from natural gas.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by drawing to the attention of the House the continuing scandal of the Fortescue oil field. There are 280 million barrels of oil in this field in Bass Strait. On the advice of the Bureau of Mineral Resources the Government classified it as new oil-that is, oil discovered after 1975. The Bureau of Mineral Resources made that recommendation on the advice of Esso-BHP. I wish to put on record that that is not a new field at all, but part of the old Halibut-Cobia field. By classifying it as new oil this Government is forgoing between $1.5 billion and $2 billion in revenue which could be gained through resource rent taxation or by application of the present oil levy policy. After paying $3.3 billion in company tax it will be left with almost $4 billion, and this should clearly be subject to a levy just as old oil is at present. This figure should be subject to a resources tax or the current oil levy policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest to the House that it have a general debate covering this Bill, the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Tertiary Education Commission-report and summary of recommendations for triennium 1982-84 as they are associated measures.
