SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the prime piece of legislation we are debating is the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill which provides funds for the next triennium to universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions around Australia. However, there are some major new provisions included in that legislation. The first of those is the attempt by the Government to impose tertiary tuition fees in respect of students studying for second or higher degrees. The other major new part of this legislation is to effect the amalgamations of certain colleges of advanced education which flow from the report of the razor gang. However, neither this legislation nor any of its major initiatives do anything to solve the serious problems besetting tertiary education in this country. There are some consequential Bills which flow from the decision of the Government to impose tertiary tuition fees. They are the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill to amend the CCAE Act and the Australian National University Amendment Bill (No. 2) to amend the ANU Act. The major provisions of those two Bills give the governing bodies of those two institutions the power to impose fees in accordance with the determination made by the Minister for Education.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to indicate from the outset what the Opposition intends to do in respect of this legislation. In the first instance, I will at a later time be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill in terms which I will refer to later. Secondly, we will be opposing outright clause 6 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill, that being the clause which seeks to give power to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) to determine fees for certain classes of students in universities and the colleges of advanced education. We will oppose outright the CCAE Amendment Bill because that Bill simply seeks to give to that institution power to charge and collect fees. In relation to the ANU Amendment Bill we will be opposing those clauses which seek to give power to the governing body in respect of the charging of fees in relation to certain students.

Of course, it is not our intention to hold up the passage of this legislation. We are as concerned as anyone to see that the money which will be appropriated by the States grants legislation flows through to the universities, colleges and TAFE institutions around Australia. However, the point that we make and will continue to make both here and in another place is that it is vitally important that clause 6 of the States grants legislation and any consequential pieces of legislation be vigorously opposed. The reasons for opposing them are quite simply these: The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) said specifically before the last Federal election that the Government was not considering any proposals in relation to the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees. There is no doubt what the Minister meant by that. There is no doubt what the Minister intended people to understand by that remark. He wanted to assure people who were concerned about the question of tertiary tuition fees that the Liberal-National Country Party, if re-elected, would not reintroduce tertiary tuition fees. However, a few months later the Government took a decision to reintroduce tertiary tuition fees in respect of certain classes of students. It is a direct breach of a promise. That is why we will be opposing that particular legislation.

We believe we have every right to use any legislative or parliamentary mechanism to oppose any provision which breaches an undertaking given by the Government prior to an election. Of course, the Minister could take the view taken by his representative at a meeting at the ANU a few days ago. Senator Teague said then that he was empowered by the Minister for Education to give an undertaking to the gathering that the Government had no intention of reintroducing fees for first degree students. When somebody in the audience interjected to the effect that that was what the Minister and the Government had said in respect of all tertiary tuition fees prior to the last election, Senator Teague simply said: 'Oh, but that was an undertaking given in the context of an election campaign'. That is, Senator Teague was saying that it is quite all right to tell lies during an election campaign. Nobody expects any undertaking or promise given by this Government to be honoured. We will ensure that we keep the Government to its promise and that it is not able to reintroduce tertiary tuition fees in any respect as a result of this legislation.

The Government has to recognise that the fate of this legislation is absolutely in its hands. If it is sufficiently intransigent not to accept any amendments which might be passed in another place, amendments designed to keep this Government honest, to keep it to its election promises, it will be entirely on its head if the funds appropriated for universities and CAEs dry up at the end of this year, as they will unless this legislation is passed in the near future. It will not be our fault. It will not be Senate's fault. It will be this Government's intransigence, its refusal to be kept to an election undertaking given prior to the general election last year. The Minister has to realise that he is now considered to be an unreliable Minister. People now recognise that they cannot trust him because the undertaking he gave before the last election has been breached. It does not matter what he says about his intentions and those of the Government in relation to fees in the future for other classes of students. No one will believe him. No one should believe him because he is unreliable, he has been caught out, and he has told a lie.

Another point that has to be made is that the Government is intent with this legislation on re-establishing the principle of tertiary tuition fees. It is intent on re-establishing a fee collecting mechanism. That is what this legislation is all about. That is why we are intent on opposing it. If this Government were successful in re-establishing the principle of fees for students studying for second or higher degrees and if it were successful in forcing universities and CAEs to re-establish a fee collecting network, it would be a quite simple matter for it in the future, without much fuss or bother, to extend the application of fees to include a vast array of other classes of students. That reason, if no other, is sufficient for us to oppose vigorously the reintroduction of fees. It is not just a question of the impact of fees on the admittedly relatively small group of students to whom they apply; it is the question of preventing the re-establishment of a principle which this Government would have no hesitation in extending to include other groups.

The Government and this Minister are simply playing up to a small rump on the back bench which believes fervently in the idea that tertiary tuition fees should be charged universally. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) is probably the ringleader of this group, but there are plenty of others whom one could name and with whom I have debated this matter both in and out of the House. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) is one of them. Those honourable members take the view that it is important to re-establish tertiary tuition fees for everybody. They believe that there is at the moment a bias in favour of the sons and daughters of the rich amongst those who are currently attending universities and CAEs. That goes without saying. The social composition of the student population of tertiary institutes is heavily biased in favour of the sons and daughters of the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —The abolition of fees was supposed to overcome that but it hasn't worked.

—The honourable member for Casey points to the fact that one of the prime reasons why the Labor Government at the beginning of the 1974 academic year abolished tertiary tuition fees and introduced a means-tested living allowance was to produce, in the words of the then Minister, ' a revolution of access'. In a small way that occurred. One of the ways in which it occurred, which the honourable member for Casey probably does not realise, is that there has been in the intervening period a vast explosion in the number of mature age students who have either returned to or commenced tertiary studies mainly because of the absence of tertiary fees. It is my suggestion that many of those people would not have had the opportunity to attend universities or CAEs at the age when it is normal to do so simply because of the existence of fees. For that group at least there has been a substantial opening of opportunities for tertiary education.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing which I dare say the honourable member for Casey overlooks is that there have been vastly changed economic circumstances between 1974 and the present. Nobody knows what would have happened to tertiary enrolments or to the social composition of tertiary institutions had fees remained. My suggestion is that had fees remained during times of much more stringent economic circumstances very many fewer children from poorer and middle income families would have been able to make it to universities or CAEs. I think it goes without saying that the abolition of fees from the beginning of the 1974 academic year has had a substantial effect in opening up educational opportunities for a vast number of people in the community.

What the proponents of fees cannot indicate is that the imposition of fees would in any way assist in opening up opportunities in this area. Certainly, in the short term it would not. My guess is that in the short term it would have a very deleterious effect and the net result would be to scare off a vast number of potential enrolments. Their theory, of course, is that if fees are charged to those students whose parents can afford to pay them we can use the revenue so gained to make it easier for the kids from lower and middle income families to get to universities or CAEs. But if they do their sums and work out how much revenue actually would be gained from the imposition of fees at the level at which they are now proposed they will see that it would be insufficient to improve the opportunities for most of the people whom they, if we can take them at face value, seek to help. Already we know that the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance is so insufficient as to deter a number of would-be entrants into tertiary education. The first objective which has to be satisfied is the improvement of the financial support available to students. I do not hear any of the proponents of the reintroduction of fees talking of improving the TEAS allowance and the availability of financial support to students.

That is the first matter that has to be addressed. Another is that the proponents of tertiary education fees seem to ignore the fact that the main reason why we do not get enough people into tertiary institutions and the main reason why the social mix is so biased is that so few children get to the end of secondary school. That is another problem which they fail to address, a problem that simply would not be solved by the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees. We ought to be implementing the sorts of policies which would encourage more and more of the kids who enter secondary schools to complete secondary schooling, meet the conditions for tertiary admission and proceed to some sort of tertiary study. Under this Government the exact reverse has happened. For the first time in over 25 years there has been an increasing dropout rate amongst people in secondary school. Fewer are getting to the end, and of those who get to the end fewer are going on directly to some form of full time tertiary study.

None of those serious problems which confront us in terms of the policy for tertiary education are in any way alleviated-I suggest that they are greatly exacerbated-by the imposition of tertiary tuition fees generally. It is not just that we are interested in opposing these fees for the group of students who will have to pay them. We are opposed to the re-establishment of the principle of tertiary tuition fees in general. That, I repeat, is what the Government is really interested in. It is not interested in the relatively small amount which it will get, which the institutions will get, as a result of the imposition of fees. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 intends to appropriate something like $1,865m for colleges, universities and technical and further education institutions around Australia. The Government says that in the next calendar year it will get no more than $8m as a result of the imposition of fees. Even that, I suggest, is an extraordinarily optimistic estimate. The Government has said that before June next year the institutions will get $4m from the fees and that they would get another $4m in the second half of the calendar year 1982.

I do not know whether the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) was struck with a bout of honesty this afternoon. He said in the Senate this afternoon that only 4,000 students would be paying fees next year. As the maximum fee which it is proposed will be payable under this legislation is $1,000, that suggests that a maximum of $4m would be gained in the whole of next year as a result of the imposition of these fees. I suspect that Senator Carrick is far closer to the mark. I suspect that the Government, as I said, has probably doubled the amount it is likely to get as a result of the imposition of a $1,000 fee on students. Perhaps there is another reason for Senator Carrick's candour. Senator Carrick has always been an opponent of tertiary tuition fees. When the reintroduction of fees was first suggested in 1976 he went to battle to prevent the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees in any form. Perhaps his revised estimate of the revenue from this proposal is simply an acknowledgement of his overall opposition to the proposal.

There are other reasons why the fee proposal ought to be opposed. It is an attempt quite selectively to penalise those students who are least able to pay. Let us look particularly at the plight of post-graduate students. A small number of post-graduate students receive Commonwealth or university awards. The amounts that they receive are very stingy indeed. They are scarcely enough to keep body and soul together. Yet those are the ones who are exempt from fees. The ones who receive nothing-the post-graduate students who are supporting themselves-are to be singled out for a selective $1,000 a year penalty because they want to proceed with some form of post-graduate studies.

This is grossly unfair. It take no account of the needs of those studients or their ability to pay. It overlooks entirely the enormous contribution which post-graduate students are making to the vital research effort which is being made, particularly in universities around this country. It also ignores the fact that, over the last few years, opportunities for employment of post-graduate students have declined substantially. There are far fewer part time or full time tutorships and part time demonstrator or full time demonstrator positions available in universities and colleges. That is largely because of the substantial cutbacks in recurrent funding which have been visited upon these institutions. Those have been the areas in which the most drastic cutbacks in staff numbers have occurred in recent times. TALK.START.PARA: —The other issue which is raised quite directly by this legislation is the question of amalgamations. The House will remember that, as a result of the decision of the razor gang and the Government's acceptance of its report, something like 30 colleges were earmarked for closure by the beginning of next year. Rather I should say that they were to have their funding discontinued unless they were able to come forward or unless State governments were able to come forward with acceptable amalgamation proposals in respect of those colleges. I think that we are entitled to suspect that some sort of conspiracy is being waged against advanced education. During the last decade there was an enormous expansion in the advanced education sector. The future of many of those colleges is certainly under a cloud; that is, the darlings of the 1970s-the CAEs-have become the demons of the 1980s. I think that either we put that down to a conspiracy being waged against the advanced education sector or we put it down to incompetence on the part of this Government. The latter explanation is probably the more likely, especially when one considers the role of the razor gang in bringing about this reversal of the fortunes of these colleges.

SPEECH.PARA: Who in their right mind, after all, would put the future of education, or anything else for that matter, in the hands of two titled accountants, two half-smart lawyers and a farmer? Their decisions may well have been applauded by titled accountants, half-smart lawyers and farmers but they have offended almost everyone else. It was the razor gang which decided that 30 colleges should cease to exist. Of couse, it was responsible also for decisions in relation to tertiary tuition fees. It is likely that most people who were involved in the college sector recognised that some form of reorganisation was not only inevitable but desirable. In 1973, when 43 teacher colleges achieved CAE status, pressures were unleashed which were clearly going to impact upon the whole sector. With the emergence of a surplus of teachers in the mid-1970s and the subsequent reduced intake in teacher education courses the call for reorganisation became more persistent.

In the event this process of reorganisation has been clearly botched by this Government. It is hard to imagine how this could have been done in a worse way. Any reorganisation or consolidation, to use the Government's expression, in the college sector should aim to achieve beneficial educational objectives which would include, at least, the maintenance of overall educational opportunities, an increase in the diversity of courses and the recognition of the separate educational approaches pursued by different colleges. As well, there was a need to recognise the sensitive questions of morale and interpersonal relationships which are essential to the success of any educational activity. Of course, there is the related question of employment security which has so far received little, if any, attention from the Federal Government. Indeed, the Minister is on record as saying that he is not the least bit concerned about the problem of redundancy which will result in colleges as a result of the consolidation. He has said in an Estimates Committee that this is clearly a problem for State governments and for the institutions themselves.

The question of educational objectives could not have been further from the mind of the Minister or the Government in respect of the current exercise. The starting point, apparently, was the notion that if there were fewer colleges some savings would be made in recurrent expenditure. Even in the view of the TEC these savings may be illusory. The Commission has said that 'significant economies are unlikely in the short to medium term'. In its most recent report the TEC has gone even further to say that it fails to see where the sorts of savings which the Government is demanding can, in fact, be made without substantial reductions in the quality of offerings in those colleges and in other colleges and, indeed, in universities around the country. The Commission believes that there may be economies of scale to be gained from the establishment of larger institutions. This is based clearly on unreliable evidence, to say the least. However, having established that fewer CAEs was a desirable end in itself, the razor gang and the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —After years of massive injections of funds into education-the taxpayer now spends $20m a day on all forms of education in Australia-and especially the injection of funds into tertiary education, it is ironic that the result has been the mixture of sometimes repellant and shameless self-interest and of frequent bad argument from academic circles and their parliamentary allies that we have heard in criticism of these Bills in the past couple of weeks and supported tonight by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins). Let us take the argument over the consolidation of resources in higher education and, in particular, the decision to close the engineering school at Deakin University. In the propaganda associated with the National Day of Protest, which would be better called the National Day of Absurdity or the National Day of Academic Betrayal of Academic Values, we read the Federation of Australian Universities Staff Associations' statement which appeared in the Canberra Times of 13 October. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of university autonomy-the independence of universities from day-to-day political interference-is an important one which safeguards the role of a university in a democratic society.

Who would disagree with that? It continues by saying that universities expect that 'they will be left to make the academic decisions-such as what is taught, and by whom'. Then, of course, in the decision to close the engineering school at Deakin University this principle is fundamentally breached. The fact is that, obviously and plainly-it is almost quaint to have to mention it-there is not the slightest, faintest shadow of a suggestion that engineering be not taught. It is taught, need one say, in various colleges and universities in Victoria and in the other States. There is not the faintest, slightest shadow of a suggestion by government as to how it should be taught. There is not the faintest, slightest shadow of a suggestion by government as to who should teach it. These are academic decisions. What is suggested is that where public money is used, government has a right and a duty to see that it is not wasted and that there is not a wasteful proliferation of engineering schools.

THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW
Wednesday, October 14, 1981
The decline of the universities

The deterioration in the standard of intellectual honesty in Australian universities could hardly have been better demonstrated than by yesterday's National Day of Protest against the Federal Government's spending cuts in the tertiary sector and in particular the decision to close the engineering school at Victoria's Deakin University.

Such a decline in academic standards was, of course, predicted by the late Professor John Anderson, of the University of Sydney, who frequently during his long and unpopular career there as Professor of Philosophy warned that the increasing dependence of the universities on public funding, and their consequent assimilation into the public sector would determine their intellectual integrity.

It is now clear that the universities in their approach to the question of public funding have no longer any integrity to defend. They act purely as a special interest lobby, ignoring any considerations of principle. This was immediately apparent when the last Federal Budget proposed to levy fees for some (not all) tertiary students, already in possession of first degrees.

At the time two of the members of the select group of Vice-Chancellors (unique among public servants in that their salaries are not public knowledge) were trained economists of considerable reputation. These two were both well acquainted with the economic arguments for charging fees, and yet at no time did they express any disagreement with the abusive approach of the Vice-Chancellors to what was a relatively unimportant, but economically justifiable, proposal.

Perhaps the non-economist members of the brotherhood of Vice-Chancellors could be forgiven for not understanding the economic issues. But to the extent that they endorse the advertisement of the Federation on of Australian University Staff Associations they justify all of John Anderson's worst fears.

This advertisement was headed ''Political interference in universities.'' Far from dealing with any attempt by any government to sponsor or censor any particular view in the universities the matter in question is whether the Federal Government should continue to finance a school of engineering at Deakin University. The maintenance of a school of engineering at the fourth university in the Melbourne-Geelong area, which would involve wasteful duplication of facilities, has nothing to do with any genuine concept of academic freedom.

No-one is proposing that engineering should not be taught; it is taught at the tertiary level in a number of institutions in the area. No one is proposing that the way engineering should be taught should be interfered with, nor that the teaching personnel should be influenced. The issue is whether it makes any sense to have a number of small, fragmented engineering schools. It is obviously to the advantage of academics that there should be a proliferation of schools, but it is not obviously to the benefit of the community. It is positively deleterious to genuine scholarship.

There is, in fact, not a very strong case to be made for the existence of Deakin University at all. It was a marginal proposition even in the days of lavish expenditure on tertiary education, and could today well be amalgamated with other tertiary institutions or simply abolished. Far from being political interference in any real sense this would be simply a rational economising on government expenditure.

The universities should never forget that they are spending funds extracted from the community as a whole. Only a minor part of their expenditure comes from revenue deriving from their own property, and even this is subsidised by the way of taxation concessions by the Government. As such the universities do not have, and cannot have, autonomy when it comes to their demands upon public funds, nor do they have an unqualified right to decide that a little bit of engineering is preferable to, say, more philosophy.

The university argument on academic freedom when it comes to public funds is a phony one. There are too many material interests, too much personal interests, as against the abstract principle of free inquiry, involved. It is clear, for example, that university libraries have been starved in recent years to maintain academic salary progression, establishments and study leave. But the library, far more than idividual staff members, is the core of a university. If any economies are needed they should come first on the teaching staff side and last of all on the library. Yet the reverse has happened.

There is considerable scope for argument on the academic priorities which should prevail within a university. These arugments can be conducted partly in economic terms and partly in terms of the importance of free, unfettered intellectual endeavour.

However, it is of interest that neither the economists nor the philosophers are being much consulted in the present noisy political campaign against the Government. Instead the university staff are conducting themselves with the indifference to rational argument one would expect of a highly inefficient, protected and declining industry.

As a trade union, involved in adversary politics and bargaining with their employer, the Government, this is understandable enough as far as the university staff associations are concerned. They have for a long time put sectional interest above intellectual principle. In this they reflect the worst features of the Australian community of which they are a part.

Nor does it much matter when the Senate of the University of Sydney declares itself ''unwilling'' to collect fees as proposed by the Federal Government. All the Government has to do is to cut the university's funding by a corresponding sum.

But it is a very serious matter when the Vice-Chancellors, who represent the pinnacle of university administration and who are responsible for the protection of genuine academic independence, are unable to distinguish between this and a sordid squabble over funds. But John Anderson would not have been surprised-Vice Chancellors were not much better in his day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I agree with the honourable member for Fremantle, who isolated the principal issues of the Bill. A principal issue in these Bills, which has also been put into controversy, is fees for post-graduate degrees. We all know that fees were abolished to encourage students from poorer families to attend universities and that it has not had this result. On the whole, students from better-off families are still the main ones attending universities but now they are funded by the taxes of lower paid workers. Nevertheless that system is to remain and will be modified only in a small way by the reintroduction of fees for post-graduate students enrolling next year, excluding students who will be doing a recognised double degree and students receiving post-graduate awards. Obviously those who are not now receiving awards, who cannot afford to pay fees, must have arrangements made so that by scholarships or loans they are not prevented from doing post-graduate degrees, if that is their wish and if they have the capacity to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The sooner these arrangements are announced the better. But it is an entirely different thing to say that people who can afford to contribute a small amount-less than 20 per cent-to the cost of their post-graduate education and who are moving into well-paid professions should be funded into those jobs by the taxes of everyone else, including those of the lower paid workers. The argument against post-graduate fees is one for taxing the poor to benefit the rich. I think the honourable member for Fremantle recognises that although, for reasons that I cannot understand, he quibbled about accepting the simple facts. This has been recognised and stated for years by economists and commentators of all kinds. In Australia one can refer for brevity to the 1977 report of the Butcher Committee on Student Loans or the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment. But again we get specious arguments from the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations and others in the coalition of militant and selfish vested interests. In its statement of 12 October the Federation said that there should not be any fees or any small contribution, not even 20 per cent, toward the costs of post-graduate students because:
Society at large benefits from a better-educated population and a diversity of interests and skills within the community.

Of course that is true. Society does benefit from a better educated population. That is why it spends $20m of taxes a day on education. The point is we would be justified in spending public money on these post-graduate students to the extent that the benefit to society they bring is greater than is indicated by their earnings. Obviously the rewards to doctors, lawyers, engineers and senior public servants with specialist post-graduate degrees are very great. No case is made that they are not more than adequate. If this is not the case, as it may not be with, for example, teachers or clergymen, there is a case for scholarships or loans for students who are working towards these positions, but not for taxing the poor to enrich the rich even further, as the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, the honourable member for Fremantle, the Labor Party and even some vice-chancellors maintain. I say some, but not all, because it is well known that vice-chancellors who are economists tend to take a different view from other vice-chancellors. Professor Bruce Williams was well known for his view that universities are better off when they live on fees rather than government grants because living off fees enhances the atmosphere and the fact of independence.

I hope that the reintroduction of fees on this very limited scale is accompanied soon by announcements of a new system of post-graduate scholarships for those in need and/or a system of student loans. Student loans are not part of this Bill but they are inevitably associated with the reintroduction of fees for post-graduate students. This idea has certainly been in the air and investigated for many years past. One of the problems that always comes up is that of finding a workable scheme in a sense of one that will ensure repayment, one that deals with defaulting. It does not take much acquaintance with the apostles of the new morality developed in the 'Me Decade' to understand that many of them would make a virtue of dodging repayment.

In the United States I understand that under one of the loan schemes-National Direct Student Loans-the default rate is a shocking 11.9 per cent. In other schemes it is far lower. Of course in any scheme one has to allow for difficult- ies of repayment by graduates who, for example, are unemployed or married. In this respect I draw the House's attention to the solution offered in the submission by Professor Richard Blandy to the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment. His submission was published as Appendix E to the Committee's report. He advocated an Australian Student Finance Scheme to administer student loans and recommended that repayment be made through a surcharge on income tax payable by graduates up to the total amount of the loan. If a former student is unemployed or without income for some reason, he does not begin repayments. If employed and paying income tax he begins repayments, the instalments being administered by the Commissioner of Taxation. This seems a simple solution worthy of consideration. In any case, I hope that a new scholarship scheme and a student loan scheme for those who need them will soon be put in place.

In conclusion, since I want to be brief at this hour, I quickly welcome the additional funding of 6 per cent in this legislation for technical and further education. TAFE enrolments are rising and TAFE has new responsibilities in the important School to Work Transition Program and a greater role to play in the educational system of Australia. It has been the poor relation for too long and something now is being done to remedy this and this is good news. With the qualifications made, I welcome these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seconded the amendment moved by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) but I shall concentrate on the question dealt with by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) in the last part of his speech; that is, the introduction of fees for second degree new enrolees after 1982. I do so both on the grounds of a personal analysis of the effects of that legislation and out of a small degree of what I consider affilial duty as the reforms in the area of tertiary education and fee charging were introduced in the course of the Labor Government by a Minister who is my father. I think that this proposal can be criticised at several levels. The first is that it is a breach of an electoral promise. Electoral promises have a degree of flexibility these days which defies even the depredations of principle that were inflicted at the turn of the century by characters such as William Morris Hughes. Nevertheless there ought to be sufficient interest in this Parliament in the value of the democratic process, and the assumption that when people go to the polls at election time they basically have a reasonable idea of what they can expect from the various contestants, that when specific undertakings are made, unless there is really excellent reason, those undertakings are in fact held to. There were, of course, very good reasons why, for example, Franklin Delano Roosevelt did not hold to his promises in the 1940 election campaign that he would not involve American forces in Europe. The reason of course was the survival of the democratic liberties of all the United States allies and the bulk of the rest of the world. In those circumstances it was probably a reasonable electoral promise to break.

SPEECH.PARA: There are probably two circumstances in which certain economic promises are made, when crises occur in the international economic system or the domestic economy which do not permit a tax reform or some other proposition put forward by a successful party at election time to be carried out. However, by no stretch of the imagination could those categories be seen to apply to this broken promise. This broken promise will produce absolutely nothing for the Treasury. The broken promise is not brought about by an urgent situation requiring the attention of the Government that could not be dealt with, if the Government wished to deal with it, at a subsequent election when an alternative promise to that put forward could be made.

The breach of electoral trust involved in the failure by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) to stick to commitments that he made during his election campaign, albeit a small matter, is nevertheless one contribution to the production of an even higher level of cynicism about politicians and political promises and, ultimately, the democratic system, which seems to be increasingly prevalent in the Australian community today. The Bill also represents a step away from an important principle, namely, that in a humane and democratic community the only criterion for access to any level of education should be the capacity to pursue the qualifications sought. This principle should irrespective of the social composition of the student body at any point in time and at any level of the educational process.

When we introduced free tertiary education in this country, we talked of a revolution in access. Speakers on both sides of this House have conceded that no revolution in access has occurred. After all, it is only six or seven years since free tertiary education was introduced. In terms of changing the social composition of major educational institutions, such a scheme should be given longer than six or seven years in which to work. There is evidence that the process which it was claimed, would be revolutionary is nevertheless occurring at an evolutionary rate in the social statistics of tertiary education students now. There is no question that, whilst universities and colleges of advanced education remain the preserve of the middle classes, dents are being made in that preserve because of this legislation and the accompanying legislation on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially by mature age students.

—They are being made especially by mature age students. If we are talking about revolutions of access, it is probably more justifiable to talk of it in these terms: A dramatic change has taken place in the sex composition of the student bodies in tertiary institutions, both universities and colleges of advanced education. In particular, there has been a substantial increase in the numbers of women attending universities. In the late 1960s I attended a university in Western Australia, the student body population of which comprised 66 per cent men and 34 per cent women. Before coming to this place I taught in a new university in the same State, where the student body comprised 50 per cent men and 50 per cent women. That is a substantial change, a change not to be sneezed at and a change which is a direct product of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument has been put forward by the honourable member for Wentworth and other honourable members opposite that students ought to be charged fees because universities and colleges of advanced education are essentially composed of middle class students and the burden of tax in this country falls on low income groups. The burden of tax falls on low income groups largely as a result of the policies of this Government. However, I will leave that aside at the moment and examine the validity of that argument per se. No honourable member on this side of the House questions the accuracy of that statement. We merely point out, first, that the situation is changing and, secondly, that the solution to the problem that is sought by this Government will not produce the sort of change that one might expect persons expressing that sort of objection would want to see brought about.

No suggestion has been made by this Government, or by any Government supporter that I am aware of, that the entirety of the cost of tertiary education should be borne by students. The suggestion that I have seen is that this charge now to be levied on second degree students should be levied on students across the board; in other words, that students across the board on an average basis, should pay 20 per cent of their education costs. What will be the result of this legislation? It will not make a dime of difference to the fact that the low income earners in Australia bear a heavy burden of education expenditure by virtue of the fact that they pay the bulk of the taxes and they do not attend universities. All it means is that, via their taxes they will continue to pay for 80 per cent of university education. If a few of them actually get into a situation in which they might be able to benefit from a university education, they will be hit with a charge currently of $1,000 a year for the privilege of being able to do so. Therefore, having been excluded by all the many social factors from opportunities for tertiary education, when they actually arrive at the point at which they could take advantage of tertiary education they will be denied access to it.

If we take the user pays principle even further, if we take it aside from, say, an arts course for which the average cost per student might be $3,000 or $4,000 a year, and through to the average cost of a medical student at $15,000 a year, the situation is even more ludicrous. In those circumstances that working class person would be paying for $14,000 worth of a $15,000 education and would then be obliged to confront a further charge of $1,000 upon attending a university. This wringing of hands and mourning the fate of the working class compelled to bear this colossal burden of tertiary education in Australia via the taxation system ought to be exposed for the ludicrous argument that it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is humbug.
—As the honourable member for Lalor says, it is humbug.
—It is disgraceful.

—As the honourable gentleman said, it is disgraceful. Neverthelesss, it is a typical case of the conservative argument that we see on a whole range of issues. If the honourable member for Wentworth is sincere, I look forward to his taking a very firm stand when substantial cuts are next proposed in real and absolute terms in funds going to government schools or to poor needy schools in the private sector. I look forward to his standing up in absolute rage in his party room and saying: 'I have taken this stand on tertiary education which I believe is a principled stand. What I want to see you do is provide the type of education that places a working class child within range of a university and permits that working class child to remain within the school process to the point at which he is likely to qualify to enter a university'. I do not really expect that the name of the honourable member for Wentworth will be seen in the Liberal Party lists on this issue. SPEECH.PARA: I have been talking generally about the principle of the introduction of second degree fees in tertiary education. I wish to look specifically at the case that we are presented with tonight, although I think the broader debate is legitimate as clearly the measure before us is the thin end of the wedge. I refer to the question of what is to happen to second degree students now. The fact is that about 85 per cent of persons undertaking second degrees or second qualifications are not covered by scholarships which pay fees. Only 15 per cent receive scholarships to cover those fees. It might be said that the able person will always get a scholarship. The question of whether one gets a scholarship for a second degree is in fact no longer dependent upon whether one has the ability to do the particular course chosen. When I was an undergraduate student about 11 or 12 years ago, if one gained in the faculty of arts an upper second class honours degree one was assured of a scholarship to do a master's post-graduate course afterwards. I take that as a small example; there are many others I could use.

When I left university teaching last year one was extraordinarily lucky if one obtained a scholarship with a first class degree at an undergraduate level, yet the qualifications for entries into masters' degrees and Ph.Ds were such that one was still entitled to do those courses, as indeed one should, be entitled, if one was judged successful in obtaining a second class honours degree. As a result, a very substantial number of persons were seeking to go on to do additional studies without the benefit of any financial assistance from the State. They were grateful, nevertheless, that they did not have to pay fees. Those people, and there are many of them in tertiary institutions, are eking out a living by taking part time tutorials, taking waitressing jobs at night, and so on, in order to be able to undertake those studies. They will find the burden of an extra $1,000 virtually impossible to bear and, as a result, there will be a substantial reduction in the number of people undertaking those qualifications.

Again, I cite from personal experience that in the classes I taught, the bulk of the student population at Murdoch University, for example, were persons who were not immediate school leavers. In fact, they comprised something like 80 per cent of the student body. The bulk of those persons in my classes were from one of several backgrounds. They were persons who had become dissatisfied with their careers and wanted effectively to drop out and do something else. Perhaps those persons are not the sorts of persons we necessarily ought to subsidise, but that was only one type. A second type, and this was very prevalent, was a housewife seeking qualifications to enter the work force. Included in that group were a number of supporting mothers on supporting mother's benefits who, as a result either of the death of their husband or a divorce, were trying to place themselves in a situation where they were no longer dependent on the State, but could undertake valuable work in the work force. A third group, and they were not insubstantial, were persons who came from work in factories or other areas of employment which normally are classed as blue collar employment who wanted to take advantage of the educational opportunities permitted when no fees are payable. They were not a substantial number, but they will definitely be excluded by the application of this legislation, not from the first degree, but definitely from the prospects of taking up work later on. The qualification now is effectively a first class honours degree to be certain of a scholarship. Any university teacher will be able to confirm that first class honours degrees go, by and large, to the bright-eyed types who go through happily straight from school. I have in mind the smart-alick little 20-year olds and the rest of them-with all due respect to them-who have that extra intellectual edge that has not been dulled by years of responsibility. The people in the category I am talking about hardly ever find themselves in a situation where they are going to obtain first class honours degrees, but their fitness for post-graduate work is undoubted.

The Government is attacking these people for no purpose. This is not shifting the burden of the cost of tertiary education away from the working class. This is not introducing a wholesale user-pays principle. This is not removing the general burden from the taxpayer by producing a considerable amount for the Treasury. In fact, its collection will probably cost more than it pays. It is just a nasty, snide, deceitful breach of an electoral promise that will damage a number of people in this community who are using their very best efforts both to better themselves and to make a serious contribution.

We pamper university staffs and other staffs.
He then went on to say:

In conclusion, I come back to my original point. Education, especially tertiary education, has become a holy cow in this country. People do not attack it or criticise it and, what is much worse, they do not question it.

We need to examine carefully the claims that are made upon governments and in turn upon the taxpayers in the general community by various interest groups in the community. We should not necessarily accept their assertions that they are acting in the best interests of educational development in this country and in the best interests of students. There is a degree of self-interest in the propositions that are put forward. I do not say that that is necessarily reprehensible. It is to be expected to a large extent. But we should subject it to the same sceptical criticism which we use when we examine proposals by industry groups or any other interest groups that put propositions to a government favouring their industry or their interest in some way or another. That needs to be done a little more in the education debates that we have in this country.

I want to refer to some aspects of the Tertiary Education Commission report which is also being considered. The report contains some discussion of the reasons for the decline in numbers in enrolments in the tertiary sector. The decline in full time students commenced in 1978 and has continued each year since. It has been accompanied by larger increases in the numbers of part time and external students. In fact, as a percentage of school leavers, the numbers entering tertiary study has declined each year from 17.9 per cent of the previous year's 17-year-old population in 1974 to 14.6 per cent in 1981. The reasons offered in the report are twofold. Firstly, young people are not convinced of the value of higher education. Secondly, the decline in the availability of financial support for students is alleged to be a factor.

Unfortunately, the report does not discuss the first reason mentioned; that is, that young people are not convinced of the value of higher education. It appears to me that that is a significant matter which ought to be the subject of more examination and analysis. My impression has always been that the original purpose of the Commonwealth's abolition of fees and the provision of assistance to tertiary students was designed to help the children of low income families to obtain a tertiary education. As a number of people on both sides of the House have already noted in this debate, it appears that the participation rate of such children in the tertiary education sector has not changed noticeably as a result. But that situation is not discussed in the report. We are grateful to the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), who earlier in this debate discussed that aspect. The first reason offered-that is, that of disenchantment with higher education-is potentially very serious. It is a major failing of the report that it virtually ignored it beyond asserting the point. Apparently, this disenchantment with higher education has occurred in the face of various tertiary institutions touting courses around in some cases and, in other cases, easing entry requirements in order to encourage more students. I hope that in a future report there will be a greater examination of that factor.

I wish also to raise the point that I think we have one very great difficulty in this country with respect to tertiary education in that it involves a sector of the community which is almost entirely dependent on funding from the taxpayer through the Commonwealth Government. I think that poses the difficulty that whenever a government seeks to make a change in expenditure we face as a result attacks from various interest groups along the lines that the Government is in some way stifling academic freedom and in some way is launching an attack on education and the quality of education in this country. I think it would be a very good thing if a number of these interest groups in the education area in our country, such as the vice-chancellor's committee, the various staff associations and so on, turned their attention to how the education sector can broaden its financial base. I would have thought that it would be in their interests to raise a discussion about how fees could be levied in a way that would not disadvantage needy students, about how educational institutions could raise fees in a way that would assist them to develop at their discretion other courses that they felt could make a worthwhile contribution to the development of education in this country.

Unfortunately we do not have in Australia the number of private foundations that exist in, say, the United States of America which can offer substantial funding to various educational institutions. Perhaps institutions of higher learning should be talking to private industry and to other potential sources of funds in our community with a view to setting up foundations and various mechanisms which can provide them with alternative sources of funds with the result that the institutions would not be entirely dependent on the Commonwealth government and on the good will of the taxpayers every year for their continued existence. I think a great many false cries of academic freedom are raised in the context of funding of higher education. I think it would be good for all concerned if there were greater co-operation in the private areas of our economy in a way that enabled institutions of higher learning to have more long term private sources of funding which would ensure that they had a broader base for their continuing activities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 faithfully incorporates the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which, for the sake of brevity and aptness, I will refer to under its well known title of the razor gang. This gang of five Ministers had no experience or professional competence to make snap decisions on tertiary education. Nevertheless, the Government, over the heads of its own expert Tertiary Education Commission, has incorporated in the Bill those recommendations and in particular the reintroduction of fees for second and higher degree qualifications in universities and colleges of advanced education. The razor gang recommendations indicated an ad hoc approach to the problems of tertiary education which makes a mockery of the well formulated reports of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The post-graduate education of Australians is an investment in the future of Australia and is particularly vital in the training of scientists and technologists. Unlike many other countries in our region we are fortunate in having a large pool of educated young people from which we can draw to undertake research activities. Previous governments have recognised that the imposition of fees for tertiary study means that many potential students are deterred from undertaking post-graduate courses. The result of the decision to introduce fees for second and higher degree studies means that potential post-graduate students, many of whom support themselves with part time work, will be unable because of economic circumstances, to undertake post-graduate study. At a time when the Tertiary Education Comission has advised the Government that universities must strengthen their involvement and commitment to research activities, it is entirely irresponsible for the Government to introduce the proposed fees. Not only is it irresponsible but also it is ludicrous when considered in relation to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) when introducing the razor gang's report. He said:

The Review's starting point is that Australia's greatest resource is the Australian people and thus the role of Government is to enable people to exercise their abilities, their skills, their imaginations and their enterprises.

When this statement is considered in relation to another of the razor gang's recommendations, namely, the introduction of a loans scheme for needy undergraduates to offset the tertiary education allowance, it is veritably dishonest. The Government pays lip-service to the concept of equal opportunity for education for all and then requires students to seek loans instead of providing adequate student allowances.

Another matter that I wish to draw to the attention of honourable members is the run-down in research funds provided through the Australian Research Grants Scheme. This Scheme provides the largest single source of funds for basic research in Australia. Despite a growing national awareness that we must direct more attention to the development of our research potential, present funding for the ARGS is little more than half of the allocation made in 1966, when it was first initiated, as a proportion of total government spending. At 1966 price levels, individual ARGS grants have been reduced from $9,800 to $2,200 in 1981. This means that research projects which have great potential for the future of Australia are not being funded by the ARGS. In 1966 the allocation for the ARGS represented 0.09 per cent of the Government's outlay for all purposes. In 1981 the allocation represented 0.05 per cent of that outlay. When an international comparison was made of the spending on research and development as a percentage of gross domestic product for the year 1979-80, Australia ranked thirteenth, equal with Finland, Iceland and Italy and far below the United Kingdom, France, Sweden, Japan, Belgium and Canada. I call on the Government to reconsider the recommendation of the razor gang and to increase the funds provided through the ARGS so that the balance of education and research in Australia may not be irrevocably eroded.

I return to the provisions of the Bill in general and its impact on the tertiary education community. Tuesday, 13 October 1981 was indeed a black day for the Federal Government. That was the day when hundreds of university academics in universities all over Australia joined in rallies and demonstrations of protest against the Federal Government's policies on higher education. For the information of the Government, I might add, as part of this unprecedented show of unity, many vice-chancellors indicated active support for the demonstrations. The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) is rather fond of quoting newspaper editorials. He ignored the editorials which I now wish to quote. The editorial comments in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October stated:

Vice-Chancellors are among the least militant members of the community. Traditionally they prefer to lobby behind the scenes. By going public they have put on notice not only their disagreement with the Federal Government over a number of issues. The message is clear that the Government's interest in preserving academic autonomy is under suspicion.
Even the conservative Australian editorial of the same day indicated a similar view. It stated:

There is little doubt that the Government-and particularly the Minister for Education-has bungled the whole affair. Had any measure of political acumen been shown, had any genuine consultation taken place, had there been any overall national educational policy, defining principles on which to base sensible economies, then the universities would have had no cause to resort to the unprecedented action of a National Day of Protest.

Why did the honourable member for Wentworth not quote those editorials? I wish to look more specifically at the provisions of this Bill. Clause 6 deals with the introduction of tuition fees for second and higher degrees. A number of universities have indicated their unwillingness to collect fees. The University of Adelaide, the Griffith University and the University of Sydney have all indicated that they are unwilling to implement the collection of fees. This open defiance by a number of the leading universities in Australia is unprecedented and is evidence of the complete irresponsibility of the Government in this matter. Initially the Government announced that $8m would be received in revenue in 1982 and that $20m would be received in 1983-84, the first full year of the imposition of the fees. More informed sources now estimate that the revenue for 1982 will amount to only $3m. The imposition of fees is another of those election promises which the Government has blatantly broken. I quote the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) who made the following commitment just before the last federal election:
I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible reintroduction of tertiary fees.

The Minister is sitting at the table. I wonder what he has to say in answer to that quotation from what he had to say as an election promise which has been broken by this Government. What an empty promise this was. It is small wonder that when Government Ministers make assurances in the House, we on the Opposition side interject and deride their statements. This Government is the most prevaricative and dishonest of any government since Federation and we are rapidly approaching the stage where any statement from the Prime Minister or his Ministers is treated by everybody, including all members of the Parliament, as mere window dressing or as speaking as their bellies guide them, which expresses perfectly to me the contempt which this Government and its Ministers have towards anybody who seeks to criticise or oppose their policies. Surely the Government must realise that it is alienating many of its supporters by this arbitary imposition of fees which for universities can mean only an unwelcome additional administrative load which will result in a loss of perhaps two-thirds of the 1982 potential graduate student population at a time when a developing Australia desperately needs to improve its supply of skilled personnel.

I would now like to turn to clause 5, which empowers the Commission to disapprove for funding purposes the introduction of new teaching developments. When a similar provision was introduced in the 1978 Act there was considerable opposition to a provision which imposed an arbitrary dictate by the Federal Government on what should or should not be taught in an Australian university. As has been stated on many occasions the concept of university autonomy is an important concept which safeguards the role of universities in a democratic society. It guarantees the indpendence of universities from the day-to-day political interference of autocratic government. Contrary to the views of some members of this House, universities do not expect to receive an unlimited share of taxpayers' money, certainly not at a time when many other areas of public spending are being restricted. However, they do expect, when that money is available, to make the academic decisions regarding what is to be taught and by whom. Universities are subject to both government and community influence in the representation on their councils and senates. They are subject to overseeing by the Tertiary Education Commission and by various State and tertiary co-ordination bodies. In these circumstances this clause is included for reasons which in my opinion envisage the imposition of a political philosophy of conservatism. Why is it necessary to include this particular clause? As I said before, it is my view that if the Federal Government has any interest in preserving the independence and the scholastic excellence of universities, this clause should be removed from the Bill. Again I quote the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October:

Fuelling the academic fear have been a series of Federal Government initiatives, all seen as part of a policy to bring tertiary institutions to Canberra's heel. The recurrent income of universities has been reduced; the means test on TEAS for undergraduates has been tightened; there has been talk about reviewing tenure; and a fee has been levied on those doing second or higher degrees next year.

The inclusion of clause 6 will be opposed by the Opposition. I hope that the Government will also see the light and take the opportunity to remove clause 5 from the Bill. By taking this action it may be able to restore some of the lost confidence which university staff and students feel towards a government which has indicated by its actions that it is hostile to the independence of academic thought in this country. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the face of overwhelming opposition the Federal Government is forging ahead with its plan to impose tuition fees for students undertaking second and higher degrees. Public statements condemning the decision have come from the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee, the Federation of College Academics, the Australian Union of Students and the governing bodies of many colleges and universities, as well as the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations. The reduction in the number of post-graduate students which will result from the imposition of fees can only diminish our research effort which is already dismally inadequate by international standards. Australians may have cause to regret this short-sighted approach in years to come when we are forced to import both our technology and our workers. It is interesting to look at the Government's about-turn on this. On 3 July the Federal Government estimated that $8m would be netted from fees in 1982 and $20m in 1983-84, the first full year of the scheme's operation. Six weeks later in the 1981-82 Federal Budget Statements, at page 76, the Government had changed its mind and stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided to re-introduce fees on a limited basis for students commencing second and higher degrees from 1982 (except for recognised combined degrees and diplomas). The revenue in 1982 is estimated to be $4m; this is expected to rise to $20m in 1984.

Yet it has already halved its estimate a mere seven weeks since the original announcement. Irrationally this Government will still stick to its belief that $20m will be netted from fees in the third year of the scheme. Unless fees double or higher degree students double in number such a figure seems wildly optimistic. My main worry about these changes is that they may work to exclude students from working class backgrounds from the tertiary education system. For many years it was extremely difficult for working class students to enter university or to undertake other forms of tertiary education unless they were able to obtain scholarships. The abolition of tertiary fees by the Whitlam Government opened the door of our tertiary institutions to many thousands of young men and women who otherwise would have had little opportunity to pursue higher education and take advantage of their academic skills. Surely we do not want to turn the clock back to the days when advanced education was an exclusive preserve for the privileged. I well remember the days pre-1972 when one per cent of the kids who entered high schools north of the Yarra actually went on to tertiary education. Honourable members cannot tell me that that meant that brains stopped at the Yarra. What stopped was opportunity. I think this Government is bent on bringing that situation back again.

We have been told that a loans scheme may be introduced, supposedly to assist poorer students to finance their education. Apart from the overseas experience which suggests that such schemes are highly complex and expensive to operate, they can act as a deterrent to poorer students undertaking higher studies because of the potential financial burden involved. Here is the government which preaches that people should not live beyond their means telling young Australians that they can obtain a higher education only by putting themselves into hock up to the eyeballs. A responsible government would implement drastic changes to our education system only after long study and extensive consultation and would ensure that such changes were not made until adequate notice had been given. This Government implements policies thought up in secrecy by a group of Ministers with no expertise in the field. Meanwhile recommendations from expert bodies get filed in the rubbish bin. The present situation creates great dangers for the Australian education system. It can only be hoped that the Government will retreat from its current proposal before too much damage is caused.

The Tertiary Education Commission has been advocating for the past couple of years a redirection of effort away from teacher education and has said that the amalgamation of some colleges could assist in this process. It certainly did not say that 30 colleges of advanced education had to merge. The TEC also stated that the colleges involved would need three years to adjust to the amalgamation. While some rationalisation of the college sector, I believe, is both necessary and desirable, these heavy-handed threats by the Government are quite unjustified. Colleges faced with mergers need time to plan and reorganise in order to achieve education improvements, and several of these mergers simply should not proceed.

Along with every other member of parliament I have received submissions from colleges, from student bodies and from other interested people concerned with education. It is not just the Labor Party which opposes what the razor gang has announced. For instance, I refer to a document circulated by the Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, the Honourable A. J. Hunt, on 21 July, in which he said that the Victorian Government expressed surprise that the razor gang's announcement gave, for the first time, an indication that the State College of Victoria at Hawthorn, the Institute of Catholic Education, and the Institute of Early Childhood Development should somehow, for some unstated reason, be merged with some other unspecified institution or institutions. He pointed out that this had never previously been suggested to the Victorian Government by the Commonwealth and that the Victorian Government had been unable, since this surprise announcement, to ascertain any rational basis for those requirements. Mr Hunt further stated that the Victorian Government remained convinced that the names of these three institutions were included in error. He said:
It is noteworthy that the requirements for the Institute of Catholic Education to merge with some other body, a most obvious error, has now been withdrawn.

Everyone with experience of the workings of government had forecast that it assuredly would. The educational logic for the continued separate existence of the Institute of Early Childhood Development is precisely the same as that existing for the Institute of Catholic Education. I suggest that it is about time the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) based his recommendations on sound educational logic instead of fairy tales dreamed up by bureaucrats in Canberra to suit the political strategies of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Tertiary education in the colleges of advanced education is being pushed down a dead end road against the tide of reason on the pretence that this will save the country money. If it will save the country money, the Minister is certainly not telling us anything about costing.

The Labor Party is strongly opposed to the reimposition of fees and will move to abolish any fees introduced as soon as possible. The last Labor Government introduced free tertiary education and the next Labor Government will restore it. Whilst recognising that there is some need for rationalisation in colleges, the worst aspect of college amalgamations or closures is the implication that the number of student places will be reduced. This is the only way in which savings will result as the colleges move to cut staff. The Labor Party is strongly opposed to any overall reduction in student places in colleges. I support my colleague, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), who said that the mature women who are attempting to enter the work force will suffer the most. Australia needs more students in full time education, not fewer.

The latest criticism of the Government's actions and possibly the hardest to rebut comes from the Tertiary Education Commission itself. The Commission, in its annual report tabled in the House on 23 September, warns of a short term drop in the standards of some institutions. This is because the Government has cut back funds for universities and colleges of advanced education. In fact, between 1981 and 1984 funds for existing activities will be reduced by about $18m a year. The Government doggedly sticks to the line that the forced amalgamations of institutions will bring about substantial savings to make up for this shortfall. As the Commission points out in its report, it has advised the Government that the amalgamations will save little in the short to medium term. Not surprisingly, the Commission seems genuinely puzzled that the Government perseveres with an obviously fallacious line of argument in the face of expert advice. The Commission also stated:
In the longer term, this decline can only be avoided by increased Government financial assistance or by cutting back activities.
Only the most starry-eyed optimist could imagine this miserable Government providing additional funds, so only one outcome is possible.

In summary, I say that this Government has completely failed to respond to the urgent needs of tertiary education. I predict that if it continues with its policies they will result in fewer full time students, a further decline in student financial support, tertiary education becoming more and more a preserve of the wealthy, and the very quick return of a Labor government to Canberra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 8 September:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have 3 weeks elapsed since it became public knowledge that certain meat exports from Australia had been adulterated.
(2) Did he say that only one company was involved in this massive fraud.
(3) If so, is it a fact that in spite of this, the investigating authorities are no nearer to apprehending and charging the main culprits.
(4) Is he able to say whether it has been reported within the meat industry that the key suspect in this case has in fact disappeared and cannot be traced.

(5) Will he ensure that investigations in this case are competently carried out to ensure that there is no repetition of the unsatisfactory and inconclusive situation which developed in respect of the so-called Greek conspiracy persecutions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any cases of Tenosynovitis been reported to date in the Department or Statutory Authorities under the Minister's jurisdiction.

(2) If so, will the Minister state (a) how many cases have been reported, (b) in what types of work the affected persons were engaged, (c) of the cases reported how many were in respect of (i) female and (ii) male employees and (d) what age brackets appear to be most affected, in the Department and each Statutory Authority.
(3) Will the Minister provide similar information in respect of carpal tunnel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No comprehensive statistical records are maintained on the incidence of Tenosynovitis or Carpal Tunnel.

In this sample seven females and three males were affected ranging in ages from 17 to 55. The claimants were all civilian employees of the Department except one female member of the Army Reserve.

The provision of comprehensive statistical data to answer the honourable member's question would require a lengthy manual search of thousands of individual records necessitating a substantial diversion of manpower from essential tasks and is not proposed in the circumstances.
