QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For what reason will new public housing tenants be ineligible to claim supplementary assistance under the guidelines announced in the 1981-82 Budget.
(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that rent for public housing in Queensland, that is, State Housing Commission home rent, has increased by more than 150 per cent since 1974.
(3) Has the cost of rental of public housing in other States increased by a comparable percentage.
(4) Was the previous increase in supplementary assistance in 1974.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under current arrangements, pensioners and beneficiaries who are public housing tenants and who receive supplementary assistance generally also receive a rent rebate or similar concession from the public housing authority. The value of the State housing authority rent rebates generally has been estimated at an average of $16 a week per recipent in 1979-80. The change in supplementary assistance eligibility conditions from February 1982 is intended to avoid this overlap in assistance by withdrawing the form of assistance that is of lesser value to its recipents. Current recipients of supplementary assistance will, however, retain their entitlements.
(2) I refer the honourable member to my answer to Part (2) of House of Representatives Question No. 623 (Hansard, 13 May 1981, page 2366).
(3) Detailed information necessary to answer this question is not readily available from Commonwealth sources.
(4) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government, in prospectively assessing university grant out-turn moneys for 1982, prejudicing the outcome of Mr Justice Ludeke's review of academic salaries which is presently before the Academic Salaries Tribual.
(2) If not, and if the Government's prospective estimate of Mr Justice Ludeke's finding proves to be inadequate, will the 1982 grant moneys be supplemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The change in the method of cost adjustment for university grants, involving a change from retrospective to prospective supplementation, cannot be said to prejudice the outcome of Mr Justice Ludeke's review of academic salaries. The new arrangement has been adopted to provide a more rigorous approach towards cost adjustment of tertiary grants which in the past has provided additional funds automatically and which has consequently had a tendency to insulate educational institutions from the effects of inflation.

In this way it is designed to encourage greater efficiency in institutions. The Government does not believe that this change in the method of cost adjustment of grants affects the role of the Academic Salaries Tribunal as specified in Section 12C of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973.

(2) In accepting the prospective arrangements for adjusting the 1982 program from estimated December 1980 prices to outturn prices, the Government agreed to a total package based on a number of assumptions relating to the timing and quantum of salary and non-salary increases, the program mix and the rate of cash flow during the year. The final outcome of each of these components may be different from the prospective allowance. The Government is not in a position to indicate a response to hypothetical variations from the assumptions involved in individual components in isolation from the total package.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Despite cuts in real terms in his Department's allocation for UNESCO activities, has the sum budgeted for commission and committee travel nearly doubled from $30,950 to $55,000 whilst that allocated to commission projects has fallen from $70,400 to $48,000.
(2) If so, what is the reason for this re-ordering of priorities in the UNESCO allocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The sums, as set out in the paper provided to Estimates Committees, are as quoted.

(2) The amount which the Australian National Commission for UNESCO has budgeted in 1981-82 for Commission and Committee fares and travel allowance has increased steeply largely because of the rises in domestic airfares, eg 50 per cent on flights to Canberra from Sydney to Melbourne over the past twelve months, higher rates of travelling allowances (approximately 15 per cent from May 1980) and the cost of meetings carried over from the previous financial year.

Following the Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Australian National Commission for Unesco re-examined its priorities within the funds available for 1981/82. It decided to maintain the frequency of meetings of the Commission and its Executive in order to fulfil its major role, which is to provide advice to the Government on the Unesco international program. The Commission has therefore had to scale down its seminar program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What percentage of the income of (a) universities and (b) colleges of advanced education (in appropriate years) did fees represent in each year from 1965 to 1973 and what is the estimated percentage for 1982, given projected enrolment figures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Full details of the information sought in respect of the years 1965 to 1973 are not readily available. However, prior to 1973 fees in universities ranged from 17 to 19 per cent of recurrent grants. Concerning colleges of advanced education, virtually no fees were charged in most teachers colleges as students were generally trainees of State Education Departments. Institutes of technology and other CAEs charged fees at rates which were significantly lower than those for universities; they represented around 10 per cent of grants.

For 1982, using 1980 enrolment figures and calculating from recurrent grants expressed on an outturn basis, it is estimated that fees revenue would represent approximately 0.5 per cent of the recurrent grants to universities and CAE's. Since fees will only be paid in 1982 by students commencing second and higher degrees, this percentage would increase in subsequent years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say which countries having a system of public funding for election campaigns and other political party activities conducted a referendum or some form of public inquiry prior to introducing public funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Electoral Office has details of public funding schemes in 11 overseas countries-United States of America, Canada, West Germany, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Italy, Austria, France and the United Kingdom.

From the information available to it, in none of the above 11 countries was a referendum held prior to the introduction of public funding and in only 3 of these countries-Canada, Sweden and Norway-was some form of public inquiry conducted before the public funding scheme was introduced. It is to be noted that the United Kingdom Government appointed a committee of inquiry (headed by Lord Houghton) to consider whether provision should be made from public funds to assist political parties to carry out their functions outside Parliament, but the Public subsidisation scheme recommended by the Houghton Committee has not been introduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister, representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For what reason has the government imposed a $10 threshold on the payment of rent in respect of eligibility for supplementary assistance.
(2) Is it a fact that, prior to the 1981-82 Budget, a pensioner paying $5 a week rent, and receiving no income other than his or her pension, could receive $5 a week supplementary assistance.

(3) Is it a fact, that as a result of the Budget, from February 1982, a pensioner paying $5 a week rent, and receiving no income other than his or her pension, will not receive any supplementary assistance.
(4) Is it a fact that a pensioner receiving no income other than his or her pension, will not be eligible to claim for supplementary assistance unless paying more than $10 a week rent.

(5) In order for a pensioner to be eligible for $5 a week supplementary assistance, will that pensioner have to be paying at least $20 a week in rent under the new eligibility guidelines for the payment of supplementary assistance announced in the Budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's 1981-82 Budget decisions on supplementary assistance were aimed at redirecting available, and extending additional, assistance to pensioners most in need through the burden of rental costs.

The maximum rate of supplementary assistance will be increased from $5 to $8 a week and the income test eased to provide some incentive to pensioners in receipt of supplementary assistance to obtain small amounts of private income.
To enable these steps to be taken, the Government has moved to direct supplementary assistance away from those who benefit as public housing tenants or who pay nominal private rents.
From February 1982 the rate of supplementary assistance for private tenants will be 50 per cent of any rent in excess of $10 a week, to a maximum of $8 a week at rents of $26 a week or more.

Pensioners paying rents of $10 a week or less could be expected to meet this cost from the basic pension. Private rents of between $10 and $20 a week will attract supplementary assistance, although generally at less than current rates. Rents in this range are still well below average market rents.
These changes will not operate to the disadvantage of those already receiving supplementary assistance.
(2) Yes.

(3) to (5) From February 1982, new applicants for supplementary assistance will have to qualify under the new provisions outlined above; however, all current recipients when the new provisions commence will be able to continue to receive payments according to present rates and conditions until such time as they cease to qualify under these conditions or would benefit from the new arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the details of (a) adequate physical protection, and 'fallback safeguards', (b) application of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards and (c) prior consent rights over retransfer of Australian supplied uranium, contained in the Australian-France Nuclear Transfers Agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The text of the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the French Republic concerning Nuclear Transfers between Australia and France was presented to the Parliament on 26 March 1981. The details of adequate physical protection, ''fallback safeguards'', application of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards and prior consent rights over retransfer of Australian supplied uranium are all contained in the text of the Agreement. It is necessary to read the Agreement as a whole in order to see the way in which Australia's requirements including those referred to in the question are fulfilled. As mentioned in the statement to Parliament on 26 March, the provisions of the agreement fully meet the requirements of the Government's nuclear safeguards policy, announced by the Prime Minister on 24 May 1977.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the discussions that preceded the implementation of the Australia-France Nuclear Transfers Agreement, did the Government of Australia at any time raise the question of French Nuclear Testing in the Pacific Ocean region, and the concern of Australia, and other regional nations about this testing; if not, why not.
(2) If the issue was raised, do provisions in the Treaty impose any limitations on French Nuclear testing in the Pacific Region; if so, what provisions and what are the limitations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has frequently reiterated its strong opposition to France's continued nuclear testing in the South Pacific before, during and since the negotiation of the Australia-France Nuclear Transfers Agreement. France is also well aware of Australia's commitment to the conclusion of a treaty open to all States banning the testing of nuclear explosive devices in all environments.

(2) No. The Australia-France and Australia-EURATOM Nuclear Transfers Agreements provide that there can be no diversion of Australian Origin nuclear material from peaceful, civil uses to military or explosive purposes. The Government's nuclear safeguards policy permits the negotiation of agreements with nuclear weapons states provided those states accept all the stringent requirements of Australia's policy, including the application of International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards to their civil nuclear industries. France has done so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or his Department's Industry Division define the role of the Committee of Reference on Defence Force Pay in its submission.
(2) Did the Committee of Reference in fact follow the role set out in the submission.

(3) Was the definition of the task of the Committee of Reference as set out in his Department's submission that special and service allowances should not be investigated or increased, and that only pay and some allowances should be included in the definition of remuneration.
(4) Will he table submissions made by the Tri-Services Committee and also that submitted by the Industrial Division of his Department.
(5) Did his Department recommend to the Committee that departures from the Kerr-Woodward recommendations should be minimised, and that changes to allowances should also be kept to a minimum.

(6) Did his Department submit to the Committee that skills of a military nature should not be assessed on the same basis as technical and professional skills relatable to civilian employment and that military skills should be excluded from work value change evaluations for trades personnel.
(7) Did his Department also recommend to the Committee that the Service allowance should not be subject to any work value increases.

(8) Is he satisfied that in opposing significant alterations in work value related areas, the discounting of military skills of trades personnel and the recommendations that Service allowances not be subject to work value changes, that his Department was looking after the interests of Service personnel as he claimed in Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. As appropriate the submission of the Department's Industrial Division indicated to the Committee of Reference a view as to the intended coverage of the reference dated 22 July 1980.

(2) In its second report (Work Value Change) dated 20 August 1981, the Committee of Reference in some cases accepted and in some cases did not accept the views on coverage put forward by the Industrial Division. Chapters II and VIII of the report refer.

(3) On the question of allowances which were included within the reference the view of the Department's Industrial Division was that Service Allowance and 5 other allowances in the nature of pay, which contained work value elements, should be considered by the Committee of Reference. The Committee in its second report indicated that Services Allowance and 10 other allowances would be covered.

(4) The Committee of Reference is still considering aspects of the two submissions. I am prepared to make a copy of each available on a personal basis to the honourable member, pending final report by the Committee, at which time the submissions will be made available to the House.
(5) The Industrial Division's submission was concerned to see that the principles established by Kerr/Woodward should be before the Committee of Reference during its deliberations.

(6) The essence of the Industrial Division submission is that salary rates should reflect the highest function regularly performed, that payment for lateral skills or acquisition of military skills by 'trades' is not a valid factor in salary assessment; otherwise cumulative financial recognition of military skills acquired by 'trades' personnel would considerably disadvantage personnel who only possess military skills.

(7) No. On the contrary, the Deparment's Industrial Division submission suggested to the Committee of Reference that any change in work value which it determined for Defence Force members, should find expression both in the normal salary for the member as well as the work value segment of any allowances. This view was specifically invoked in relation to Service Allowance.

(8) The main conern of the Department's Industrial Division in its submission was to see that the Committee of Reference had before it all relevant facts relating to its reference and to offer comment and views on particular aspects of the reference. In this it was doing no more than was publicly invited by the Committee of Reference. It is the Government's intention that a full spectrum of relevant views should be before the Committee of Reference when it deliberates on such a fundamental issue as the remuneration of the Defence Force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that his Department during the week 13-19 September 1981, ordered yet another Australian Federal Police inquiry into yet another rural industry; the abalone industry.
(2) If so, what alerted his Department to a need for a Federal Police inquiry and when was this information provided.
(3) What aspects of the abalone industry are being invesigated by the police.
(4) Have complaints been received from the Japanese relating to the quality of Australian exports of abalone.
(5) What are the responsibilities of inspectors within his Department in terms of checking abalone for export.
(6) Is he able to say whether the industry, which is now meeting 50 per cent of inspection charges, is satisfied with the scope and standards of inspections by his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. I wrote to my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services on 11 September 1981 seeking his assistance in arranging for the Australian Federal Police to investigate certain alleged irregularities in relation to the operations of a Victorian-based company which exports abalone.

(2) The Chairman of the Tasmanian Fisheries Development Authority wrote to my Department on 28 May 1981 advising that they were preparing a case for consideration on possible breaches of the Exports (Fish) Regulations. The Authority wrote again on 15 June requesting advice on the action my Department would take to stop the export of illegally processed abalone. My Department concluded preliminary investigations in Melbourne between 16 June and 10 July but could find no evidence to support the allegation. Additional information was received from the Authority on 17 August.

(3) The Authority alleged that a Victorian based company which has premises registered under the Exports (Fish) Regulations, received abalone for export that had not been processed in a registered export establishment.

(5) The responsibilities of Fish Exports Inspectors are defined by the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act and the Exports (Fish) Regulations and cover four broad areas which may be summarised as follows-
(a) inspection of premises as well as operating requirements to verify complience with basic hygiene standards in relation to the processing, storage and transport of fish;
(b) inspection of product to verify compliance with commodity standards designed to ensure that fish is sound, properly packaged, and of minimum quality;
(c) examination of labelling to ensure it accurately describes the product to which it is applied; and
(d) the issue of export documentation when product complies with the legislation.
(6) There is no evidence that the industry is not satisfied with the scope and standard of export fish inspection which is kept under continuing review in consultation with industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a claim by the Universities Commission to the Tertiary Education Commission that Newcastle College of Advanced Education has received Advanced Education Council funds totalling some 15 per cent above that appropriate to the student load achieved in 1981; if so, is there any substance to this claim.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article on page 22 of 'The Ugly Side of Australian Business' by T. Hall, wherein it is claimed that a United States company, Industrial Bio-Test, destroyed all of its toxicological testing records before they could be examined by Federal authorities.
(2) If so, is he able to say whether there is any substance to this report.
(3) How many products have been assessed by National Health and Medical Research Council Committees or the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee on the basis of test data from Industrial Biotest.
(4) If the records referred to in part (1) were destroyed what reassessment has been made of each of the products referred to in part (3).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the article on page 22 of 'The Ugly Side of Australian Business' by T. Hall which refers to the accidental destruction of toxicological records by Industrial Biotest Laboratories (IBT).

(2) It is true that senior employees have IBT have been charged with devising and intending to devise a scheme to defraud clients and United States Government agencies by writing and distributing false and fraudulent study reports and false and fraudulent explanations of studies and study reports.
I am not aware however, that reports were deliberately destroyed as suggested by Mr Hall.

(3) Approximately 100 chemicals (pesticides and drugs) have been supported in part by toxicological studies carried out by IBT. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) and the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) have approved most of these chemicals for use in Australia. It is known, however that many IBT studies have since been validated and, in most cases, formed only part of the overall toxicological evaluation of the chemicals of concern. In addition, the bulk of the toxicological assessment for each chemical was undertaken by other independent laboratories and there has therefore been sufficient toxicological evaluation overall on which to assess human safety considerations.

For this reason the NH and MRC and the ADEC, as with the U.S. and Canadian Governments, have not banned any of the chemicals concerned. This action, especially by the U.S. Environmental Agency, further highlights the fact that there is little reason to believe any human hazard exists.

(4) Official requirements to have IBT data validated have been in effect in the U.S.A. and Canada since 1977. In this connection there is a Canadian/U.S.A. collaborative program of validation and Canadian health authorities have announced that it will take at least another year to complete the task. The Canadian and U.S. Governments have been approached to ensure that Australian authorities are kept informed as IBT studies are validated or as new studies which are being undertaken are evaluated.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Photographs of Minister in Departmental Journal

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Why are there only 2 photographs of him in Volume 31, Number 1 of 1981 of Health, the Journal of his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Unlike the honourable member, I had not taken the time to count my appearances in Volume 31, No. 1, of Health Journal. Indeed I suppose I should be flattered by his concern that I appear only twice.

However I should like to point out that judgments on the number of ministerial photographs or on the inclusion of any other material in Health Journal are made solely by my Department. I have no editorial function in its production. The Department does not submit-nor do I intend to ask for it to submit-proposed copy and illustrations to me for approval before publication. Each issue is as fresh to me on arrival as it is to the honourable member.
If, however, he would like to see more photographs of me in the Journal, I will be quite happy to pass his suggestion on to my Department.
